## Page 4

ABSTRACT Archaeological investigations were conducted for approximately 90% of fee-simple purchase areas for the proposed Superconducting Super Collider between October 1989 and July 1990. These studies are ongoing. Eventually, the entire 54 mile ring will be surveyed since geotechnical activities and indirect impacts will be performed for the full circuit. In all, 7 archaeological sites have been recorded and have received preliminary evaluations of their potential eligibility for nomination to the National Register of Historic Places. Cultural resources which will be directly impacted by this project include prehistoric camps and tool manufacturing areas, historic farmsteads, schools and churches, cotton gins, a small rural comimunity (Boz), and the Ellis County Poor Farm. These resources will be irrevocably ultered by the project and this report presents the first phase of treatment for the loss of this cultural heritage. == Pot es J aS il _| C33

## Page 5

EE mH HH HH HE MANAGEMENT SUMMARY From October 1989 to July 1990, the Archaeology Research Program of Southern Methodist University conducted a background and archival search and pedestrian reconnaissances of proposed land acquisitions and impact areas for archaeological and cultural resources within the Superconducting Super Collider. This project is under construction by the Department of Energy; Universities Research Association, Inc.; Superconducting Super Collider Laboratory; and Texas Natural Resources Laboratory Commission. Construction of this machine will directly affect about 10,000 acres of Ellis County, Texas. An additional 10,000 acres over the ring may be indirectly impacted. Approximately 43 historic and prehistoric archaeological sites had been recorded in Ellis County prior to commehcement of this work. An additional 77 archaeological sites have now been recorded in approximately 90% of the fee-simple purchase areas. Thirteen sites are prehistoric, two are prehistoric/historic, and sixty-two are historic. The archaeological research conducted for the project follows the Secretary of Interior's Standards and Guidelines, the Texas Antiquities Code, and the Council of Texas Archaeologist's Guidelines. This includes the inventory and evaluation of a number of cultural resources, including oral history, vegetation ecology, architecture, primary and secondary archival sources, dendrochronology, and archaeology. The multidisciplinary focus of this research has involved the participation of nonarchaeological professionals, to develop a more complete and accurate cultural model for the SSC project area. These resources, taken together, offer a more detailed picture of the local population (and inferentially, the prehistoric populations) than would otherwise be possible. The primary objective of this project is the collection and synthesis of the greatest amount of data possible and to record and report this information in a manner that it can be compared with different projects from region to region. This report is an interim document which presents the results of the investigations conducted to date. Since land access and project scheduling are ongoing, additional surveys, informant interviews, and other research will be necessary to completely inventory and evaluate the cultural resources affected by the Superconducting Super Collider. These will be attached to this report, which is the first of several phases of compliance with Federal and State cultural resources laws and guidelines. ii

## Page 15

ay J is me ese a INTRODUCTION 1 The Archaeology Research Program of Southern Methodist University, under contract (ESC 90821) with Universities Research Association, Inc., has performed field surveys of proposed fee-simple purchase by David H. Jumey areas and impact areas associated with the Superconducting Super Collider in Ellis County, Texas. The lead Federal Agency responsible for this project is the Department of Energy. The responsibilities for compliance with federal and state cultural resources protection laws and guidelines are shared by the Idaho National_ Engineering Laboratory Commission, EG&G, Inc.; the Superconducting Super Collider Laboratory; and the Texas Natural Resources Laboratory Commission. The Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) is located entirely within Ellis County, Texas (Figure 1-1). This project is south of the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area, and the present landscape consists primarily of rural farmlands. The SSC will be a 54 mile ring which completely encircles the town of Waxahachie (Figure 1-2). Other towns and communities adjacent to the SSC include (clockwise from the northwest) Midlothian, Red Oak, Palmer, Garrett, Ennis, Bardwell, Avalon, Forreston, Italy, and Maypearl. The entire community of Boz will be within the West Campus. The principal impacts to the Ellis County landscape will be confined to fee-simple purchase areas for the East and West Campuses, shaft penetrations, and cooling ponds (Figure 1-3). Most of the 54 mile ring will not produce any direct impacts to the land surface, since the SSC will be constructed by boring a tunnel over 100 feet below the ground, in bedrock. The most extensive impacts will be within the West Campus, where over 300 acres will be excavated, and an entire administrative and scientific complex will be constructed. The largest proposed project areas under consideration are the West Campus, with approximately 7500 acres; the East Campus, with approximately 1500 acres; and the Ellis County Farm, with approximately 450 acres, In addition, 25 shaft penetration areas are planned, totalling approximately 1256 acres. Some roads will be improved, and approximately 5 miles of new road construction is planned. Other roadways will be upgraded and improved and additional utilities will be needed. All of these areas will receive full pedestrian reconnaissance, identifying all cultural resources. Approximately 90% of fee-simple purchase areas has been completed as of this interim report. The archaeological survey for the SSC was conducted to identify any cultural resources within the project area which may be potentially eligible for the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP). Protection of these resources is required by a number of federal laws and regulations, including but not

## Page 19

i ee I - \ J q | limited to the Antiquities Act of 1906 (34USC225); Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act of 1935 (49USC666); Archaeological and Historical Conservation Act of 1974 (88USC174); National Historical Preservation Acts of 1966 and 1980 (80USC915 and 94USC2987); National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (83USC852); Executive Order Number 11593 of 1971 (36CFR9821); and Archaeological Resources Protection Act of 1979, 1980, and 1988 (94USC2987, 102USC2778, and 102USC2983). All of these regulations direct federal land managers to implement cultural resources inventory and assessment programs with the consultation of the SHPO, Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, and interested parties. The present, first phase archaeological survey was designed to comply with standard archaeological survey methodology as defined in the Department of the Interior's Standards and Guidelines (National Park Service 1983), the Council of Texas Guidelines (CTA 1987), and the regulations implementing the Texas Antiquities Code (13TAC41). In all, approximately 90% of the fee-simple purchases has been surveyed to date (September 11, 1990). When the remainder of the ring is considered, approximately 70% of the entire project area has received intensive coverage. Sixty-two historic sites, thirteen prehistoric, and two multiple component prehistoric/historic sites have been identified, recorded, and have received preliminary evaluations. These sites have been categorized according to a three level priority for further work (high, medium, low). A high priority indicates that the property may be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP); and 16 archaeological sites have been classified as high priority. A medium priority indicates that the NRHP eligibility is not known at present and further work is recommended; twenty-eight archaeological sites have been classified as medium priority. A low priority indicates that the archaeological site is probably not eligible for the NRHP, and 33 properties have been classified as low priority. This report consists of eight chapters, accompanied by four appendices, which present interim information on recorded cultural properties and a summary of initial researches on the cultural background of the region. Chapter 2 of this report describes the environmental setting for Ellis County. The bedrock geology is briefly summarized and evaluated for the potential preservation of archaeological sites, The soils, climate, and vegetation are discussed in some detail, since these aspects of the environment are important to understanding the human use and occupation of the region. The climate has fluctuated in the past, which has caused shifts in the vegetation and has also affected human settlements and use of the project area. Chapter 3 presents the prehistoric archaeological background for the region. Due to the fact that few large archaeological studies have been performed in Ellis County, this chapter draws on previous research in Dallas, Tarrant, and Navarro Counties as well as other areas of northem, central, and eastern Texas and adjacent states of Oklahoma, Arkansas, and Louisiana. Two important aspects of prehistoric settlement and use of Ellis County are naturally occurring springs to which people were attracted, and ancient upland gravels (Uvalde) which were exploited for the manufacture of stone tools. At present, these two prehistoric property types, (i.e., spring heads and upland gravel sources) have not been adequately investigated in this region. Future studies associated with the SSC should explore more fully these site types using the 1-2

Such investigations will help to expand the local settlement patterns which are heavily biased by large reservoir projects consisting mostly of fluvial bottomlands and valley flank studies. Archaeological studies of large sections of the Blackland prairie ecosystem have not been undertaken to date in Texas placing important emphasis on the SSC studies described here. Integrating known and newly found sites in the greater SSC project area will provide a strong data base to fill in the void between wooded environments to the east and grassland and savannah environments of the lower Great Plains to the west. Based on known prehistoric sites in Ellis County, chipping areas, camps, habitations, and burial grounds are known to be present. The SSC project, however, is primarily upland, which has fewer sites than lowlands. Chapter 4 presents the historic background for Ellis County. Specific events and persons that have influenced the settlement and development of the county are summarized. Farming, by both landowners and tenants has played the most significant role in Ellis County's history and the majority of recorded historic archaeological sites are farmsteads. Cotton gins, schools, churches, and the Ellis County Poor Farm are other historic property types which represent important aspects of the development of the county. Chapter 5, the Research Design, integrates the historical significance of archaeological properties within a series of questions about human behavior. This is a preliminary design, which involves the overriding theme of Human Ecology and requires the simultaneous reconstruction of past lifeways and past environments. The research questions provide an empirical means of evaluating the importance of specific archaeological properties in terms of the data contained in them and their historical context. Chapter 6 is a description of the 13 prehistoric sites and the prehistoric components at two prehistoric/historic sites. The value of each is discussed in relation to the present environment and the potential yield of information that may be used to address the research questions. Prehistoric properties are evaluated for their potential significance under Criteria A, B, C, when appropriate, in addition to Criterion D. Chapter 7 contains the descriptions of the 62 historic properties and the historic components of two prehistoric/historic sites. The nature of each site is discussed, previous occupants or owners are identified, the property's applicability to meet National Register Criteria A, B, C, and D is reviewed, and its potential to yield information useful to address research questions is summarized. Chapter 8 summarizes the prehistoric and historic site assessments and provides recommendations for further work. The management of cultural resources is an ongoing educational and scientific process, and a number of options should be considered in the treatment of properties impacted by the SSC. Appendix A is a descriptive summary of investigations that have been conducted for the geotechnical explorations necessary to plan construction. This study was conducted simultaneously with the survey of fee-simple purchase areas. However, any cultural resources that were identified were avoided by redesigning the access routes or moving the bore location. 1-3 Ee es

Appendix D is incomplete at present (October 1990), since this is an ongoing project involving archaeological collections performed by non-professional archaeologists. This information is useful for understanding the range of archaeological resources that is present in Ellis County. For example, collections that have been made over several decades greatly augment data obtained by single visit archaeological reconnaissances. The research philosophy employed in the SSC archaelogical survey is that of focused multidisciplinary research, examining numerous facets of the cultural and environmental ecology (past and present) for the region. As noted by Martha Doty Freeman (Story et al. 1990:367-384) many Cultural Resource Management projects never pass beyond descriptions of the archaeological data as manifestations of historical events. ARP has achieved significant results in the elucidation of the late prehistoric settlement for the Richland Creek region, specifically the investigations of Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites (Bruseth and Martin 1987:159-167) and the Cobb-Pool site in Joe Pool Lake (Peter and McGregor 1988). Also, ARP has employed multidisciplinary approaches in the study of historical archaeological sites, employing non-archaeological professionals in history, architecture, and ethnology. Oral history, dendrochronology, architectural history, cemetery studies, and reconstruction of the cultural environmental landscape within and around project areas have been conducted for Richland Creek (Moir and Jurney 1987; Jumey and Moir 1987), Joe Pool Lake (Moir et al. 1988; Jurney et al. 1988), and North Central Texas (Jumey et al. 1989). As prehistoric and historic properties considered eligible are studied further, it will be necessary to involve some to explore more fully the range of important data present. Eventually, this database will allow the development of a Cultural Resources Managment Plan for the SSC which will not only detail local cultural patterns, but also relate them to regional ones. Finally, since detailed studies of historic and prehistoric properties in sizeable areas of the Blackland Prairie Belt in North Central Texas and away from major alluvial valleys have not been conducted to date, the investigations associated with the SSC will offer an opportunity to fill some important local and regional data gaps. 1-4

Cole GEOLOGY The SSC project is located in the north-central portion of Texas, which is classified as the West Gulf Coastal Plain Section of the Coastal Plain Province (Fenneman 1938). This area is generally characterized by low gently rolling relief formed from the weathering of relatively soft sedimentary rocks. The surface geology (Figure 2-1) consists of a series of latest Cretaceous and Paleocene age (63 million years old) lithified sediments of various hardnesses and rates of erosion. The principal geologic strata (west to east) are the Eagle Ford Group, the Austin Chalk, and the lower Taylor Marl (Ozan Formation). The Eagle Ford Group and the Taylor Marl comprise all of the project area and are most susceptible to erosion. The landscape is characterized by broad rolling uplands dissected by low gradient streams. The Austin Chalk is a clayey limestone which is more resistant to weathering, but which is relatively unstable where exposed. This escarpment, or surface landform is exposed from northeast Texas, through Dallas and extends to near San Antonio, although various limestones are articulated in the southernmost area. In areas such as Cedar Hill, in southwestern Dallas County, the Austin Chalk forms distinct escarpments while in an area 3 miles west of the western project boundary, near Maypearl, this escarpment is less pronounced. Another minor stratum, consisting of unconsolidated Quaternary deposits, is the Wolf City Sand. This stratum is adjacent to the Trinity River Trench, and for the most part, is outside the Study area. The Eagle Ford Group consists of shale, sandstone and limestone, with calcareous concretions. Sandstone and sandy limestone are in the upper part, with bentonites in the lower part. A hard limestone bed marks the base in Ellis and Johnson Counties, and low cuestas 200-300 feet thick have formed in small localities. The Austin Chalk is divided into three parts, with chalk throughout the upper and lower parts. There are some interbeds of calcareous clay. The formation weathers white with scarce marine megafossils. It is from 300-500 feet thick and will be the most extensive formation within the SSC project area. The Ozan Formation, or Lower Taylor Marl consists of clay with calcareous silt and sand increasing toward the top of the formation. It grades upward to the Wolfe City Sand. There are common marine megafossils and the thickness is over 500 feet. The formation weathers bright brownish gray. oe ran 2-1

= = i 4M { = 4 C7} omecaman] 1) t ! { } | al ; (Ez) a A minor, although culturally significant unconsolidated deposit is a thin veneer of pebble-sized to small cobble-sized quartzite, chert, jasper cobbles, and petrified (silicified) wood fragments which mantles the uplands along Chambers Creek and the eastern project area. These appear to be water worn lag gravels from long abandoned stream channels, dating to the early stages of the Pleistocene or earlier (Byrd 1971; Menzer and Slaughter 1971; Banks 1990). These gravels provide the only locally available sources for the manufacture of stone tools. Banks (1990) indicates that the term "Uvalde" gravels can be used to describe this feature which is an ubiquitous term applied to almost all relict gravel deposits on late Tertiary and Pleistocene remnants of the High Plains that once extended as far to the east as Fort Worth, with redeposited gravels extending much further, possibly into Louisiana, where it is known as the Citronelle Gravel. In addition to drainage patterns that developed due to the differential erosion of geologic strata, certain groundwater or surface aquifers and stream drainages were also produced by ancient tectonic activity, as a result of the Pennsylvanian mountain building epoch (trends northeast-southwest) which produced crustal deformation (forming Grabens) due to sediment loading in the Gulf of Mexico (Dave Goss, SSCL consultant, personal communication 1990). Small fracture belts up to 200 ft wide have influenced surface and subsurface water flow in the western project area, particularly along tributary drainages to Greathouse Creek and Baker Branch. This tectonic phenomenon has made erosion a major factor in the preservation of prehistoric sites in the western project area. Indeed, calcite crystals which are visible at the surface within fracture lines in this area indicate high groundwater tables that are estimated to be 40,000+ years old (Dave Goss, personal communication 1990). These calcite crystals may be suitable for radiocarbon dating, thereby indicating the rate of peneplanation (landscape levelling) and groundwater lowering over the last several episodes of the Quaternary. The Austin Chalk provides a source of stone which was used by historic people for foundation and chimney material. However, it is highly susceptible to weathering, and heat rapidly breaks down its Structure. During the historic period, it was possible to excavate massive wells and/or cisterns in this geological formation throughout the western project area, However, dependable water in the chalk rock areas is located at 600-800 feet, below the Austin Chalk (Brooks et al. 1964:71). Today the chalk from the Austin formation and shale from the Eagle Ford provide materials for making concrete. The Taylor Marl, located within the eastern and southern portions of the project area, was relatively unconsolidated and wells dug during the historic period usually had to be lined with wood or brick to prevent collapse. Although stone was not available for building, the Taylor Marl was suitable for brick manufacturing, and plants were developed at Palmer and Ferris. The distribution of Quaternary Terraces (see Figure 2-1) is of great relevance to the location and potential preservation of archaeological sites dating to the Paleo-Indian period. The mapped Quaternary Terrace units are relatively few in the SSC project area, and are limited to small areas along Red Oak Creek and around Lake Bardwell. There are more extensive Quaternary Terraces along Chambers Creek, some of 2-2

These “stranded” terraces are thought to be relicts of a pre-Holocene drainage, possibly including the Trinity River that once occupied the Chambers Creek Valley (Billy Stringer, Soil Conservation Service, personal communication 1990). Figure 2-1 illustrates how the underfit Chambers Creek has extensively cut the Eagle Ford Formation and Austin Chalk. The location of this relict drainage pattern has great relevance to our understanding of landform development in the southern SSC project area. The Quaternary Terraces which have been mapped during the geotechnic explorations for the SSC are fairly limited in their distribution. Quaternary Terrace deposits are located between the shaft penetrations F6 and E7; F8 and E9; E9 and F9, where there are Uvalde gravels present; Fl and E2; and E4 and Red Oak Creek. These terrace deposits have the potential to contain Pleistocene megafauna, but may contain evidence of human occupation only on their surfaces, since they may date more than 20,000 years. Post Pleistocene (H>locene) alluvium is also relatively limited in the SSC project area (see Figure 2- 1). The only significant areas where Holocene alluvium has accumulated are Red Oak, Grove, Waxahachie, and Onion Creeks. The areas where alluvium is located include F6 and E7; F7 and E8, with Big Onion Creek, Waxahachie Creek between E2 and F2; and Red Oak Creek between F3 and E4 and F4 and ES. Also, there is a substantial acccumulation of alluvium within the East Campus along Grove and Cottonwood Creeks. This points to the fact that relatively few areas in the study area have the potential to contain buried deposits relating to the prehistoric cultures that settled within and used Ellis County following the end of the Pleistocene. In a way this is extremely beneficial to modelling site potential and presence, since deep excavations can be cost effectively concentrated in a few areas with direct construction impacts. CLIMATE The western portion of Ellis County is classified as falling within a transitional belt between the Subtropical Humid and Subtropical Subhumid climatic regions (Collins and Bousman 1990). Eastern Ellis County (breaking about Waxahachie) falls entirely within the Subtropical Humid region. This is about the same location where the 32 inch/rainfall/year isopleth occurs. This isopleth zone falls along an area passing through Rockwall, Ellis, Navarro, and Limestone Counties. The climate in Ellis County affects agriculture in several ways, but four circumstances stand out; (1) there is irregular seasonal distribution of effective rainfall, (2) there is a fairly high rate of evapotranspiration, (3) there are frequently periods of more than 100°F temperature for several days in summer (usually in August), and (4) there are moderate winters with cold spells rarely lasting more than several days (Brooks et al. 1964:72). About 60% of the annual precipitation falls in the spring and summer. Excessive amounts of rain in the spring often delays planting, keeps the soil cold, and causes.erosion. The wind also affects water retention. In spring a strong westerly or southwesterly wind may blow in dust storms. Cold winter air masses called "northers" move into the area from the north and bring sudden drops in temperature. When this event follows a warm and moist winter, it may terminate what is known as "False Spring”, and produce severe freezing of early crops, fruit trees, and affect the growth of post oak and other species of trees (Stahle 1990). On the average, there are 275 days between the last recorded temperature of 28°F temperature in the spring and the first in the fall (Brooks et al. 1964:73), which can be called the frost-free period. This allows all general field crops to mature, and the winters are mild enough for cool-season crops (such as wheat) to grow. The winter wheat crop is often the most dependable, but if there is a dry fall, this particular crop may not make a stand sufficient enough to cover the cultivated land or provide grazing in this area. SOILS Only three major soil associations are present within the SSC project area; the Eddy-Stephen, Austin, and Houston Black-Houston Series (Figure 2-2). The Austin Chalk underlies the Eddy-Stephen and Austin Associations, composing the western project area. The Taylor Marl underlies the Houston Black-Houston association which underlies the eastern project area. As stated previously, the uplift of the Austin Chalk has produced minor surficial fracturing which has influenced groundwater movement as well as geomorphological conditions which in turn are generally unfavorable for the burial and/or preservation of archaeological sites in primary contexts. Other minor soil associations include the Burleson Clay and the Trinity-Frio. Figure 2-3 illustrates the stratigraphic positioning of the Austin and Eddy soils. This view is from the SW, typical of the area between Maypearl and Boz. The generally rolling upland soils formed on Austin Chalk are truncated by the west facing escarpment. The West Campus is located in this general environmental zone, from 640-720 ft ams, on the Eddy and Austin soils, from 1 to 8% slopes. The tunnel itself will be near the base of the Austin Chalk. Figure 2-4 illustrates the landscape from the West to the East Campus, and is fairly accurate in term of stream placement and drainage patterns. Greathouse Branch is west of the West Campus, Onion Creek is in the south-central portion of the ring, and Red Oak Creek forms the northeastern border of the ring. South Prong Creek is not shown in this generalized figure. The junction between soils formed on chalk and the Taylor Marl is approximately in the center of the ring. Overall the landscape of the ring is characterized as gently rolling uplands which were broad tallgrass prairies in their native state. The vegetation of the western portion of the project area, on chalk, graded into short to medium grasses (Billy Stringer, Soil Conservation Service, personal communication 1990). 2-4

## Page 32

Two radiocarbon dates, taken from 4 to 5 ft below surface within the drill core for the shaft penetration BE8, in the Onion Creek valley, were submitted for dating to see if a rate of valley alluviation could be calculated. A clear soil horizon was preserved in the core from 4.5 ft below surface, an abrupt boundary between light grey clay loam with many fragmented snail shells to a dark organic clay loam. This soil boundary is also present in the stream bank of Onion Creek, approximately 50 meters north of the core location. Initially it was hypothesized that this buried black soil may be the Navarro (Bruseth et al. 1987:229-247) or Copan Paleosol (Hall 1982; Collins and Bousman 1990). The lower date was recent with 107.43+0.76% organic carbon (SMU 2405), indicating the input of radioactive carbon from atomic bomb testing. The upper date was 3190480 BP (SMU 2416), indicating that older sediments have been eroded from adjacent upland soils, burying the historic landscape. This phenomenon of deeply buried recent soils, covered by older sediments has been observed elsewhere in central Texas (Britt Bousman, personal communication 1990; Mike Collins, personal communication 1990). Three soils comprise the major part of the landscape along the western project area: the Eddy, Stephens, and Austin soils. The Eddy Series soils consist of dark grayish-brown lithosols and thin gravelly clay loams on uplands, which are underlain (usually 10-20 cm) by chalk. Plant roots penetrate the upper portion of the chalk, primarily through cracks. Pastures on these soils are composed mostly of short grasses and mesquite (Brooks et al. 1964:13). Only the Eddy gravelly clay loam with 1-3 percent slopes is suitable for occasional cultivation due to its droughty nature. Small grains, sweet clover, and similar cool season crops grow best on this type of soil. The typical soil profile of an Eddy gravelly clay loam consists of an Ajp from 0-6 inches below surface, over R-Ac platy chalk from 6-30 inches, over R soft chalk from 30-70 inches (Brooks et al. 1964:69). The Stephens Series soils consist of well-drained, shallow silty clays containing chalky rock fragments which overlie bedrock, and is called the whiterock prairie. This soil is slightly thicker than the Eddy, and ranges up to 30 cm deep. These soils are shallowest when they are near Eddy soils, and deepest when they are near Austin soils (Brooks et al. 1964:23). The Stephen developed under prairie, with side-oats grama, big bluestem, little bluestem, Indian grass, and other middle to tall grasses. A typical Stephen silty clay soil profile consists of an Ay, with chalk fragments on the surface, from 0-4 inches thick; an A12 with many chalk fragments from 4-14 inches; and R-Ac from 14-24 inches, and R from 24-40 inches (Brooks et al. 1964:68). The Austin Series Soils are well drained, moderately deep, friable silty clays on the prairie, and are well dissected by small drainages. The surface soil ranges from 15-20 cm and contains weathered chalk fragments. This soil is deepest in small valleys and concave footslopes, reaching up to 1 meter in depth. These soils also have developed under middle to tall grasses. A typical Austin silty clay profile consists of an Ajp from 0-6 inches, an Ay2 from 6-16 inches, an Ay3 from 16-22 inches, AC from 22-34 inches, and C from 34-42 inches (Brooks et al. 1964:59). 2-5 4 ace Co C= | SS Ge C3 Vee et 5

## Page 33

——4 E = The Burleson Clay Terrace (Figure 2-1, Number 1) is a landform that was produced during the Quaternary by broad scale downcutting. It is located along the north side of Chambers Creek, north of Waxahachie Creek, and north of Red Oak Creek. On this landform the Houston-Black and Burleson clays are the dominant soil types. The Burleson Series are very dark gray, deep heavy clay soils with a dense subsoil that slowly takes water. The surface layer is 10-15 cm in depth and is susceptible to cracking. The parent material is weathered old alluvium, rich in lime. When these soils are located on stream terraces, the parent material consists of this lime-rich alluvium with seams of water-bearing stratified sands and gravels (Brooks et al. 1964:11). These particular soils are deepest when they cover large areas, where the sand and gravel deposits are buried up to 15 ft deep in the ancient alluvium. A typical Burleson clay profile consists of an Aip from 0-4 inches; an A42 from 4-12 inches, compacted by tillage; an A13 from 12-26 inches; and AC from 26-40 inches; and C from 40-60 inches (Brooks et al. 1964:40). Two soils, the Houston and Houston Black comprise the majority of the landscape for the SSC project area east of Waxahachie generally from 400-500 ft amsl. The Houston Series are dark olive-gray, deep heavy clay soils, and are generally eroded (Brooks et al. 1964:16). These soils are well drained, rich in lime, and are agriculturally productive. Prior to historic settlement the native vegetation on these soils consisted of middle to tall grasses. The parent material underlying the Houston Series is either an olive clay or clayey marl (Taylor), however in the transitional zone between the Austin Series to the west, the Houston soils may overlie Austin Chalk. A typical Houston clay profile consists of an Ayp from 0-3 inches, with 3-15 cm pebbles on the surface; an Ay2 with few small (20 mm) pebbles from 3-9 inches; an AC from 9-34 inches, with few small (3-4 mm) pebbles; and C from 34-46 inches (Brooks et al. 1964:63). An important point to note is that these rounded quartzite pebbles and cobbles (Uvalde Gravels) are within the plow zone, while only smaller pebbles (2-4 mm) are below the plow zone in undisturbed soil. It is for this reason that the Uvalde gravels are termed "veneer", due to the fact that they are surface features that resulted from ancient (Pleistocene, Tertiary, or older) geological processes. The Houston Black Series are nearly level, gently sloping deep clays on uplands and terraces. These particular soils are moderately well drained, rich in lime, and are the most agriculturally productive in the region. As with the Houston soils, the native vegetation of the Houston Black consisted middle to tall grasses prior to historic settlement. In places, pebbles and cobbles are sometimes present in these soils. The parent material is weathered chalk, calcareous clay, clayey shale, or old alluvium. The A horizon is 15-30 cm thick and is intensely succeptable to cracking. This soil is intensively cultivated, and is quite mobile, or self-mulching. A typical Houston Black Clay (on the Ellis County Farm, 41EL58) consists of an A1p from 0-6 inches, with few rounded pebbles (3-15 cm in diameter) on the surface; an Aq2 from 6-16 inches, an A13 from 16-40 inches; an AC from 40-70 inches; and C from 70-80 inches (Brooks et al. 1964:63- 64). 2-6

## Page 34

One last soil Series, the Trinity Clay is found in the floodplains of Big Onion, Waxahachie, Grove, and Red Oak Creeks. Although not extensive, this soil type is very important for archaeological investigations, since sites can be deeply buried in the floodplains which are associated with this soil. Although sites may be harder to find in these areas, the processes which formed the Trinity Clay soils could have preserved and separated various cultural occupations through time. As a result all stream cuts in this soil type were closely examined during field survey. The Trinity Series are deep heavy clays, rich in lime, on floodplains. The surface layer is over 50 cm deep, and has over a 1 m thick subsoil. The parent material is calcareous alluvium washed from the blackland prairie. Beds of stratified sand and gravel lie beneath the parent material in many places. The typical Trinity clay soil profile for Ellis County was described in the Trinity River floodplain, and may not be quite as representative of the few areas that it is located within the SSC project (i.e., Red Oak, Grove, Waxahachie, and Big Onion Creeks). PRESETTLEMENT VEGETATION The SSC project area is situated along the westem edge of the East Texas zone of primary productivity in terms of the biomass (plants and animals) production (Rosenzweeg 1968; Owen and Schmidly 1986; cf. Collins and Bousman 1990:25). This factor is extremely significant to the understanding of long term climatic change. This zone is felt to have shifted frequently in conditioned response to climatic shifts. Therefore, such “edge” areas have the potential to yield significant information for environmental reconstruction through proxy records such as pollen in alluvial and aquatic deposits, geomorphological and soils analysis, dendrochronology, and other paleoenvironmental techniques of climatic reconstruction (Figure 2-5). - Historic reconstruction of plant communities that were recorded through General Land Office Surveyors’ notes taken during the distribution of Public Domain in Texas, Oklahoma, and southern United States have provided data on limited samples of native vegetation communities (Jordan 1973; Delcourt and Delcourt 1974; 1977; Delcourt 1976; Schafale and Harcombe 1983; Jumey 1987, 1988a; Weniger 1984). These notes provided fairly consistent and dependable data on arboreal species, and in some cases prairie/forest boundaries (Bourdo 1956; Delcourt and Delcourt 1974, 1977; Delcourt 1976; Schafale and Harcombe 1983; Jurney 1987, 1988a; Weniger 1984). Historic reconstructions are most successful when compared to modern community studies based on appropriate sampling and mapping techniques, and when cross-checked in the field (Schafale and Harcombe 1983), if native arboreal ecosystems remain. In Ellis County, all native arboreal ecosystems as well as prairies have been totally altered or eradicated. These types of studies using archival information, although biased by the political economy of land entrepreneurship and the lag factor + from initial frontier mapping to subsequent infilling of the settled landscape, provide a firm baseline from 2-7 fos

Based on the General Land Office surveyor's notes of Ellis County, the SSC project area encompasses three major presettlement ecosystems: pure upland prairies, brushy prairies adjacent to stream valleys (uplands and slopes), and riparian forests (floodplains) along streams such as Red Oak, Grove, Chambers, and Waxahachie Creek. Since the beginning of the historic period, these original plant communities and physiographic settings have been altered by numerous human activities. For example, fire suppression allowed trees and shrubs to encroach upon the prairie, In the eastern project, gullying was noted along prairie/slope margins of Red Oak Creek during the initial GLO surveys. In heavily forested areas, native trees were cut for housing, fences and fuel. Settlers also planted seeds and saplings from "home" thereby altering the general landscape by introducing exotic species. Bois d'arc is one transplanted species which was Not present.in the native ecosystem west of the Trinity River (Jurney 1988a). Due to its importance in fence building, building foundation piers, wagon spokes, etc., settlers planted this tree as a first priority, and today is has a dominant status in some areas. The largest of the native plant communities was the upland prairie. While this area was dominated by grasses and forbs, a large variety of trees were also present along the fringes of stream valleys and lowlying upland areas. Elm and mesquite were the most common trees followed by hackberry and cottonwood. Minor tree species along the brushy fringes of the upland prairies included several types of oaks, red cedar, and fruit and nut bearing trees such as haw, gum bumelia, and persimmon. The large number of forage tree species present in this area would have been conducive to high faunal populations. The riparian forest ecosystem would have been found along the streams of Ellis County. These consisted of hardwood forests and occasional wetland prairies. Elm was the dominant tree followed by hackberry, Spanish oak, and pecan. Oak species, fruit and nut producers such as red haw, walnut, and mulberry were also present. Much of the understory would have been water-loving species such as cattails and bulrushes. Along Waxahachie Creek and the eastern SSC project area around Ennis a higher density of mesquite was recorded in the surveyor's notes. Other trees were elm, hackberry, pecan, and ash. Along the wetland prairie cottonwood was the dominant tree followed by elm, hackberry, and mesquite. Numerous fruit and nut producers such as red haw, mulberry, and walnut were also present. This understory would again have contained water-loving species. Overall the presettlement vegetation of the SSC project area was predominantly prairie along with several riparian forests and wetland prairie communities included. The area would have been very rich in forage species which would have been able to support a large number of faunal species. This in tum would have made excellent hunting for local human populations as well. Hardwood resources were extremely important for historic settlers. Although some oak species were present in riparian forests and along the slopes of major drainages, extensive oak forests not present within the SSC project area. Nevertheless a major oak forest was located around the Tellico area, east of Ennis. 2-8 = a= = ] fl : } =

J = Cc) This forest was lumbered prior to and after the Civil War. A mortise and tenon frame church in Tellico has been tree-ring dated to 1867. This church was built from locally sawn post oak lumber. A second expanse of post oak forest was present near Italy, but was not as extensive as the one at Tellico. Both of these areas, along with the Red Oak, Greathouse, and Chambers Creek valleys offered sufficient forest resources (primarily oak) to attract early settlers. It is also probable that the early settlers within the prairie areas of the SSC project imported some hardwood lumber as well as pine lumber from east Texas. Post oak lumber was essential for horizontal log houses. Small oaks could be hewn and used in timber framing, but siding was needed to complete the structure. Larger oaks could be sawn, but due to their hardness and tendency to warp this species was not suitable for siding in most cases. Baldcypress and pine siding and framing materials had to be imported overland from East Texas by wagon. After the introduction of the railroad, cost for imported lumber fell, and a wave of construction began. Elms, pecans, and hackberries were second choices for construction and were generally not used in houses. Firewood was a commodity that insured the disappearance of native forests, which were replaced by managed wood lots. PRESETTLEMENT FAUNA The SSC project area, as noted above is dominated by prairie ecosystems, and was probably similar in the associated environments throughout the Holocene. Presumably, the most important animals of the tallgrass prairies were bison, cottontail and jack rabbit, and antelope; with bear, raccoon, white-tailed deer, and wild turkey along the wooded fringes of streams and around springs. On the basis of faunal data from archaeological sites (Dillehay 1974 has suggested two periods when bison were essentially absent from the southern High Plains; 6000/5000 B.C. to 2500 B.C. and A.D. 500 to A.D. 1200/1300. Lynott (1979) reviewed the extant evidence (which is relatively poor for earlier periods) for North Central Texas and concluded that they were never very numerous in the tallgrass prairies, but that after ca. A.D. 1200 their numbers did increase. Apparently, white-tailed deer were always the most dependable game animal within the SSC project area. MODERN FLORA The SSC project area has been radically altered by the historic settlement of the region. There are no known areas of native prairie left in Ellis County. The Katchina Prairie near Ennis, and a small area within the West Campus have been re-established as prairies, but the original plant communities probably do not reflect the undisturbed ecosystem. Also, the supression of prairie fires and the placement of barbed wire fences across the prairies have fostered a grid of hackberry and elm trees along the fencelines. Today elms and hackberries comprise a significant portion of the arboreal vegetation in wooded areas that were once prairies.

## Page 38

Another tree species which has been introduced onto the prairies is bois d'arc. This tree was planted by settlers to serve as hedges and as sources of fence posts, wagon spokes and foundation material. Mesquite is also thought to be an introduced species, resulting from the early herding of cattle. However, the GLO records indicate that large mesquite were relatively numerous in the native prairies during the 1830s-1840s. MODERN FAUNA Today, the animals of Ellis County also reflect the extreme disturbances wrought on the native ecosystems. Bison and bear have been extirpated. White-tailed deer were also extirpated during the late nineteenth century, and have been reintroduced since World War II. Raccoon, oppossum, armadillo, and coyote have been the most successful species to adapt to the modern landscape. Wild turkey were observed during our surveys of the wooded thickets around upper South Prong Creek. In summary, the landscape of today is only slightly similar to that of the presettlement period. For instance, the most common game animal in the Chambers Creek forest is reported to be feral hog. The native plants and animals have been altered in terms of their lifeways and habitats. Therefore any archaeological sites which may contain fauna or floral remains from the early historic or prehistoric periods could potentially yield significant information on the native ecosystems. 2-10 r~ —s —- ( hen eS : = =< a : . } — =o : Ue :

Jumey In the State of Texas, the diversity of the archaeological record and the environment is so great that a narrower focus must be given to the location of the Superconducting Super Collider Project, which is located in Ellis County, Texas. Through time Ellis County has been located within different cultural areas which have been arbitrarily defined on the basis of archaeological remains and physiographic provinces. As Bruseth et al. (1987) note, these arbitrary divisions are not so clearly defined in the archaeological record. During the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods, cultural affiliations were with the North Central Plains (Figure 3-1, from Brown et al. 1982). During the Early historic contact era, Ellis County was within the Northeast Culture area (Figure 3-2), but was adjacent to the Northeast culture area and the Prehorse Plains culture area. During the Late Contact era, when indigenous historic Indian groups are somewhat identifiable, Ellis County was well within the Caddoan Language area (Figure 3-3), but was adjacent to the Shosonean Language area. Ellis County is located on the southern border of what has been defined as North Central Texas, therefore adjacent cultural areas exerted considerable influence on the prehistory of the project area. The archaeological evidence in North Central Texas lacks major syntheses, but several recent publications have brought much of the archaeological data together. Lynott's Regional Model for Archaeological Research in Northcentral Texas (1977) and Prikryl's Synthesis of the Prehistory of the m Fork of the Trinity River (1987) are the best examples of this level of research. However, no interregional Interpretations of North Texas have been produced since Krieger's Culture Complexes and ef in Northern Texas (1946). Therefore the taxonomic nomenclature and cultural historical sequences which have been developed mix several types of theoretical constructs. For the purposes of this overview, the term focus is employed as an heuristic device for describing cultural afffiliation or technological levels of adaptation. The terms phase and aspect are used to describe technological or stylistic manifestations of artifact assemblages which have specific geographic limits or boundaries. The terms focus or focii refer to more spatially and temporally limited defined assemblages of artifacts, A horizon is a set of technological or stylistic attributes which has broad geographic distributions. Ellis County is located geographically on the marginal area of three broad archaeological areas; Edwards Plateau/Central Texas, Trinity, and LaHarpe/Gibson/Fulton (Sorrow 1966:1). Sorrow (1966:1) states that the Edwards Plateau Aspect and the Central Texas Aspect, which form a continuu m the Archaic Period to the Late Ceramic Period, were located to the west. i a. a Whatever the case, these very first Americans are not presently recognizable in the SSC project area, specifically. nor for that matter in this portion of Texas, generally (cf. Story 1990:176). During the Late Pleistocene and with the onset of the Holocene Epoch, the first human inhabitants are believed to have entered this region. These first inhabitants were the Paleo-Indians. This stage of human development is "most often characterized in terms of its manifestations on the Great Plains..." (Brown et al. 1987:5-4). The majority of the Paleo-Indian sites are found as surface exposures in mixed association with later occupations (Lynott 1981b:100). The Paleo-Indian Period is initially identified with a low population density which slowly increased through time. "Unfortunately, one of the most striking characteristics of the Paleo-Indian Stage in tne SSC project area) s the extreme rarity of sites exhibiting Paleo-Indian cultural materials" (Richner and Bagot 1978:51). "The single most distinctive trait of the Paleo-Indian Cultures is the crafting of stone projectile points which weré often exceptionally well made. Many of these points share common attributes which show some temporal and spatial variability and can be typed accordingly (Story 1990:177). These stone tool types associated with the Paleo-Indian sites are basally ground lanceolate points and were used either as projectiles or as knives. The lithic raw material used in tool manufacturing was of high quality and often was exotic (non-local) to this region. The Paleo-Indian Period can be divided into three horizons based mainly on the tool types that were used. These three horizons are the Clovis, Folsom, and the Plano. The Clovis, Folsom, and Plano horizons are considered to be techno-cultural horizons due to their wide geographic distribution of affiliated point types which are assumed to have been used over a relatively short period of time (Stanford 1983; Adovasio et al. 1983; Owen 1984). The geographic distributions of many of the Paleo-Indian point types span the North American continent and can be extended by basic technomorphological comparisons into South America (Brown et al. 1987:5-4). Clovis Horizon The Clovis Horizon consists mainly of lanceolate points with short basal flutes and prismatic blades, laurel-leaf shaped bifaces, end scrapers, and smooth bone or ivory cylindrical shafts (Lynott 1981b:101). Exotic lithic materials were utilized for the construction of points and scrapers as opposed to locally available quartzites and cherts. Clovis points (Figure 3-5) are rare but they are widely distributed and are in all areas of the Gulf Coastal Plain except in east-central Texas, which could represent gaps in the data rather than any real pattern in the Clovis settlement or economic system (Story 1990:178). Most of the Clovis sites are identified with a single point find and are located on upland, non-aggrading landforms, erosional cuts, or gravel quarries. It has been stated that the Clovis Horizon people were highly mobile and traveled considerable distances in small bands (Lynott 1981b:101). This implies that there was an overall low population density. However, with the lack of many good archacological sites, a series of unanswered questions still arise concerning more detailed aspects of the Clovis lifeways. (Meltzer 1987:27-28). Unfortunately, the answers to these questions are based more on speculation than on substantive information, and there is an important scientific need to fill this gap. The truth is that the archaeological record of the Clovis Horizon, as with the rest of the Paleo-Indian Period, consists of mostly isolated fluted points rather than stratified or buried site contexts. However there are a few archaeological sites where Clovis points are found in contexts with mammoth kill and/or scavenged sites. Information on other aspects of the Clovis Horizon lifeways is very sketchy, and we get information based on hypotheses of archaeologists who feel for example that since the Clovis economy was "oriented toward the exploitation of large grazing animals like the mammoth, the more forested conditions in the eastern parts of northern Texas probably served to mit mammoth grazing and consequently human activity during this time period" (Lynott 1981b:101). . One of the few exceptions to the general lack of good Paleo-Indian sites is the recent discovery and excavation of a Clovis camp, bison kill site, and associated spring and pond by Reid Ferring of the University of North Texas. A report on this excavation, performed for the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers is in preparation. Briefly, Ferring (personal communication 1989) interprets this site as two brief encampments following a kill, with tool kit refurbishing, tool use, and tool discard activities present at the site. A Clovis Point, endscrapers, and heavily used blades were recovered the majority of which were made of Alibates chert from the Amarillo area and red quartzite from New Mexico. Over 10,000 artifacts were recovered. Since the site was deeply and rapidly buried, there is excellent preservation of cultural and paleoenvironmental information. Another find pertinent to the SSC project area is the discovery of a cache of Clovis blades in the Richland Creek Reservoir (Number 12 in Figure 3-6) by two avocational archaeologists Keven Davis (Waxahachie) and William Young (Corsicana). These blades have been donated to the State of Texas and are currently being analyzed by Bob Mallouf (State Archaeologist) and Mike Collins (TARL). Briefly, most of these blades were made from Edwards Plateau chert, and all had been heavily used and worn. Also, three blades made from materials of non-local origin were present. All of the blades were apparently used and then left in a cut-off channel of Chambers Creek and were less than 50 cm below the present ground surface (Keven Davis and William Young, personal communications 1989). The vegetation during the Clovis Horizon in this region was becoming more open due to decreased rainfall and warmer temperatures following the Pleistocene. There were forested conditions which probably persisted longer in the eastern areas, especially in the Blackland Prairie (Lynott 1981b:101). The distribution of the Clovis points suggests that all major environmental zones were exploited at one time or another (Story 1990:178). The sites that one could expect to find associated with the Clovis Horizon would most likely consist of an isolated fluted point. Such a site on the rarest occasion, could be associated with a mammoth or bison 3-4

Almost all of the Clovis points have been found in upland settings or along small tributary streams, probably because these are the areas where the sites are most likely to be preserved or discovered (Story 1990:182). "Finds in the main river valleys are less frequent probably because either the sites are deeply buried or they have been removed by erosion" (Story 1990:182). In the case of the Clovis cache find along Chambers Creek, this was an isolated activity area located in what was a landform with a low density of prehistoric site occurrences. To find sites (87% chance) of this size (ca. five meters in diameter with 2 artifacts/m2) it would be necessary to excavate 1 x 1 m shovel tests at 4.3 m intervals on an hexagonal grid over the entire landscape to be surveyed (Kintigh 1988:706). Such an intensive investment of labor is not feasible at the reconnaissance level, since costs would be exorbitant. According to a 1987 article by David J. Meltzer, a literature and questionnaire survey of members of the Texas Archaeological Society and others was done on the Clovis fluted points found in Texas. This survey, among other things, shows that there have been two Clovis points found in Ellis County (41EL5) and 12 Clovis points found in the North Central region of Texas (Meltzer 1987:32 and 42). The Ellis County points were found by C.K. Chandler of San Antonio, who has agreed to allow reanalysis of his entire collection from sites along Mustang and Waxahachie Creek in the vicinity of the East Campus. The two Clovis Point finds are located adjacent to the upland Uvalde gravel deposits fringing Lake Bardwell (Number 6 in Figure 3-6). However, the Paleo-Indians were not apparently using the Ogallala quartzites, since so few culturally diagnostic artifacts of this period have been found (C. K. Chandler, personal communication 1990). Thus, a major research objective for the SSC is why did Paleo-Indians leave broken points on sites adjacent to these veneer gravels? Did they make other types of tools there? There is a demonstrated presence of Paleo-Indians in the Superconducting Super Collider project area, and site discovery is a distinct possibility. Folsom Horizon Following Clovis is the Folsom Horizon. Folsom may have developed out of Clovis with possibly a gap of several hundred years (or several generations) and an apparent absence of an intermediary point style (Story 1990:189). There is a complete shift from the hunting of mammoths as the people from the Clovis Horizon did, to the hunting of bison (Bison antiquis and Bison bison). This shift in hunting preference began around 9200 B.C., which corresponds to a drying climate resulting in more open grassland environments namely short grass prairies. Short grass prairie ecosystems are believed to be preferred by the bison (Lynott 1981b:101). Folsom sites tend to be more restricted in distribution than Clovis sites (Story 1990:189). Overall the Folsom Horizon is believed to have lasted until 8,500 B.C. Thus far, there has been no evidence found to indicate that the social organization had changed significantly from the Clovis to the Folsom horizon. "Small bands of aggregated families with high degrees of mobility continued to move over vast areas, and population density in the region was still quite low" (Lynott 1981b:101). The level of use of the SSC project area and the Trinity River Valley by Folsom peoples seems to be very low. This is based on the relatively few artifacts found in the area which in part 3-5

## Page 48

Tool assemblages found at Folsom sites include the channel-fluted projectile points and nonfluted projectile points. The fluted Folsom points are very thin and have long distinctive flutes on both sides which extend from. the base to almost the tip of the point. There is also a distinctive nipple, which is sometime found located in the middle of the base. This nipple represents the platform for flute removal (Turner and Hester 1985:99), The raw material utilized for Folsom projectile points is characteristically of high quality. Other artifacts recovered at major sites include bifaces in various stages of reduction, scrapers, choppers, perforators, hammerstones, abraders, bone needles and possibly bone gaming pieces (Story 1990:189). The major Folsom sites are located in the Rocky Mountains and the western part of the Great Plains. In Texas, the Lubbock Lake site has yielded substantial evidence of Folsom occupation. Evidence of Folsom sites consist of snly points and some bifaces in the North Central Texas region. At present there are ten sites known to have produced Folsom points in this region, and of those ten sites, all but one are from surface or culturally mixed deposits (Story 1990:189). Plano Horizon The Plano Horizon is next in the cultural continuum and represents the period of time when Paleo- Indians were beginning to adapt to post-Pleistocene environmental and climatic conditions. Long, parallel flaked, nonfluted and sometimes stemmed lanceolate points, such as the Plainview, Eden, Meserve, Angostura, Scottsbluff, Dalton, and San Patrice types are characteristic of this horizon. Unlike the Clovis and Folsom Horizons, the Plano Horizon encompasses a more diverse set of cultural components, which are characterized by a proliferation of projectile point types. Dalton and San Patrice are included with the Paleo-Indian cultural groups because Dalton, San Patrice, and Plainview represent three different geographic areas but overlap temporally (Prikryl 1987:150), and are similar to other cultural groups classified along with the Plano Horizon. The Plano Horizon is believed to be the "final big game hunting occupation of the southern plains" (Lynott 1981b:101). The Plano Horizon existed from about 8,500 to 6,000 B.C. There is some controversy over the inclusion of the Plano Horizon with the Paleo-Indian Period or if it should be associated more with the Early Archaic Period (Suhm and Jelks 1962:213-214; Coe 1964:64-68; Gardner 1974:18; Perttula 1987:3-11; Prikryl 1987:145). This epistemological controversy is due primarily to the marked increase in population which is based partly on the greater number of projectile points found in relation to the previous Clovis and Folsom Horizons and partly on the increased expansion of post- . glacial grasslands. Also, it is difficult to arbitrarily define changes in what may have been a gradual techno cultural transition. There is speculation that a slight reduction in group mobility occurred in North Central Texas which is possibly due to an increase in population density along with a concomittant increase in the tall-grass prairie 3-6 =

Lynott (1981b:101-103) also speculates that the family was still the basic economic unit and the largest social unit formed, but in northern Texas, most of the Plano Horizon sites occur in mixed contexts (non-aggrading soils) with later Archaic sites so it is very difficult to establish any population or social structure parameters. Scottsbluff Scottsbluff points are distinguished by their small shoulders, well defined stem that is “paralleled - sided to slightly expanded with square comers, and a generally straight base with more or less parallel - sided pressure flake scars that terminate smoothly at or near the midline of the points that are the result of a carefully staged sequence of production" (Story 1990:205). There is a difference, however, between the Scottsbluff points fo’ ad in Texas and the points found on the Plains. The Plains are where the Scottsbluff point was originally identified and defined. In Texas the points tend to be “wider, both blade and stem breath, than those on the Plains", the stem bases sometimes have a shallow V-shaped notch while those on the Plains do not or just rarely do, the reduction sequence appears not to have as many stages as those of the Plains, and the "points found on eastern sites are resharpened more often than the western ones, sometimes down to a mere nubbin" (Story 1990:209). Scottsbluff points of the woodland region tend to be constructed of non-local lithic materials, particularly central Texas cherts. It is believed that the people associated with Scottsbluff points preferred oak savannahs and forests over prairie country (Story 1990:209). This could explain why there have been few Scottsbluff points found in the project area with good context. A single apparent (though huge) Scottsbluff was collected by Charles Barton (Maypearl), five miles from the project area in a gravel/sand quarry of a Quatemary terrace in the Chambers Creek Valley (see Figure 2-1). This is an anomalous find, since it is whole and has no use or resharpening evidence, in a region where, as stated above, Scottsbluff points are usually at the end of their lifecyle or use trajectory. Scottsbluff points have also been found in the Sulphur River Drainage of northeastern Texas and the upper and middle reaches of the Trinity River (Story 1990:209). The transitional period between the Paleo-Indian Period and the Early Archaic Period technologies is represented by the Dalton and San Patrice point types. The Dalton and San Patrice point types are distinctive basally-ground lanceolate points which are usually side notched and often have characteristic tangs (Lynott 1981b:104; Prikryl 1987:157). There is some disagreement as to the classification of the Dalton and San Patrice points with either the Early Archaic Period or the Paleo-Indian Period. Story et al. (1990) and most others include Dalton and San Patrice with the Paleo-Indian Period, but these point types and associated lifeways appear to be closely related to the Early Archaic Period as well. Dalton The Dalton point is a sometimes fluted lanceolate style projectile point/knife, which probably developed out of an eastern form of Clovis (Story 1990:190). ## Page 50

After they were no longer serviceable as a cutting tool, or when broken, Dalton points sometimes were recycled into perforators, scrapers and burins” (Story 1990:190). Dalton tool kits contained "end and side scrapers, gravers on flakes, gravers on end scrapers, true blades, unifacial modifications to blades and blade like flakes, bipolar cores and wedges" (Story 1990:190). In addition to the point type, the Dalton people invented a bifacially chipped stone adze, possibly used in woodworking. Dalton points are fairly numerous in the SSC project area and surrounding counties of North Central Texas and have been found in Ellis County. The sheer number of points suggests that there was a more intensive use of the area than either Clovis or Folsom. During this time period, we notice hints of higher population densities, a reduction of mobility, and an emergence of territories (Story 1990:196). The greatest concentration of Dalton materials is in Northeast Texas and adjacent parts of Oklahoma and Arkansas. Although present in Ellis County, the project area is still a marginal zone for Dalton occupation. San Patrice The San Patrice, like the Dalton point, may have developed out of the Clovis or some other fluted complex (Story 1990:197). There are definite similarities between the San Patrice and the Dalton styles, nevertheless, the San Patrice points differ from the Dalton in several ways. First, San Patrice points are more often basally fluted with single and multiple flakes. Sometimes they are obliquely side notched, and are usually made of local raw materials, including petrified wood and small chert pebbles, San Patrice points are infrequently recycled into other tools. And lastly, the blade portions of the points are wide relative to their length and the edges are rarely saw-toothed or steeply beveled (Story 1990:202). In addition to the San Patrice points, other distinctive tools include the Albany scraper (possibly a knife) and a number of nondiagnostic unifacial tools, including side and end scrapers, retouched blades, burins, and gravers (Story 1990:202). There have been San Patrice point types found within Ellis County, as has been shown by our current examination of the collections of avocational archaeologists. The temporal placement of San Patrice is problematical because no San Patrice points have been found in tight stratigraphic context, and only one has been radiocarbon dated in North Central Texas (Story 1990:202). At that site, points similar to the San Patrice were found in strata “above Folsom and below a late style Dalton point, a Dalton adze and Plainview points" (Story 1990:202). The classic San Patrice points are found to the south of the Dalton points and mainly in the heavily wooded areas (Story 1990:202). This differs from the Dalton in that Dalton appears to have exploited a wider range of environments including the woodland edge. There is also a difference in raw material utilized for the construction’of Dalton and San Pairice points. 3-8

## Page 51

cP i eH la a El SUMMARY In general, all of the Paleo-Indian people apparently led highly mobile hunting and gathering lifeways. These earliest people exploited broad regions to gather plants and to hunt both migratory and resident animal populations. There are sites with evidence displaying that the early Paleo-Indians were big game hunters. Clovis sites for example have been found in association with mammoth kills, Folsom and Plano are associated with the hunting of bison (Bison antiquis). Recently, Clovis sites have also been associated with bison kills (Reid Ferring, personal communication 1989). Early reports concerning the Paleo-Indians stated that the subsistence was based heavily on big game hunting. In most areas of North America and specifically North Central Texas, this evidence is lacking, instead a generalized hunting and gathering lifeway is more likely. As mehtioned above, most of the knowledge of the Paleo-Indian culture is from surface finds, although professional excavations have occurred at some sites. Paleo-Indian Period sites are noted on both the main stream valleys and minor tributaries. Generally, these sites are exposed in the "second terrace deposits of the Trinity River and its major tributaries" (Skinner and Connors 1979:9). This evidence indicates a highly mobile existence with scattered campsites. The geographic diversity of point types and stone raw materials suggest unbounded territories. For example, the closest source for the Clovis cache in the lower Chambers Creek Valley is the Edwards Plateau near Georgetown, some 90 miles distant (Mike Collins, personal communication 1989). Paleo-Indian points have been recovered from Chambers Creek, Lake Bardwell, and Navarro Mills Reservoir (see Figure 3-6), as well as other areas within Ellis County, again indicating a Paleo-Indian presence in the Superconducting Super Collider project area. Caches of tools and raw materials such as the blades found by Keven Davis and William Young in Chambers Creek Reservoir are also known, Two areas of high potential for finding Paleo-Indian sites are in the area of the Supercollider's E7 and E8 penetration shafts. No survey work for the project has been done at E7 due to access being denied to the survey crew by the present owner of the land. Radiocarbon (humate) samples from the drill core at BE8a (see Appendix A) indicate that modern soils are buried 5 feet below the present ground surface. Paleo-Indian deposits could be much deeper. But again, Paleo-Indian material has been recovered in this area and sites have previously been identified and recorded, so further research should include geomorphological modeling and deep excavation with augers and machines. EARLY ARCHAIC PERIOD (6,000 - 4,000 B.C.) The Early Archaic Period marks the end to the Paleo-Indian Period when people began to adapt to a fully modern environment. There do appear to have been major climatic fluctuations in this period and a variety of projectile point types and artifact assemblages appear. There appears to have been a variety of 3-9

The term :"Archaic” has been used to designate cultural developmental sequences; a segment of a culture-historical sequences in a specific geographic area; and simply as a designation of a time period (Story 1990:211). Following Story et al. 1990, the term is used in this study to designate peoples who were hunters and gatherers or foragers beginning ca. 7000/6000 B.C. and possibly lasting among some peoples in North Central Texas until the Late Prehistoric Period. In North Central Texas, the Early Archaic Period is a very problematic time period due to the lack of well documented in situ sites. The best data for the region comes from Central and Southwest Texas. During the Early Archaic Period, there appears to be a lack of regionialization but there is a broad cultural pattern. Thus far there have been few sites located or investigated in North Central Texas which have discrete Early Archaic components, although Prikryl (1987:160) identified 57 diagnostics of this period from 22 sites in the upper Trinity River basin. The aggregation of Zarly Archaic Period peoples was confined to small groups of nomadic seasonal hunters, using geographical rounds which exploited both migratory and resident animals. Their hunting camp sites were briefly occupied. There is, however, a debate which remains unanswered, over whether the population size was increasing or decreasing during this time period. The small number of possible Early Archaic sites identified indicates that the population density was still low. "Maximum social groups were probably loosely structured bands that often changed size and composition, mostly in response to fluctuations in food resources" (Story 1981:144). Again this interpretation points to the strong influence of environment on human behavior. At this juncture, a discussion of anthropologically and archaeologically derived models of territorial ranges is merited. This character of cultural geography prompted the development of catchment analysis (Vita-Finzi and Higgs 1970) and the pattern of land use based on residential locations (Lee 1969) and is beneficial to the understanding of Archaic lifeways. Economic zonation and logistical radius models have been employed to define mobility patterning among hunting and gathering societies (Binford 1982:5-31). These models have been refined, employing ethnological studies of Australian individual and group territorial organization (Peterson and Long 1986) which indicates a complex organization beginning with the territory of an individual, encompassed by a broader annual range, encompassed by lifetime range of an individual. A band encompassed an aggregation of several annual and lifetime ranges of individuals, and together there is a group territory separated by "dead ground", from other bands but several bands may be encompassed by the individual group range. Beyond this range of the individual group, there is the binding force of reciprocity and gifts are exchanged beyond the band's annual range. The binding force for this zone of reciprocity is ultimately language, and the distribution of stylistic variables in material culture may reflect the actual language area (Sampson 1988:13-28). ; Early Archaic Period chipped stone tools tend to be less carefully fashioned and less often made of ‘exotic raw materials than during the Paleo-Indian period (Story 1990:213). The tool assemblages tend to be "more functionally varied but more cheaply produced, in terms of manufacture time and raw material 3-10 Say

The Early Archaic Period for Central Texas has been divided into four phases, the Circleville, San Geronimo, Jarrell and Oakalla (Prewitt 1981:73). The early part of this period, the Circleville Phase is characterized by low population density with a subsistence based on hunting and gathering. Gathering was apparently stressed over hunting and was preformed over large geographic areas in the range of the group. This trend continues through the San Geronimo and Jarrell Phases but during the Oakalla Phase this changes and we fin” the appearance of rock middens, less diversity in projectile point forms (Prewitt 198 1:73), and an apparent reduction in group range. Overall, there appears to be a cultural continuation from the Paleo-Indian Period to the Early Archaic Period which can be shown by the finely flaked lanceolate form and basal grinding present on many Early Archaic point types. Basal and lower edge grinding of Early Archaic points seem to have been a common trait in North America and North Central Texas (Suhm and Jelks 1962:213-214; Coe 1964:64-68; Gardner 1974:18; Adovasio et al. 1983; Lynott 1981b:104; Prikryl 1987:157). The Early Archaic Period has a "more diverse array of tools and are more varied from one locale to another" (Story 1981:143) as opposed to the Paleo-Indian Period. The projectile points are more often produced from local cherts and quartzites than in previous times. Ground stone items also appear at this time which suggests changes in processing of food resources or may suggest intensification of plant food collection (Brooks and Drass 1984). Additional evidence for the exploitation of a wide range of plant species and the increased utility of these plants can be associated with some of the new technologies developed by the Archaic people. These include the use of stone-lined hearths and baking pits and the use of milling implements. The subsistence of the Early Archaic Period is believed to be very similar to that of the Paleo-Indian Period with a few exceptions. As mentioned above, the Early Archaic Period people were nomadic seasonal hunters similar to the people of the Paleo-Indian Period except the geographic area covered in the annual range of a group or band was probably reduced. Emphasis was also placed on gathering rather than hunting (Brown et al. 1987:5-6), which may have further reduced the annual range of a group or band, and most likely there was a wide range of plant species which were probably exploited within this annual range (Story 1981:144). The environmental conditions of the previous Paleo-Indian Period consisted of a slow warming trend, but during the Early Archaic Period, there was a marked change. This climatic change was in the direction of a marked warmer and dryer period. This created new open prairie uplands and hardwood forests retreated to ‘floodplains, resulting in new adaptive requirements for the Early Archaic occupants (Lynott 1981b:103). It is not certain if "the occupants of northern Texas during the Plano Horizon adjusted their adaptive pattern or 3-11 ¢
