MIDDLE ARCHAIC PERIOD (4,000 - 2,000 B.C.) The Middle Archaic Period can be seen basically as a continuation of the Early Archaic Period, with a few exceptions listed below. The Middle Archaic Period is divided into several aspects. The LaHarpe Aspect extended in a wide band in the woodland/prairie interface region of northern Texas and portions of Oklahoma. The Trinity Aspect which contains the early Carrollton Focus (as)pne of the best (and earliest) defined Middle Archaic Period cultural assemblages (Crook and Harris 1952, 1954a, b; Crook 1952), and was centered along the Trinity River in North Central Texas. These apparent cultural traditions, along with the late Elam Focus (Crook and Harris 1952) are also centered in North Central Texas. These " :spects" and "foci" need reevaluation (Story 1990), but the original information still provides the best overall cultural- historical model for the Archaic in this region. The LaHarpe Aspect (Johnson 1962:268) particularly, spans both Middle and Late Archaic Periods, and needs completed reorganization through controlled archaeological investigations. The Carrollton Focus consist of only artifacts (Crook and Harris 1952:14) and the majority of the artifacts are projectile points. A few of these projectile points are composed of Plainview-like, nonfluted Folsom or early wel But the vast majority of the points are medium (35-50 mm) to small (under 35 mm) in size, some of which are stemmed with parallel sides and square bases, while others are shouldered and somewhat resemble the Gary contracting stem types of the Late Archaic\Period (Crook and Harris 1952:17). There were also 6thep points associated with this "focus" which include the Carrollton and Trinity dart points (McGregor 1988:31). In addition there are also spokeshaves, the Waco sinker, the chipped stone Carrollton axe, scrapers (specifically gouges), a few grinding stones, some ground stone items, drilling and boring tools made from broken projectile points, and two forms of knives (Crook and Harris 1952:14-18). Hammerstones and choppers are also fairly common at Carrollton Focus sites. The Elam Focus is a direct outgrowth of the Carrollton Focus (Crook and Harris 1952:23). The most common artifacts recovered from this focus are projectile points. These points are medium (35-50 mm) to small (under 35 mm) in size and relatively thick. Possibly the most common projectile point of this period is the Ellis dart point, followed by the Yarbrough and Elam (McGregor 1988:31). The technique used for the construction of these points are stemming and/or shouldering and barbing (Crook and Harris 1952:27). Drills were specifically made on a thick rough leaf-shaped knife, and scraping and cutting flakes were also present. Side scrapers, as in the Carrollton Focus, continue to be used; as do the quartzite hammerstones and choppers. We also find in comparison with the Carrollton Focus, the Elam Focus was characterized by a higher percentage of local quartzite in the lithic tools (McGregor 1988:31). use Creok ¢ Carns [452 cetation | | ae = & SS Ga) aes

The Clear Fork Phase, as Prewitt (1981:73) describes it, is marked by an intensification of specialized food gathering. The population density continues to rise, based on the increase in site frequency. Population density continues to rise through the Marshall Ford Phase and peaks during the Round Rock Phase (Prewitt 1981:73). The San Marcos Phase is marked by a dependency toward a more generalized gathering subsistence and less dependency on hunting. Burned rock middens are common occurrences in Central Texas associated with the Clear Fork Phase, but there have been none found in North Central Texas. LATE ARCHAIC PERIOD (2,000 - 200 B.C.) ” There is more detailed information for prehistoric lifeways, environmental adaptations and demographic patterns for the Late Archaic Period. There is evidence that the territories of cultural groups during this time began to shrink, accompanied by increasing populations (Bruseth et al. 1987:237). There are significantly more sites related to tne Late Archaic Period than previous Periods, and these stratified and single component sites have received more detailed investigations (McGregor and Bruseth 1987; Prikryl 1987: 166; Peter and McGregor 1988). There is increased evidence for the reuse of camp sites and some indication that "populations began to congregate during the fall and winter when large quantities of food were locally available" (Lynott 1981b:105). This supports the theory that the population density continued to rise while the size of the hunting territory continued to shrink. As a result, he steady regionialization process from the Middle Archaic Period proceeded through the Late Archaic Period. It appears that the band level of society was slowly becoming more elaborated, possibly tribal, during this period. Also, during this period in North Central Texas, there was a shift in the raw materials used for tool construction, from non-local chert sources to local quartzite sources. This is noted by the steady increase in the use of Ogallala Quartzite which is found in the local Uvalde Gravels. This shift to local sources may have worked in conjunction with constraints on the size of territory exploited by a group, thereby (Geimonstratingja population increase (Prikryl 1987:170). Or this may be viewed as a result of maximization of the local environment and/or a decrease in the ability to exploit more distant resources due to a population increase (Prikry! 1987:170). In addition to the projectile points, there is evidence showing the use of pecking and polishing of stone to produce ornaments and implements such as spear-throwing weights and axeheads (Story 1990:213). In Central Texas, the burned rock middens found in the Middle Archaic Period cease in the Late Archaic Period in the eastern portion but continue in the west (Prewitt 1981:73). A portion of the Late Archaic Period is the continuation of the LaHarpe Aspect. The LaHarpe Aspect shows strong cultural ties with areas to the north and east (Prikryl 1987:166) and is associated with contracting based dart points, the most typical being the Gary point (Johnson 1962:268-280). Prewitt (1981:73) views the Late Archaic Period in Central Texas as the Uvalde, Twin Sisters, and Driftwood Phases. With this Prewitt (1981:73-74) goes on to state that there was a slight decrease in the importance of hunting and a tendency toward a more generalized gathering subsistence base. This is continued through the Uvalde Phase, and during the Twin Sisters Phase, the subsistence base is heavily oriented toward gathering. Hunting importance is lowered. This is based on the low ratio of projectile points to other tools (Prewitt 1981:74). This pattern continued through the Driftwood Phase. Even though the importance of hunting is reduced, subsistence patterns for the Late Archaic Period in North Central Texas continued to be based on the hunting of bison and also antelope (Lynott 1981b; Prikry! 1987). This bsistence strategy also included the occasional exploitation of riverine faunal and floral resources. "Prairie and cross timbers subsistence was directed toward intensive exploitation of local bottomland resources" (Lynott 1981b:104). There is evidence elsewhere in North America for the development of horticulture during this period (Martin and Bruseth 1988:33) and the northern Texas region inhabitants may have received initial contact with the horticultural ideas, "but continued to pursue an essentially hunting and gathering lifestyle” (Lynott 1981b:105). The environment, as shown by evidence at archaeological sites, may have shifted slightly to wetter conditions during the Late Archaic Period. Human activities tend to bias palecenvironmental data due to differential selection of species and different processing techniques. This factor points out the need to collect paleoenvironmental information from non-site areas as well as culturally induced deposits. With wetter environmental conditions, the density of all vegetal resources would have increased, resulting in the expansion of the Eastern Cross Timbers woodlands, which would have resulted in an increase of the plants utilized for human consumption, as well as increased biomass for game animals (Prikryl 1987:170). There has been three and a half times more Late Archaic sites found than there has been Middle Archaic sites in the Upper Trinity (Prikryl 1987:166). Late Archaic Period sites are numerous and most sites have been found in floodplains, first order tributary streams, and along minor tributaries. The sites are larger or more frequently occupied, and are more widely distributed, however there is no evidence of sedentary villages. Camps and habitation areas were not occupied year-round, and movements remained in geographically circumscribed areas (Story 1981:146). Late Archaic Period sites have been recorded in North Central Texas and are relatively well represented within the project area. These sites contain the Yarbrough and Gary type points (Shafer 1964:10). Points of tne{Laiarpe Aspect have been found in Ellis county, pointing to a high probability of additional sites that may be present in the project area. The presently accepted end of the Late Archaic Period is with the apparent introduction of the bow and arrow and pottery (see below for pottery discussion). Inferentially, there was a complete shift from band level society to tribal society, with more rigid territoriality based on language limits. The expanding stem Scallorn arrow point type appeared around A.D. 700 (Story 1990:217). The bow and arrow introduction is 3-15 o-~)

With the bow and arrow, there probably is a drastic change in the hunting efficiency, marked with a higher abundance of food resources and a resulting increase in population. Also, the use of the arrow indicates individual hunting strategies (stalk) versus the dart where group (surround) strategies prevailed. However, there does appear to be a time transgressive shift in the replacement of the dart by the bow and arrow and the actual date may vary depending on geographic location and the nature of hunting strategies across Texas. Among the best evidence for late or transitional Archaic use and occupation of North Central Texas comes from the deepest layers of fill in large man-made depressions at the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites in Richland Creek (Story et al. 1990:228-229). These depressions, termed "Wylie Focus pits” are ‘problematical features which may indicate group aggregation and ceremonialism, including more elaborate burial practices, beginning ca. 200 B.C. and A.D. 1 (Bruseth et al. 1987; Story 1990:235). 4 we 2 - EARLY CERAMIC PERIOD (200 B.C. - A.D. 800) It is generally accepted that the Archaic Period ends with the introduction of the bow and arrow and pottery. The date given for the first ceramics is estimated to be between A.D. 700 and 900 (Story 1990:217), although there is a possibility that early shell tempered sherds dating between A.D. 200-700 7 were present in the large pit featureg at Adams Ranch (Martin 1987:244) and Bird-Point Island (Bruseth Nor AT 4) er eol eo 1987:112-113; Bruseth and Martin 1987:164) in the Richland Creek Reservoir (Number 12 in Figure 3-6). There are a number of traits and inferred cultural behaviors which are shared with the peoples of the Late Archaic Period, but more importantly there are a number of cultural changes that do take place. These are the partial reliance on cultigens, the more prolonged stays at specific locations which represent sedentary settlements, the attention placed on social and ritual elaborations, technological innovations, and possibly (the most important) is the pottery making and the use of the bow and arrow (Story 1990:243); as well as the appearance of cemeteries (Prewitt 1981:74); although Late Archaic cemeteries are known elsewhere in Texas. Another important development in the post-Archaic is the cultural variety within the Early Ceramic Period. As with other transitional periods, the identification of specific cultural parameters indicating cultural change is difficult. The beginning of the Early Ceramic Period is identified with the initial presence of ceramics (pottery). The Early Ceramic Period corresponds to the broader Woodland Tradition of the Midwestern and Eastern United States (Story 1981:145-147). The Woodland Tradition sites are easily recognized by the thick, cordmarked vessels with conical bases (Story 1990:356). At this time there were also smoothed, flat-bottom vessels, Gary type dart points, some arrow points, especially the Scallorn type with its expanding stem dated ca. A.D. 700, cf. Story 1990:217), drills, scrapers, and grinding implements (Story 1990:356). The most common features of the Woodland Tradition are hearths and probable roasting ovens along with the less frequently occurring storage pits, burials, and possible structural remains (Story 1990:356). Apparently, major migratory patterns of bison had changed and bison were not common in this period (Dillehay 1974; Lynott 1979, 198la, 1981b). Rabbits and turtles were also hunted. Evidence at many sites suggests that the most common plant food source is the hickory nut (Martin 1987). In contrast to the results from the investigations at Richland Creek, 40 miles south of the SSC, the investigations at Joe Pool Lake 30 miles to the north of the SSC did not yield evidence of Early Ceramic cultures (Story 1990:248). This may be related to the relatively light overall settlement of the Joe Pool Lake area, which resembles that of the SSC project area itself. Limited evidence suggests that the Early Ceramic Period in North Central and East Texas evolved directly out of the earlier indigenous cultures of the Late Archaic Period. This is supported by evidence of the LaHarpe Aspect, which began in the Archaic period and continues into the Early Ceramic Period. The only difference between the earlier part of the LaHarpe Aspect and the later part of the LaHarpe Aspect is the presence of ceramics (Johnson 1962). The LaHarpe Aspect finally ends with the introduction of abundant variations of arrow points and decorated pottery which symbolizes a more sedentary mode of existence (Gohnson 1962:144). One portion of the later LaHarpe Aspect is the Fourche Maline Phase. This phase is represented primarily to the north, but some influences may have entered the SSC area. The artifacts associated with the Fourche Maline Phase include Williams Plain ceramics, stone gorgets, boat stones, double-bitted chipped stone axes, shell gorgets, bone atalat] hooks and corner-tanged knives (Johnson 1962:269). A noted by Story (1990:248), much remains to be unraveled of this period in North Central Texas. The ceramics of the Fourche Maline Phase culture are grog and bone tempered and are often left undecorated. These pots are flat based with flaring sides and are sometimes referred to as "flower-pots". Typologically this kind of pottery is called Williams Plain (Brown 1971:42-54). Williams Plain ceramics are almost always associated with Pre-Caddo occupations and normally date prior to A.D. 800. During the Early Ceramic Period there appears to be two distinct ceramic traditions. The grog and bone tempered paste tradition is associated with the Fourche Maline culture while the sandy paste tradition is associated with what has been recently called the Mossy Grove Tradition (Story 1990:256-259). This later tradition is located to the south of the SSC project area, along the Gulf Coast. While changes occurred in most aspects of the lifeways of Early Ceramic Period, subsistence patterns appear to have changed little. This is based on the lack of tropical cultigens, but squash (Curcurbita pepo) and sunflower seeds have been found in Early Ceramic Period sites (Story 1981:146). "Subsistence was probably based on an intensive foraging strategy and possibly included incipient cultivation of native food resources” (Story 1981:146). Ceramic vessels were an important innovation which possibly reflects alternative ways of food preparation that were not known in the earlier Archaic periods (Story 1981:146), and this could signify the beginning of intensified subsistence. The Fulton Aspect and the Late Ceramic Period as defined here, both end at A.D. 1600. As for the settlement patterns of the Caddoan people, we find “habitation loci, special purpose camps and other areas whure more ephemeral activities are carried out, burial grounds, and community (or ceremonial) centers" (Story 1990:334). Northeast Texas was “occupied by sedentary villagers who depended upon cultivated crops for a significant portion of their diet" (Story 1981:147). The habitation localities are identified as having refuse consisting of sheet trash and concentrated midden deposits as well as other cultural features (Story 1990:334). The artifacts associated with these habitation sites include broken or depleted lithic tools such as arrow points, drills, utilized flakes, celt fragments, chipping debris, potsherds, pipe fragments, and possibly floral and faunal remains (Story 1990:334). Story (1990:334) list other cultural features which also may occur and includes large and small pits, hearths, occasional concentrations of bummed rocks and a small number of structures. There are even possible bell shaped storage pits at some sites and a few burials. Most of the Caddoan habitation locations appear to be those of farmsteads or hamlets. Village sites are uncommon until the Fulton Aspect of the Late Caddoan Period (Anderson 1972:122). There is quite a lot of information known about the burial locations of the Caddoan people. The Caddoan burials are frequently accompanied by grave offerings and this has promoted vandalism and looting of Caddoan sites in East Texas. Differing sizes of burials and burial goods may represent differences in the sizes and numbers of communities contributing to the burials and the distinction of social class, both ascribed and achieved (Story 1990:338). The most common grave encountered, probably of low status individuals, is a single grave usually less than a meter deep. These burials are usually in or near the habitation site, often in areas with other burials or in formally defined cemeteries (Story 1990:339). The offerings to the dead consist of mostly pottery but often contain omaments like shell beads, personal items like weapons and tool kits, as well as lithics and ceramics (Story 1990:339). The differences in burials such as the grave goods is inferred as evidence for the existence of a complex social (and religious/political) system (Story 1990:339). "The most lavish and expensive (as measured in terms of exotic offerings and labor expended) interments were the shaft burials associated with earth mounds” and are presumably “reserved for only the highest ranking individual(s) in the society” (Story 1990:339). This suggests that there is strong evidence of a hierarchical structure based on the burial goods and the burial types or mounds. 3-19

## Page 62

At the close of the Gibson ‘Aspect and the beginning of the Fulton Aspect there is a shift in settlement pattern. The population moves into small villages and with that comes the loss of impressive mounds and status burials of the earlier Gibson Aspect (Anderson 1972:122). During the Late Ceramic Period a number of new traits appeared, including highly decorated ceramic vessels, the acquisition and circulation of marine shell (most notably conch), flat-topped mounds, standardization of ceremonial activities associated with the dead (commonly referred to as the Southern Cult), and villages with central plazas. These sites are found principally in southwest Arkansas, the extreme northeast corner of Texas, and in northeast Oklahoma. It has been suggested, using dental morphological data from a number of sites, that areas in Arkansas and Oklahoma, while distinctively Caddoan, display considerable physiological differences which may indicate ethnic or tribal differences (Rose et al. 1985; Roge and Hoffman 1986; Schambach 1990:67-68). Furthermore, there is another Caddo manifestation in eastern Texas south of the Red River which may be a third distinct ethnic or tribal group, however no dental studies have been done on these people at this time (Burnett 1990:385-418). There is evidence which suggests that some exchange of cultural traits did exist between the Caddoan people and Lower Mississippi River Valley Mississippian Tradition people. The extent of this interaction is not known but the Caddo shared most material culture traits amongst themselves rather than with adjacent groups. The Caddo have very distinctive traits in ceramic styles and motifs. These consist of formal and decorative features. Distinctive Caddoan vessel forms include carinated bowls, bowls with rim peaks, and long-necked bottles (Kreiger 1947:233; Webb 1961:19; Davis 1970:40; Hoffman 1969:160; Wyckoff 1974:65). Techniques used for decoration include engraving, excising, zoned punctation and polishing. These techniques are common in the creation of the characteristic Caddoan curvilinear designs such as interlocking scrolls, swills and concentric circles. Other vessels may display a combination of the curvilinear designs with the addition of a series of vertical, horizontal and/or diagonal lines. Pinched ridges, brushed-incised designs and applique fillets are also common Caddoan decorative techniques. The Caddo also used a red slip to cover the entire surface of a vessel. Engraved designs filled with a dry pigment, such as red ocher or white pigment, are also very characteristic Caddo decorative motifs. ~ The Caddo ceramic vessels found in Texas have some presence of fired clay fragments or crushed sherds as temper in their pastes. Most of the Caddo ceramics here are composed of grit-grog paste which contain a varying degree of bone, shell, sand, organic debris and limestone (Bell and Baerries 1951). The bone used as a temper is a crushed bone and this is associated with the early Caddo, principally the Gibson Aspect. The shell temper is also crushed and it appears to be associated with the later Caddoan ceramics of the Fulton Aspect. The shell tempering is not an indigenous Caddoan trait, and it may have been adopted from adjacent Plains Village populations (Orr 1952; Skinner et al. 1969:64; Story 1981:151), or the Lower Mississippi Valley. 3-20 aos oe me : Lo) sil

In addition to the ceramic types listed above are other traits of the Caddoan speaking people which include sedentary villages, reliance (ranging from light to strong) on maize agriculture , ranked societies and complex exchange networks (Story 1981:139). "Circular houses with interior support posts, certain clay pipe forms, and shaftlike burial pits with elaborate offerings" (Story 1978:57) are other archaeological traits which have been recognized as characteristically Caddoan. Some additional features for the Late Ceramic Period include rock-lined hearths and fire cracked rock and daub concentrations, The most noticeable change in the lithic tool assemblage is in the arrow point types. The bow and arrow hunting method produces changes in hunting techniques and probably improved hunting efficiency” (Story 1981:147). The lithic tool types of North Central Texas during the Late Ceramic Period are’ characterized by(an influx of Southern Plains}consisting of Washita, Harrell, and Fresno arrow points, snub- nosed scrapers, edge-beveled knives and flake drills (Prikryl 1987:178). The evidence for subsistence practices of the Caddo and other associated Native American groups is obtained from the analysis of fauna, floral and human skeletal remains and from ethnographic research done by the French and Spanish in the years from 1687-1772 (Anderson 1972:133). Subsistence appears to be from a mix of wild resources, plants and animals, fish, and cultivated crops such as corn and beans (Story 1990:343). Corn was the main domesticated staple with beans the second (Anderson 1972:133). White- tailed deer was the most often hunted animal but squirrel and rabbit, bird, and fish were also utilized as supplements to the diet (Story 1990:343). Over-all, by the Middle to Late Caddoan period, “the adaptive efficiency (as measured by nutritional status, incidence of infectious disease, and mean age of death) of both the subadults and adults was comparatively good, only to decline in the Late Caddoan period" (Story 1990:343). There have been a number of hypotheses suggested to explain the decline of the Caddoan groups for this period. The first of two suggested by Woodall (1972; Dillehay 1974; Lynott 1979) is the re-entry of the bison into the southern Plains after A.D. 1200, which may suggest a drier climate. Bison are thought to prefer the short grass prairie biome in which they develop larger herds. The second hypothesis is a gradual dispersal of population from the early ceremonial centers to hinterland communities. This dispersal could be due to the diminished return necessary to maintain social complexity. As simple societies expand and invest in more elaborate political expansion, there is an insufficient return to the local level, which engenders disaffection and re-segmentation (Sahlins 1963, 1968; Leach 1954; Tainter 1988:205). As for material found in the Superconducting Super Collider project area, there is strong evidence to suggest a shift back to bison hunting and a bison-oriented economy. This period in North Central Texas is characterized by an influx of southern Plains type tool assemblages consisting of Washita, Harrell, and Fresno arrow points, snub-nosed scrapers, edge-beveled knives and flake drills (@rikryl 1987:178). PROTOHISTORIC PERIOD (A.D. 1536 - 1820) Some of the earliest Protohistoric Period people in North Central Texas were those of the Washita River Phase in Oklahoma. It has been stated that "sometime around A.D. 1450-1500, many of the Washita River Phase sites appear to have been abandoned, possibly as a result of population pressure from nomadic groups such as the Apache or Kiowa who were apparently moving into the Southem Plains” (Wedel 1961:131-148; Bell 1973:185; Schroeder 1962; Brooks and Drass 1984:33). This may have been caused by climatic stress and/or environmental changes or by political and economic factors introduced by Europeans. By A.D. 1550, these groups appear to have coalesced into fewer and larger villages, and some sites begin to yield occasional European trade goods. These villages were located on river terraces (Skinner and Gallagher 1974:8), mainly along the Red River. - Other native groups utilizing this area during the Protohistoric Period included the Wichita, the Tonkawa, the Waco, the Caddo (Bidai, Anadarko) and in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries a variety of groups which immigrated from the eastern United States including Cherokee, Chickasaw, Delaware, Kickapoo, Choctaw, Koasati, Alabama, as well as others (Skinner et al. 1978:28). These groups from the eastern United States were forced to immigrate to this region by pressure from the expanding Anglo-American frontier (Drinnon 1980; Henri 1986). By the time North Central Texas was being frequented by Europeans, the dominating groups were tribes of various Wichita speaking peoples. These included the Taovayas, Wichita proper, Yscanis, and the Tawakonis (Story 1990:363). In addition, this region was also occupied by the Kitsais, the Osages, the Apaches, the Comanche, and the Tonkawas and the later by Chickasaw and Choctaw (Story 1990:363). 3-22 . C i) ee

The Wichita proper and the Waco groups survived as relatively coherent cultural entities until well into the nineteenth century in North Central Texas but other groups may have disappeared completely (Anthony and Brown 1990:9). Some of the first people in contact with the “outside” world in Texas may have been those contacted by the expedition sent out by the then-governor of Jamaica, Francisco Garay, who explored the mouth of the Rio Grande between 1519 and 1523. Another expedition was Alvar Nunez Cabeza de Vaca and the survivors of the Narvaez expedition to the Texas coast in 1528 (Anthony and Brown 1990:9). In North Central Texas, most likely the first contact was with remnants of the De Soto Expedition in the fall of 1542 (Anderson 1972:133). In any case this early contact would not have had a great impact for several centuries, except possibly for the spread of contagious diseases. It is even possible that trade goods from the French reached this area even earlier. The Native Americans which De Soto met in Texas in 1542 were the Hasinai Confederacy which consisted of 9 or 11 Caddo-speaking tribes. This Confederacy may have been a result of the low population densities caused by diseases and warfare. French and Spanish observers recorded the customs of the Hasinai during the years of 1687-1772 (Anderson 1972:133). This period is marked by massive changes which in part may be the result of the introduction of the horse by the Spanish in 1675 (Anderson 1972:133). With the use of the horse, the Late Caddoan residence pattern changed from the sedentary forest hamlets to seasonal scheduling of nomadic hunting forays onto the Plains. However, this also brought about warfare with the Osage and Comanche who claimed the Plains hunting grounds. The subsistence pattern information gathered between 1687 and 1772 demonstrates how the men would hunt deer, ducks, geese and prairie chicken in winter time. Buffalo (Bison bison) hunting was done year- round with major hunts occurring in the winter time, since buffalo hunting required far distant travel to get to the region with the buffalo. Males would also clear and break the soil for planting. The women would do all of the planting, harvesting, cleaning and storage of crops and gathering of the wild plants. During the period 1772-1781, there was a severe drought (Stahle and Cleaveland 1988:59-74) which may have promoted the abandonment of agriculture which may have encouraged a shift to bison hunting as a major subsistence strategy. In the late 1830's Texas military leaders decided to remove all of the Native Americans from the state. In 1838, General Rusk's volunteers burned a Caddo village which was located near present-day Arlington (Skinner et al. 1978:29). The surviving Caddo left the area. In 1839, a group of Cherokee and Delaware re- established a large village (ca 1,000 persons) at approximately the same location, which was totally destroyed by General Tarrant in 1841 (Skinner et al. 1978:29). After these incidents, the population of the Native Americans in North Central Texas continued to decline until 1854 when all Indians were removed to a reservation on the Brazos River (Skinner et al. 1978:29). However, archival and in some cases biophysical and archaeological evidence is mounting to indicate that a significant number of Native Americans merged into Anglo-American society in North Central Texas. 3-23

Other archaeological work in Ellis County has been limited to small areas such as Soil Conservation Service (SCS) dams and flood retarding structures, or utility (gas and water pipelines and powerlines) projects which are often narrow linear transects. The SCS did survey along two miles of upper Big Onion Creek, without recording a single site. The 23.4 mile water pipeline from Richland/Chambers Reservoir to Ennis was surveyed, with eleven localities (four prehistoric and seven historic) in Ellis County, none of which merited further work (Archaeology Research Program 1982). The prehistoric sites were all located on exposed Uvalde gravels, and contained tested cobbles, debitage, and tool fragments, none of which were temporally diagnostic. A linear transect for a powerline was surveyed from Waxahachie to Ennis (approximately 15 miles) by Espey Huston and Associates, but only two historic sites were recorded at TARL. The proposed lucation (ca. 200 acres) of the Waxahachie - Midlothian Airport yielded only two historic sites (Westbury 1986), one of which received National Register test evaluations (Westbury 1989). Finally, a 12 mile transect for the Rockett Water Supply Corporation was surveyed between Midlothian and Sterrett, and yielded four historic sites. The portion between Sterrett and the Rockett terminus, as well as all corporate lines was surveyed by Ferring (1983), and yielded no prehistoric or historic sites. As these surveys indicate, nearly all recorded prehistoric sites are located in the eastern project area where there are extensive Uvalde gravel veneers. These veneers also extend along Red Oak and Chambers Creeks, where sites are also known. In addition, there is a tendency for intensively occupied sites (41EL11) to be located near intermittent or permanent springs. In terms of major, comprehensive projects, only the Richland Chambers Reservoir (Number 12 in Figure 3-6) in Freestone and Navarro Counties, and Joe Pool Lake (Number 1 in Figure 3-6) in Dallas, Tarrant, and a small portion of Ellis County, are near the SSC project. These and other reservoir projects provide a broad regional network of study areas (Figure 3-5), mainly restricted to floodplain, and forests, in marked contract to the SSC, which is primarily uplands and prairies. In all, 15 prehistoric sites received extensive data recovery at Richland/Chambers Reservoir. At Joe Pool Lake, five prehistoric sites received ‘ extensive data recovery. Briefly, the results of the investigations at Richland/Chambers Reservoir indicate prehistoric occupation fromy€a. 3000 B.C.)to A.D. 1650, with the most occurring during the Richland Creek Phase (A.D. 700-900) and the Round Prairie Phase (A.D. 900-1300). During this time the climate was slowly drying while group mobility decreased. Subsistence strategies appeared not to change and was based on the collection of and storage of native foods (Bruseth et al. 1987:240-241). 3-25 \ S Le 6 [ & ee

Jurney This chapter presents the analysis of recorded information, informant reports, and landowner interviews that relate to the specific historic archaeological properties and communities within and around the project area, This historical overview is related to the known historical properties and the research questions appropriate to their archaeological context. The written record provides the specific dates of events, people, and their actions. Although as early as 1532 there is documentary evidence of Spanish and French activity in East Texas, no settlement is known for the upper Trinity, however some explorers may have passed near the SSC project area. It is possible that Luis de Moscoso led the survivors of Hernando de Soto's expedition through North Central Texas en route from the Mississippi River back to Mexico (Reese et al. 1986:154). In the eighteenth century, other expeditions, such as that by Athanase DeMezieres (Castaneda 1945:2-3) passed through East Texas, south of the project area. CULTURE HISTORY Initial Settlement In 1756, the presidio San Augustin de Ahumada and the mission of Nuestra Senora de la Luz were established on the banks of the lower Trinity River (Bolton 1914, Foscue 1960). Also, by the mid- eighteenth century both Spanish and French traders had developed exchange networks with Native Americans who resided in Texas. However, these networks did not match the extensive slave and deer hide trading system established by the Spanish, French, and English in the southeastern United States and Canada (Henri 1986). The social, economic, and political changes wrought on native societies there in the late eighteenth century led to increased emigration and long term use of Texas and regions west of the Mississippi for hunting forays by southeastern Native American groups such as the Choctaw as early as 1766 (Kinnaird and Kinnaird 1980:349-370) and the Cherokee (Clarke 1971:13-15), and Alabama-Koasati in the early 1800s (Flores 1985; Holley 1965:44 and 100). As a result of these early incursions in the Trans- Mississippi South there were conflicts between native (Tehuacana, Tonkawa, Waco, Wichita) and other immigrant Indians. During the late eighteenth century and the first three decades of the nineteenth century, these Native Americans formed a buffer between the cores of European and American settlement; primarily the Red River Valley, southeast Texas, and the Gulf Coast (principally Austin Colony) and Mexican 4-1

Any settlements in the SSC project area dating to this period are hypothesized to be light, short term encampments with very little cultural debris remaining. Mexican Colonial The Spanish system of land grants was designed to provide land only to Spanish citizens. Some Americans began to take advantage of this by immigrating into Spanish territory. For instance Moses Austin immigrated into Spanish Louisiana in 1797 (what is today Missouri), renounced his American citizenship, and developed a strong relationship with Spanish officials (Haley 1985:9). After the Louisiana Purchase he began to plan trade missions to Spanish Texas and in 1819, following a financial panic, he followed Spanish requests to immigrate into Texas to secure an Anglo-American Colony, with himself as Empresario, This land allocation system allowed the empresario to charge fees from settlers and still obtain land in compensation for encouraging their settlement. Following the Mexican Revolution in 1821, Moses and Stephen Austin gained the opportunity to persuade the new government to allow the planned settlement which was approved with a new colonialization law in 1823, with each settler receiving a maximum of a league (4,428 acres) for ranching, and a labor (177 acres) for cultivation (Haley 1985:17). The Public Domain in the SSC project area within today's Ellis County was first distributed in the Mexican Colonial Period. This includes the eight leagues (35,424 acres) awarded to Thomas Jefferson Chambers in 1834. Chambers is typical of many American entrepreneurs (such as Moses and Stephen Austin) who were attempting to take advantage of the liberal Mexican land policies. Also, these entrepreneurs were in competition with Native Americans and Immigrant Indians in Texas. In 1826, Thomas J. Chambers a 24-year-old immigrant from Virginia went to Mexico to study its language and laws following the entrepreneurial spirit of Moses and Stephen Austin. By 1828 he had been appointed Surveyor General of the state of Coahuila and Texas, and was promoted to State Attorney in 1834. For his services, he received 35 leagues (over 150,000 acres), including the eight leagues in Navarro County (Glaspy 1981; Jurney and Glaspy 1987:40). This land acquisition along the upper Trinity River was in a consortium with Rafael de la Pena (actually his attorney, Nathaniel Townsend), Jose Manuel Bangs, Ira Lewis, and Isaac Dunahoe, all residing in Leona Vicario, of the State of Coahuila and Texas. Rafael de la Pena transferred his 11 leagues of land to Nathaniel Townsend on July 13, 1830; this was witnessed by T. J. Chambers, and the tract was surveyed by J. G. W. Pearson on October 23, 1834 (Texas General Land Office, Spanish Collections 130:17). Although there was land speculation during the Mexican Colonial Period involving lands within the SSC project area, no known settlements were produced. The only potential sites could be the temporary camps of the land surveyors, and the actual land tract corner posts or witness trees that they observed, During this same time, Immigrant Indians and Native Texas, Indians were skillfully denied land rights in the same region, primarily through diplomatic maneuvers such as those of Joel R. Thus, Immigrant Indians and Native Texan Indians were seen as unwelcome competitors for Mexican lands which the Anglos wanted and conversely, any land surveyors or speculators were seen as direct threats to Native American lifeways and homes. Republic of Texas In 1836, Texas gained its independence through armed revolution from Mexico, and for a decade was an independent nation. In order to fill the coffers of the Treasury, Texas sold the only commodity it had, land. From 1836 to 1838, Texas organized a system of land allocation which was based on a network of land districts (Figure 4-1). This system allowed veterans of the war to be paid for their services through land grants. Recent immigrants could also receive land for minimal cost. Also, another empresario system was established to encourage further settlement. During the spring of 1838, a group of surveyors from Franklin, the seat of the Robertson Land District, began to survey large blocks of grants in the area later to become Ellis, Navarro, and Freestone Counties. B.J. Chambers, the son of T.J. Chambers, surveyed several tracts in the SSC project area for the Robertson Land District at this same time. Two parties, totalling 23 surveyors, had a rendezvous on upper Richland Creek, approximately 25 miles south of the SSC. They were ambushed in October 1838 bya large party of Kickapoo Indians on a bison hunt, and only one man, William Henderson, survived the battle (Samuels and Knox 1980; Jumey and Glaspy 1987:40). The presence of Kickapoo Indians in what is today Navarro County, approximately 30 miles south of the SSC project area indicates that they and other Immigrant Indians may have passed through the project area. Even though some land was granted within the SSC project area and was surveyed from 1834-1838, there was not any significant settlement, primarily due to these Native and Immigrant Indians, who retaliated against Anglo encroachment. It was not until the Cherokee, chief negiotiators for all Immigrant Indian groups, were forcefully removed (despite intercessions by Sam Houston) in 1839 that extensive settlement was possible in the project area. The young Texas Republic was without any financial structure and Public Domain was the only readily accessible commodity. The first land grant system in the Republic, as discussed above, still paralleled that of the Mexican Colonial Period (metes and bounds), and allowed individual selection of tracts as well as the empresario contract system which promoted wholesale grants to citizens (Shine 1969). The first grants were given along the Gulf coast, and available land rapidly became depleted, particularly the most desirable tracts. Also the size of grants was such that not all of the acreage could be located where the people first given grants lived or had first settled. Many of the 1838-1850 surveys in the SSC area (Figure 4-2) were surveyed to make up for unfiled grants from other Land Districts (see Appendix B), or were the balance remaining from the original grant. 4-3

## Page 75

Ney t (aaa) Ga Ge i ‘] Many of the early land surveys refer to the distance from Fort Graham in today's Hill County in order to locate in time and space the individual grant that they were surveying. These were the metes and bounds equivalent of a meridian, where surveys were tied into previously known and mapped locations. Fort Graham apparently served as a refuge in times of hostilities with immigrant and Native Indians as well as time of inclement weather such as did Kings Fort in Kaufman County to the east (e. g., McCaleb 1906:34- 40). The complicated division of Public Domain in Texas represents to an extent the division between the northern and southern United States. The northern United State used a rectangular grid system which was arbitrarily divided according to standard acreages (640, 320, 160 acre intervals) despite the landforms and available resources. In the southern United States, a metes and bounds system was used which allowed a settler to choose the landscape features he desired, if they were not already claimed and marked by other settlers or Indians. The Euro-American settlement in Texas was based on the sale of land according to a system which originated first from Spain and Mexico and included the empresario system which was maintained in the Republic Period. The Peters' Colony, an empresario contractor based in Louisville, Kentucky, within the Texas Republic used a N-S oriented (Township and Range baseline meridian modeled after the United States system of surveying) grid to divide their allotted land grants. The Nacogdoches Land District used a grid 45° west of north. The Robertson Land District used a grid oriented 35° west of north. There is no apparent reason why the Robertson and Nacogdoches systems follow this declination. All of these socio-political and cadastral systems collided in Ellis County (Figure 4-2). Appendix B presents the data compiled from the GLO records for 185 land tracts in the SSC project area. A brief discussion of the information is presented here. The Robertson Land District administered (surveyed) at least 123 of the 185 land tracts which were surveyed on-the-ground in the sample from Ellis County. However, not all of these tracts were granted by the Robertson Land District. In fact, other land districts comprised the largest input of actual grants (N=57), followed by the Mercer's Colony (N=30), Peters' Colony (N=18), and the Robertson Land District itself (N=18). The high incidence (62 of 185) of secondary relocation from other land districts (Figure 4-3 and 4-4) and the certified Peters’ and Mercer's Colonialists indicate that the Public Domain had been quite depleted prior to the onset of the Ellis County administration (beginning in 1850), which was completely responsible for all land Surveys after 1858 (N=62 or 185). The lag effect from the secondary location of parcels remaining from Republic of Texas land certificates continued until 1869. From 1870 onward, most grants were from Ellis County or the General Land Office and were administered through Ellis County and surveyed by its own surveyors (see below). A substantial number of the early land surveyors were instrumental in the evolution of local entrepreneurial systems based on land acquisition. B. J. Chambers, for example, also controlled land in Freestone County, Central Texas (Jurney 1990) in 1867 helped found Clebume in today's Johnson County to the west (Block 1970), along with W. F. Henderson, the Kickapoo battle survivor. D. R. Mitchell, J. E. Patton, and G. W. Cunningham played important roles in the Robertson Land District/Peters' Colony 4-4

## Page 83

Eloquent descriptions of the SSC area prior to extensive settlement or land alteration are as follows. "The black soil did present drawbacks for travelers. The roads in North Central Texas were universally primitive, and the early settlers found them a serious obstacle. There were no bridges or graded roads," recalled Mrs. George James, who family traveled from Tennessee to the northeastern part of Dallas County in 1855. "When travelers came to one of those rushing streams they just had to wait until the water went down. Getting up and down those steep muddy banks was a hard problem. Wagons would often sink to the hubs. With each wheel loaded with sticky black mud that had to pried off with poles, the teams had to be doubled and hitched to a wagon to get across" (James 1927:3-4). Yet the land had an irresistible virgin beauty, which remained vividly in the memories of the early pioneers. "Our first impressions of Texas," wrote Mrs. James (1927:1-2), “were the vastness of the prairies and the long range of vision. It seemed we could see where the sky and earth met... When spring came the prairies were like a vast flower garden. Flowers of every hue spread out for miles." Her sentiments were echoed by John Billingsley, whose family crossed the Red River in 1844 after a difficult journey from Missouri. “This prairie land was then in its beauty,...no plow had ever skimmed its surface, no barbed wire, no wall or ditch crossed the trail of the Indian hunter, the wild deer in his flight or the wild horse in his ramble, A carpet of green grass now covered the land and our horses and oxen no longer rambled in search of food over this beautiful and rich prairie country we traveled” (Billingsley 1885:202). By 1846, Taos or Porters Bluff (at the junction of today's Ellis, Navarro, and Henderson Counties) had become an important community for packets and small steamers (Jester 1944; Jumey and Glaspy 1987:43). By 1848, roads were constructed originating from this town. At its peak, Taos had a 20 room hotel, homes, blacksmith, sawmill, boat landing, warehouses, and a ferry (Richner and Bagot 1978:196). Taos was twice destroyed by floods in 1866 and in 1878, when it was finally abandoned. In 1850, a north-south military road was constructed from Austin to Oklahoma, and is shown on the 1852 map of Peters Colony (Figure 4-6). A number of branches extended off this route in northern Ellis and southern Dallas Counties. Also, a route followed the crest of the Austin Chalk uplift, which was a reported branch of the Chisholm Trail according to Mrs. J. R. Dunaway (Brooks et al. 1964:70). This cattle trail was also known as the Shawnee Trail, which ended with with three branches to Kansas City, Sedalia, and St. Louis, Missouri (Stephens and Holmes 1989). As shown in Figure 4-6, land division was only partially completed by the Peters' Colony. Many of the tracts claimed by the Peters' Colony were in actuality already granted to others, and some of the tracts shown in Figure 4-6 as being granted were later cancelled by court action. Also, all original field notes were stolen from the Peters' Colony Office by irate settlers and were destroyed (Connor 1959). Many of these tracts had to be resurveyed. Plantations and Farmsteads 1850-1870 The entire region of central and northern Texas which contained the Blackland Prairie witnessed an era of growth prior to the Civil War. From the 1850s on intensive cotton production was exported from the 4-6

Dunlap, who immigrated from Mississippi with his father and slaves (Green 1970:254-257) settling on the John and Ann Adams Survey just prior to the Civil War. He expanded beyond farming, was a self-taught jurist, and also was president of the Cotton Association, Good Road Association, the Currency Association, and the American Exchange Banking System (Green 1970:165). This individual also was instrumental in the formation of the Ellis County Farm in 1883. In addition, his widowed mother married P. C. Sims (an early Boz settler) which united these prominent families and their lands. By 1850, the overland routes had been established through the project area (see Figure 4-6). The Old Springfield: Road from Hcuston to the north Texas area was one of the main routes, used primarily for driving cattle. The vast majority of immigration to this area at this time was originating from the southern States (Lee 1982), including a high proportion of slave owners (White 1940:904). Slave holding was an essential part of cotton production, but the intensity of this practice was never as great as along major river drainages of the Gulf Coastal Plain. As noted above, the Peters' Colony promoted immigration from midwestemers, the Ohio Valley, and Tennessee. In the 1850s, the cultural and territorial conflicts between these zones of settlement collided in Ellis County. One Peters’ Colonialist, Peter Stout (and his family), occupied two farmsteads in the East Campus area. Also, land tracts belonging to Samuel Billingsley and his son are within the SSC project area. Two major north-south arteries led out of Waxahachie, one followed the exposed Austin Chalk uplift along the headwaters of all drainages through Cedar Hill and into Dallas, while another (the eastern route) intersected a network of roads and led south crossing Grove Creek to Taos. John Billingsley recalled that “from the year 1848 to 1851 there were great changes in the country...people were moving in more each year, the water courses were being lined with settlements, farms and houses began to dot the prairie, dry goods and grocery stores were established in Dallas and a few in the county at different points” (Billingsley 1885:218). In 1859, on the eve of the Civil War, Texas was fifth in cotton production. In 1860-1861 the script grants (land given in compensation for expenditures) given to the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado RR Co. from Ellis County indicate that the railroad was considered an important mode of transportation which had to be developed in the SSC region. However, the war delayed the railroad and depleted the cotton industry. Also, during the 1850s-1860s Texas underwent the most prolonged drought in the last 300 years (Stahle and Cleaveland 1988:66), which greatly depleted the agricultural economy. Texas did not match the 1859 cotton production, probably due to the drought and the realignment of the labor force, again until 1875 (Agelasto et al. 1922:331). By 1879, Texas was the largest cotton producer of all states in the union, and remained so into the early twentieth century. 4-7

## Page 86

Civil War and Reconstruction The Civil War halted the settlement and economic growth of Ellis County, and most agricultural productions were donated to the Southern cause. The only Public Domain which was surveyed during this period was script to individuals who contributed to the war effort. After 1865, however, land surveying rapidly began again, and apparently the entire region again attracted settlement. For example, B. F. Forrester (site 41EL78) settled in the Boz community in 1869 and joined J. M. Dunaway (1855, site 41EL75) as the earliest resident farmers and landholders in the area. The principal labor source for cotton production, slaves, was lost after the Civil War. Blacks had a brief taste of social equality in the late 1860s and early 1870s due to the radical Republican influence over southern legislators. Fraternal organizations and some governmental positions were nc + available to African Americans. However, the “public” demand for self rule and white supremacy resulted in the reinstatement of the political milieu that had existed prior to the war. An example is the transactions between James Agee, Isaac and Ann Newton (colored), and William Smith. R. M. Wyatt, a local surveyor and land entrepreneur, filed an affadavit with the Texas General Land Office that Isaac and Ann Newton were working as agents for Smith, when they obtained their homestead in 1875 (see site 41EL104). R. M. Wyatt was the principal land surveyor for Ellis County after the Civil War, and also secured many tracts of vacant land, Due to the abolition of slavery, a new system of production became necessary in order to practice cotton agriculture. Tenant farmers (croppers, renters, or otherwise) became a major substitute for slave labor in the cotton belt. Tenant farming was both an economic system and a social institution in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. For the North Central Texas area, Saunders (1982:180) outlined the general principles behind this form of farming: : Briefly, tenant farming represents an economic system which, at a general level, can be divided _.into the land owning and non-land owning classes. In addition, this southern institution was “occupied by both white and black families at the owner/non-owner levels. Consequently, the most widely represented period presents a data base which may be classified along economic (owner vs. non-owner) and ethnic (white vs. black) divisions. Tenant farming may be defined as the right of an individual to farm a landowner's land for either a set fee paid in cash or by an exchange of a predetermined proportion of the final crop harvested for a particular period. Although the precise terms varied from state to state, the general agreements usually followed the terms presented in Table 4-1. The half system for the sharecropper and the one-quarter cotton and one-third com for the tenant farmer became the standard fees allowed by the State of Texas in 1913 (McElree 1917:45). Although cash tenants were formally recognized throughout all states as a specific type of tenant, they were extremely low in number and continued to decrease in frequency throughout the early twentieth century (Saunders 1982:180-182). Table 4-1 lists the types of tenancy and economic relationships and practices (after Goldenweiser and Boeger 1913). 4-8

Essentially, goods transported by rail facilitated the rapid growth of the cotton industry in the Blackland Prairie. Farmers were now able to ship their product to manufacturers while at the same time manufactured goods could be imported to the rural communities. Also, cotton ginning and pressing machinery could be imported to railroad centers, and farming cooperatives and businesses could greatly increase the efficiency and profits to be realized from cotton agriculture. As noted above, active development of the railroad began in 1860-1861 and recommenced in 1866, based on the granting of land script to railroad companies in Ellis County. The Houston and Texas Central Railroad (H&TC) joined Houston and Dallas and was completed in 1871. This line joined the Missouri Kansas & Texas Railroad at Denison to complete the rail line from Houston to St. Louis (Ellis County History Workshop 1972:51; Hardy-Heck-Moore Inc. 1990:45). Ennis was developed as a regional business and labor center following the completion of this railroad. Several

## Page 88

towns (e. g., Alsdorf, Ferris, Palmer, Trumbull, Garrett) were also established by the general railroad program of placing towns every 20 or 50 miles, and switching stations where needed. This railroad greatly influenced settlement along the eastern side of the project area. After Ennis was incorporated in 1872, pioneer immigrants from eastern Europe (Bavaria, Germany, Czechslovakia, etc.) began to settle there. Script land given to the railroads was available for settlement. - The success of one immigrant was passed back to the homeland, and informal networks were established that promoted subsequent immigration (Stollregen 1973). Nationally, a surge in immigration began around 1900, and many immigrants arrived in Ennis, such as Joe and Josie Dolezal from Bavaria (see 41EL1 19). The Waxahachie Tap Railroad was organized in 1875 and was finished in 1879, cutting through prime cotton country to the H&TC at Garrett. This line was joined by the Texas Midland Railroad in 1928, providing a connection through the Blackland Prairie cotton belt to Paris, Texas. This latter line was abandoned in 1943 becc ise of severe washouts (Ellis County History Workshop 1972:113; Hardy-Heck- Moore Inc. 1990:47). On the local level, the presence of the railroad allowed farmers and co-operatives to reach higher levels of cotton production and processing. Oil and bale presses (see site 41EL134) at local gins allowed greater efficiency and cost-benefit when products were sold. The railroad provided the means to tie households to National Markets. The late nineteenth century marked the beginning of a major change in lifeways, from self-sufficient farms to cash crop oriented agriculture. The Gulf, Colorado, and Santa Fe Railroad was built across the northwest comer of Ellis County in 1882, but had little effect on the project area. The Fort Worth and New Orleans (part of the old Buffalo Bayou Brazos and Colorado or Trinity Brazos) reached Waxahachie in 1882, passing through the center of the project. Some communities, such as Bardwell, relocated to gain access to this line. The Missouri, Kansas, & Texas Railroad followed the path of the Shawnee Trail and 1850 military road (today's U.S. Highway 77). It reached Sterrett in 1889 and Milford in 1890. The communities of Red Oak and Forreston in the SSC project area were greatly affected by this railroad. Part of this route in the southern part of the county was joined by the International and Great Northern in 1902, which extended up Chambers Creek near Boz and led to the northwest of Maypearl. -Many communities in the project area underwent several stages in their evolution. Figure 4-5, previously shown illustrates the steps in the formation of the Boz/Bethel community. This shows how early settlement began in the forested areas of Chambers Creek and Gratehouse (Greathouse sic) Branch, and shifted to the upland prairies by the 1870s. This trend in settlement appears to be universal in Texas and was discussed in the Billingsly (1885) diary. Streams provided forests for homes and fuel, and prairies were initially used for hunting and grazing. It was not until after the Civil War that settlers began to break the raw prairie lands, . The shift from self-sufficiency to a cash based economy also had repercussions in the case of invalid and/or indigent individuals. Such individuals had traditionally been cared for within the family, but Texas in 1869 realized that county poorhouses were necessary. ## Page 89

C4 = Elizabethan England and created a system of aid to avoid starvation, but was careful not to create comfort (Cottrell 1989:171). This attitude was reinforced in the new Texas Constitution of 1876, which maintained a provision for establishing county poorhouses and farms, and which continues today. Often jail trustees were used to provide heavy labor, while indigents, mentally ill patients, and the elderly did less strenuous work. The Ellis County Poor Farm was established in 1883, indicating that a social need was present. This farm became a productive asset to county revenues, due to the influence of O. E. Dunlap. The Ellis County Farm continued in operation until 1964. Climax and Decline of Tenant Farming 1900-1945 The practice of tenant farming increased steadily in the United States between 1880 and 1930 (Vance 1929; Cauley 1930; Wise 1937), with the most precipitous increase between 1910 and 1930 (Sanderson 1937). In Texas, the percentage of tenant farms increased from 37.5% in 1880 to 60.9% in 1930 (Cauley 1930; Sanderson 1937). The WPA files for Ellis County indicate that most land purchases and construction of dwellings were in this period (see Appendix B). In the 1911-1914 period O.E. Dunlap stated that Ellis County produced 10% of Texas’ cotton, which was 10% of the world's production, and the County Farm produced 1.5 bales per acre (Green 1970:254-255). The depression of the 1930s, combined with soil exhaustion, the cotton boll weevil, and the cotton market crash culminated in the end of farm tenancy as a major agricultural strategy, although it is present in various forms today. At the close of the 1930s and early 1940s, a complete shift in population occurred as rural families moved to urban areas. Many farms in the project area were abandoned at this time, and only a few remain standing today. Rural Development after 1945 The rural portions of the project area have undergone a considerable decrease in population since World War II. Most of this decrease has been in the 20-25-year-old age group (Lee 1982). Towns, on the other hand, have shown a growth. As traditional farms became influenced by developments in technology and federal land programs, rural lifeways have become more focused on a cash economy and the use of consumer goods. The most significant aspect of this has been the mass consumption of goods, both foods as well as commodities, appliances, etc. To a large extent, yeoman agriculture and the small family farm have been replaced by agribusiness and large corporations (Richner and Lee 1977; Lee 1982). Summary Traditional approaches to the study of landscape geography have been oriented toward broad regional models of the diffusion and evolution of traits. Some settlement models used in archaeological interpretation depict economic development as a sequence progressing from initial colonization, to the spread of agrarian systems, and finally to competition for limited space and resources (Hudson 1985; Skinner et al. 1981). Rural Texas settlement has been described as being scattered and semiclustered along 4-11

These crossroad settlements sometimes grew to include 15-20 houses, major community cemeteries, blacksmith shops, and large general stores (Jordan 1973; Skinner 1983), as did the community of Boz. It has been suggested that the distances between such rural supply centers were standardized at 6-7 miles to allow the rural population access within a single day's travel time by horse and wagon (Hart 1976). Hart (1976) further suggests that farmstead dwellings and outbuildings were not placed in any particular relationship to each other, in accord with southern custom. Others, such as Glassie (1975), have suggested that some generalized patterning does exist in rural farmstead arrangement, and formal relationships among buildings and structures have been demonstrated on late nineteenth and twentieth century farmsteads in the Richland Creek (Moir and Jumey 1987) and Joe Pool Lake (Jumey et al. 1988) project areas.. Frontier settlement in East Texas concentrated first in the heavily timbered regions and then expanded along the interfingered prairie zones. Initial settlers apparently sought the openings in oak forests and the edges of timbered zones, where readjustment was not an extreme factor in the adaptation to an environment different than that from which they had come. During the latter half of the nineteenth century a combination of events and technological advances (i. e., railroads, drilling machines, windmills, reapers, steel plows, and mowers and threshers) allowed settlement to advance onto the extensive prairie grasslands. A successful farm today is measured by its owner's or manager's ability to combine several agricultural practices in the general operation of a farming enterprise (Kellog 1941:287). This is especially significant in terms of keeping these practices together, and balanced against costs and profits, as economic and social changes occur and technology progresses. The major failure of the tenant farm system can be attributed to its dependence on a single cash crop: cotton. It appears that the small family farm was diversified and continued to function quite well even into the twentieth century. These family systems ended, however, with the deaths and/or removal of those generations which fostered them. The descendants of the first and second wave of settlers either shifted gradually toward economic systems far removed from traditional rural agrarian pursuits, such as oil extraction, or relocated to urban areas. Also, many rural farms were operated by landlords who lived in town (i. e., Waxahachie, Ennis) and who either traveled to the farm, hired managers, or leased to tenants. Some farms in Ellis County have remained successful and have stayed within the same family for over 100 years. Table 4-2 lists the farms in Ellis County that have remained within families for over 100 years. In all, 24 farms are listed on the Texas Family Land Heritage Registry, kept by the Texas Department of Agriculture in Austin. Seven farms began in the 1850s (1852-1858), four in the 1860s, six in the 1870s, and seven in the 1880s. Although this is an excellent reference, listing on the family Land Heritage Registry is voluntary, and many older farms may not be included. A prime example is the J. M. Dunaway farm (41EL75) which began in 1855, is still in the family, but has not been listed. 4-12

## Page 92

PREVIOUS HISTORIC ARCHAEOLOGY The previous historic archaeological research in Ellis County has been limited to only a few recent projects. The Bardwell Reservoir studies (Shafer 1964; Sorrow 1966) completely omitted historic cultural resources from evaluation. This was the largest archaeological study in Ellis County which has been performed to date. The principal studies relating to historic cultural resources have involved large projects in neighboring counties. The archaeological evaluations of the proposed Tennessee Colony Reservoir touched on a corner of Ellis County and did include historic resources, two of which, Trinity City (41EL1) and Taos (Richner and Bagot 1978:196) are crucial to our understanding of the historical development of the region. In their integration of the historic period, Richner and Lee (1977:48-50) defined four periods of significant regional development: Frontier (1820-1840); Initial Cash Crop (1840-1870); Tenant Farming (1870-1940); and Agribusinéss (1940-Present). Although collections were made during the survey and evaluations of many historic sites were performed, no major excavations were conducted. From 1982-1984, extensive prehistoric and historic investigations were conducted for the Richland Creek Reservoir, located approximately 40 miles south of the SSC project area. Intensive historic excavations, archival searches, and informant interviews were conducted on a plantation site, 31 farmsteads, and 5 light industrial sites dating between 1855 and World War II (Moir and Jurney 1987; Jumey and Moir 1987). The results of these historic archaeological studies indicated that small landowners and tenant farmers practicing cotton agriculture dominated the settlement of the Richland Creek project area, principally occupying valley flanks and partially elevated bottomlands. The most intensive settlement began after 1860, and was densest from 1890 to 1920. Traditional lifeways were maintained until the 1930s and 1940s, and indicated a mixture of cultural elements from the upland and lowland areas of the southern United States. Archaeological deposits around farmsteads typically covered 1500 m2 to 3500 m2 adjacent to the dwelling, and contained an estimated 100,000 to 500,000 artifacts per site. Most farmsteads were occupied for 50 years or less. From 1984 to 1986, extensive prehistoric and historic investigations were conducted for Joe Pool Lake in Dallas, and Tarrant counties and a small portion of Ellis County. In all 13 historic properties received intensive study, 9 of which were landowners’ farmsteads, and 4 of which were tenant farmers’ dwellings. Middle to late nineteenth century (N=3), late nineteenth century (N=7), and twentieth century (N=3) sites were investigated by multidisciplinary methods. Cultural influences were derived from the upland area of the southern United States and from Midwestern regions. Overall, the Joe Pool Lake historic settlement pattern diverged from the trends observed among the cotton farmers of Richland Creek; and farmsteads there represent more diversified rural farming strategies from 1860 to 1930 including row crop agriculture. Settlements were located along the Austin Chalk Escarpment and the prairie interfluves, with few farms in the floodplain of Mountain Creek, 4-14 Co p= 4 — o—

Jumey The research orientation for the initial assessment of prehistoric and historic archaeological properties within the SSC Project area is human ecology. As defined in this work, human ecology includes not only the relationships between man and the biophysical environment, but also the interrelationships among/men and women}, including the political economy of human affairs. It is realized however that the probability of all types of environmental, subsistence, settlement, and material cultural information being present in the study area is not 100%. Also, the full range of human cultural affairs may not be totally documented through the archival or ethnohistorical records. Therefore the historical contexts (research questions) and potential research avenues that are proposed will be weighed against the known or possible data sets that can be recovered. The present project is an initial assessment of cultural resources within the project area and is not designed to answer the National Register eligibility or the known research potential for each property. This is mandated by several factors, the principal one being the fact that all land is still under private ownership and there is a no collection policy on private lands. Therefore archaeological reconnaissance was designed to identify all cultural properties, determine their boundaries and depths, and evaluate the material cultural content based on field observations of artifacts. Unfortunately, the material culture expertise of supervisory and field personnel varies, and firm chronological identifications of both prehistoric and historic remains were not totally successful. All temporally diagnostic artifacts were documented in field notes and photographs were taken of selected items. This phase was designed to produce as little alteration as possible to the resources, pending a future phase of study where more detailed documentation, formal test excavations, and controlled artifact collection can be implemented. Artifact collections and systematic test excavations are essential to complete the NR evaluations of each property that exhibits potential significance. Assessments of archaeological site significance will primarily be based on the criteria of the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP). The significance for archaeological, agricultural, and cultural properties, usually 50 years old, is evaluated using one or more of four NRHP criteria. Those criteria state that the quality of significance may be embodied in property types such as a building, structure, district, site, object, or artifact that possesses integrity of location, setting, feeling, and association and: 5-1 *»

Presently, a single historic context, The Emergence of Sedentism in Northeast Texas (Perttula et al. 1989, 1990), has been published. Two additional contexts are currently being reviewed, Cultural Implications of Late Quaternary Environmental Change in Northeast Texas (Collins and Bousman 1990), and The Evolution of Agricultural Societies in Northeast Texas (Perttula 1990). A historic context is an organizational framework that identifies a group of related properties based on a shared theme which is bounded in geographical space and time. Historic contexts/themes may be constructed using existing information ranging from historical data to concepts, theories, or models, These contexts should neither be so broad as to include all property types under a single framework or so narrow as to focus on only one property type (Federal Register 1983:44718). A historic context has several components (Perttula 1990) which include: (a) themes; (b) geographical boundaries and chronological limits; (c) overview of the regional data base; (d) major problems or constraints of the data base to the development of the context; (€) property types that should be considered (for both historic and prehistoric groups); (f) treatment goals for the properties and objectives for the context; (g) regional synthesis of the data base; (h) study units for the context with a brief discussion of each; 5-2 C =) 5 =a c J ee

## Page 101

— I ] As noted above, human ecology refers to the dual examination of human relationships to the biophysical environment as well as interrelationships in the cultural environment. Six (Research Questions 1, 2, 5, 6, 7, 12) of the seventeen research questions are directly related to paleoenvironmental reconstruction and the relationship of culture to environment. An overriding need to develop these research questions is chronometric dating of both cultural and natural deposits. These research questions focus most directly on the theme of human ecology and involve two major assumptions: (1) that the survival of human populations is dependent on learned behavioral responses to the biophysical and cultural environment; and (2) that cultures most likely to change will do so in response to stress. The culture-historical sequences identified for North Central Texas have been discussed in Chapter 3 for the prehistoric and Chapter 4 for the historic period. Paleoenvironmental reconstructions, along with cultural historical identification, have been major foci of archaeological investigations in two areas adjacent to the SSC project: the Richland Creek Reservoir approximately 40 miles south (Bruseth et al. 1987), and Joe Pool Lake approximately 25 miles north (Peter and McGregor 1988). In addition, archaeological surveys and excavations were conducted within the boundaries of Bardwell Reservoir. Only 15 sites dating from Archaic to Late Prehistoric were recorded (Schafer 1964), and only a single site, 41EL11, was selected for intensive excavation (Sorrow 1966). This site is located adjacent to three natural springs (C. K. Chandler, personal communication 1990). Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric occupations at 41EL11 were identified in fair stratigraphic context, with burials, hearths, and pits identified. Faunal preservation at 41EL11 was excellent with several extirpated species identified, including bison and pronghorn antelope. Other projects in Ellis County have been more limited in scope and area and were focused on pedestrian surveys (Ferring 1983; Westbury 1986; Anthony and Brown 1990). In addition to these local studies, the archaeological background and overview of the Archaeology and Bioarchaeology of the Gulf Coastal Plain (Story et al. 1990) is an essential reference for the regional archaeological record. Human ecology is a research perspective which is focused on determining how human groups tespond(ed) to and influence(d) natural environments. These responses are manifested in culture and technology. To properly address this research perspective, it is necessary to have data from archaeological contexts that indicate the times and places where human activities occurred, and non-archaeological contexts where human activities have not disturbed the paleoenvironmental record. Chronological control is an essential element of both these aspects of Human Ecology. Environmental factors such as soils, access to and availability of water, and the composition of local floral and faunal communities have been demonstrated to have direct links to human activities as interpreted from the archaeological record. Geomorphological and cultural factors such as erosion, sedimentation, soil conditions, and modern land use practices have affected both archaeological and environmental records (Collins and Bousman 1990:3). These factors must be considered when identifying and locating cultural properties, evaluating their integrity and information yield, and developing cost effective programs of investigation and preservation. 5-7
