Recycling of a earlier Structure is indicated by the eastem wing of the house. This wing is clapboard over a board and batten construction. The internal superstructure is partially constructed using cut nails and sawn pine lumber and is estimated to date from ca. 1890. These sills and wall studs were recycled from another structure which does not appear to have been located at this site. The other three wings of the structure consist of clapboard over stud frame and are constructed entirely with wire nails, with an estimated date of ca. 1930. Sawn lumber was used throughout, with 2 x 8 inch pine sills in the east wing and 10 x 10 inch pine sills in the rest of the structure. The sills rest on both cedar and bois d'arc pilings. This structure is in poor condition; between its initial survey on May 7, 1990 and a follow-up survey on July 6, 1990, one sill supporting the western wing had collapsed. The second structure 100 meters to the southwest is a partially collapsed pole barn dating to approximately 1940. A scatter of lumber 10 meters southwest of the house may be from a third, collapsed structure. A cistern located 4 meters from the house is constructed of both machine made and hand made brick. A second cistern 120 meters from the house is constructed entirely of commercial brick and was used to water livestock. Milk glass, window glass, whitewares, and a glass marble were observed around the house, all of which date to the twentieth century. These items were exposed in the cattle traffic area. The observed artifact scatter and yard features (fence, trees, cistern) cover 3600 square meters. : Structures appear at this location on the postal route map (ca. 1915), all of the Ellis County highway maps, and the 1960 USGS map (1978 update). The major disturbance to this site has been from bovine activity. The site area is curently used as pasture. Modern metal stock troughs in the farm yard indicate heavy utilization of the immediate vicinity. It does not appear that the immediate vicinity of the house has been plowed; therefore the farmyard should still be reasonably intact, with some mixing due to cattle trampling. Based on all appearances of the farmstead and the organization of structures, the house, barn, and wells were constructed around 1930-1940, using some recycled materials. Since it was built of commercially milled pine lumber, there is low potential for tree-ring dating. This site does not appear to contain information relevant to the historic Research Questions and is classified as low priority. | 41EL88 is part of the John Estes land grant. This was granted to the heirs of John and Sarah Estes on May 2, 1850 by Mercer's Colony and Kaufman County. This 295 acre grant was transferred to Blumford Shankle who located the property on March 3, 1855. W.W. Parks surveyed this tract for the Robertson Land District on October 19, 1855. In 1936 this tract belonged to J.C. Turner, who obtained the property in 1904 (ECDB 150:209). Site 41EL88 was his residence at that time. In all, two acres were reserved for the home, 0.5 acre for garden, 150 acres for cultivation (70 com and oats, 80 cotton) and 40 acres in pasture. Two dwellings were present: a nine room 1.5 story residence measuring 40 x 42 feet, which was built in 1895; and a five room "shack" measuring 32 x 36 feet. which was built in 1927. In addition to the dwellings, nine sheds and a barn were present. Fieldwork conducted at this site included close interval (5 meter) pedestrian survey. All structures and surface fedtures were closely examined, photographed, and mapped. Diagnostic artifacts were described, photographed, and left in the field. This site (Figure 7-27) currently consists of a dense 6000 square meter scatter of manganese solarized glass, window glass, whiteware, blue glass, wire nails, milk glass, and metal fragments dating from ca. 1900 to the present, The western side of the site is currently used as a cattle pen; the eastern side contains an occupied 1 story house. The house is in excellent condition and has been extensively modified. Since this house does not appear to have nine rooms, it may be the 1927 structure described by the WPA survey as a shack. Alternatively, the older structures may have been tom down and replaced by a newer dwelling. Within the cattle pen is a concrete stock trough and possible well (Plate 7-30) that may relate to an earlier use of this site. A farmstead is shown at this location on all four Ellis County highway maps and the 1960 USGS map (1978 update). No structures are shown here on the postal route map (ca. 1915), which conflicts with the WPA data and suggests that the postal map may not be completely accurate. The occupation at 41EL88 is estimated to date from 1895 to 1990. The removal of the original farmhouse, cattle tampling, and plowing have disturbed the integrity of this site. The area immediately surrounding the house may still maintain a good deal of integrity, but the serial occupation of this house detracts from the integrity of the deposits. Archival information indicates that J.C. Turner was a prominent local rancher and was an officer of the Ellis County Agricultural Extension Service. This site could potentially address Research Questions 10, 12, and 16. Since there are standing structures, there could be some intact deposits relating to Turner’s and earlier occupations. Further evaluations are recommended. 41EL89 (SSC-6-33) The site is located 900 meters south of FM 1446, 1.3 km east of Ewing Road. The site is on the Boz USGS Quadrangle Map. This site is located in the Placido Olivari survey (1-4811/2, A812), which was granted by the Bexar Land District on February 26, 1837. This grant was sold to Calvin Emmons on August 28, 1837. The actual land tract was surveyed in 1846. At that time the area was entirely prairie with two walnut trees observed along South Prong Creek at the eastern edge of the tract. The WPA file for this tract has been destroyed. Fieldwork conducted at this site included close interval (5 meter) pedestrian survey. All structures and surface features were closely examined, photographed, and mapped. This farmstead site (Figure 7-29) consists of a house (Plate 7-32) and modern well covering 3600 square meters with dump areas outside of the site limits. No barn or outbuildings are present. The entire area is densely vegctated, and this plus the large number of bees and wasps inhabiting the house, have made a closer survey difficult. The house is pine clapboard over sawn and milled pine studs, wit’. cut nails in the framing and wire nails in the clapboard. This house appears on the postal route map (ca. 1915) and the 1960 USGS map. It is not on any of the Ellis County highway maps even though it undoubtedly was present. Its location makes it impossible to see from the closest road, which may explain its absence from these maps. Initial construction is estimated to date to ca. 1890-1900 with a rear addition added at a later date, based on the milled pine lumber and cut and wire nails. The condition of the house, which is fair, and modern refuse indicate that the house was most likely occupied until approximately 20 years ago. The area surrounding the house has been used as a dump in recent years, with piping, sheet metal, a 1970s Ford Mustang II, and lumber making up the majority of discarded material. There is evidence for several episodes of burning of trash, and pits have been dug into bedrock to accommodate the refuse. Since there is standing architecture it is possible that this site does have some integrity. However, archival information indicates little historical significance. There is some potential to address Research Question 12. The site is classified as medium priority and further evaluation of the historical and archaeological contexts are recommended. 41EL91 (SSC-6-35) The site is 100 meters east of Ebenezer Road, 620 meters north of Tammy Lane. A legal suit between Stout and Randolph Townsend (4-25-1860), who was the heir to the Pena Survey through Nathaniel Townsend, ended in a judgement in Stout's favor. The WPA files for the Stout Survey have apparently been destroyed. The Searches and Researches of Ellis County (2, 3), which are on file at the Sims Library, mention Peter Stout. This information was reprinted in the Ennis Daily News (February 1978) and the Palmer Rustler Special Edition (1928): "Among the first to brave the hardships and privations in taking out homestead rights within a radius of 15 miles of Palmer, where Palmer now stands were Peter Stout, Solomon Barron, Al Stacks, Lambert Pace, Smith Greathouse, and a few others." (Palmer Rustler 1928) Fieldwork conducted at this site included close interval (5 meter) pedestrian survey. Diagnostic artifacts were examined and photographed and left in the field. The site is currently a moderately dense to dense historic artifact scatter totaling 5000 square meters, starting under a grove of hackberry trees and extending downslope. Artifacts include manganese solarized glass, cut nails, blue and green shell edge ceramics dating from 1840s to 1850s, tableware dating from the 1870s to 1880s, and hotel ware from the 1950s or 1960s. Intense twentieth century utilization of this site is indicated by the relative abundance of artifacts from this period observed. Structures are marked at this location on the postal route map (ca. 1915) and the 1941 and 1955 Ellis County highway map. Occupation is estimated to date from the middle of the nineteenth century to the middle of the twentieth century. This is most likely the original Peter Stout farmstead. It is known from census records that Stout moved from Tarrant County to Ellis County between 1850 and 1860 (Ellis County Genealogy Society 1985: 25) and the material culture corresponds to that period. Disturbances to the site include erosion of the site's northern fourth, some cattle trampling, and possible plowing, and it has had intensive twentieth century use, mixing the components. However, this site could have the potential to address questions about the pattern of settlement, marriage alliances, community formation, and material culture questions (Research Questions 9, 12, 13, and 16). It is located just outside the East Campus, but may suffer indirect impacts. It is classified as high priority, and further evaluations are recommended. 7-45

In fact, up to 2 meters of gravel has been spread in this area, potentially burying archaeological evidence of this mapped structure. It is possible that several buildings were present east and west of Hoyt Road. The Buena Vista School was shown on the 1901 map of Ellis County and may have been constructed at or just before the turn of the century. The postal route map (ca. 1915) and Ellis County highway maps from 1941 and 1955 show the school at this location. Mrs. Jennie Ruth Paul Tucker lived near this school. She reported that the Buena Vista School sat directly in what is today Hoyt Road, with a road to the east and around the west, both joining FM 1446. The eastern curve still remains, with a cistern adjacent to the east. The western curve is within the gravel stockpile area. The Buena Vista Methodist Church sat to the north and west of the western curve. A tabernacle (outdoor picnic area) was located north of the church, adjacent to the intermittent stream. Both the church and tabernacle are potentially buried under the gravel stockpile. No cemetery was located with this church, but a small store may have been present (Jennie Tucker, personal communication, 1990). Fieldwork conducted at this site included close interval (5 meter) pedestrian survey. All features were examined, photographed, and mapped. A single shovel test (35 x 35 x 10 cm) was placed 5 m south of the SSC-1 datum. Soil depth was only 10 cm, when bedrock was encountered. The intermittent stream has been incised into bedrock due to the intense flooding from adjacent fields. The profile in this area consists of a surface layer (0-25cm) of redeposited soil. From 25-40 cm, a lens of the gravel stockpile and a large concrete slab were present. This slab covers an original Eddy gravelly loam soil from 40-60 cm below the present ground surface. No artifacts were noted in this soil, which is located north of the tabernacle. Below this soil, a weathered chalk was encountered from 60-80 cm, which rested on bedrock. 7-46 J 3 = | == =

By the time of WPA survey in 1937, the Garrett Survey had been cut into over 69 parcels. These parcels have since been redivided. Fieldwork conducted at this site consisted of close interval (5 meter) pedestrian survey. All diagnostic artifacts were noted and described and their distributions were recorded. The site basically consists of a house foundation which is composed of concrete front and rear porch pads, concrete steps, and four concrete pier foundations. Ceramic tableware and decorative pieces found at the site date from the 1930s to the 1950s. Aduitional artifacts dating from 1890 to 1900 were found 20 meters west of the house site. arrived in New York City aboard the Rhenia in 1902. They initially filed for citizenship on January 24, 1911, nine years after their arrival. At the time of their filing, June 12, 1916, the family consisted of Joe, Jr., born October 1, 1907; Rosa, born January 20, 1909; Emma, born May 18, 1911; Jettie, born October 10, 1913; and Agnes, born April 8, 1916. Fieldwork conducted at this site consisted of close interval (5 meter) pedestrian survey. All structures and diagnostic artifacts were noted, described, and photographed. The site was plotted on the USGS quadrangle map, but no sketch map of the site was completed. Interviews were conducted with the present inhabitant (Jerry Dolezal) and the landowner (Robert Mitchell). The historic component at 41EL119 consists of a farm house (Plate 7-45), six outbuildings, two cisterns, and various pieces of horse-drawn farm equipment. The structural remains cover approximately 4000 square meters. The house is in fair condition while the outbuildings (Plate 7-46) and farm equipment have been better maintained and are in good condition. The one story frame house is cross-gable, reported by the previous owner to have been built around 1890. An addition was added to the front of the house around 1924. The siding and porch (part of the 1924 addition) have wire nails used in their construction. The outbuildings are all painted and were constructed with wire nails. A trash (recent) filled cistern sits at the southwest comer of the house and a second cistern is 40 meters to the south by the largest of the outbuildings. A wagon which was purchased in 1918 sits in the farmyard. This wagon is in excellent condition. Bottle glass, ceramics, and handmade brick were noted in the yard and around the outbuildings. A few pieces of stoneware were observed in the garden. The overall size of this component of this site is approximately 4000 square meters. Hardy-Heck-Moore (1990) also recorded this site (#978) during their survey of Ellis County. They recorded it as a one story house with an asymmetrical plan. The condition is stated as being poor and the date of construction is estimated to be 1900. No other structures are reported. Hardy-Heck-Moore (1990) gave this house high priority and consider it to be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. _ The current occupant of this house (Jerry Dolezal) stated that the house was “a hundred yvars old”. His brother Joe inherited the farm, and sold it to Mr. Mitchell. Jerry Dolezal currently operates the farm. The house is known to predate the 1917 purchase. This farmstead does not appear on the postal route map (ca. 1915) or the 1941 Ellis County map, but is on all other maps. The 1941 map is obviously in error, but this appears to be common for farmsteads located well off the road, such as this farm. All of the outbuildings are believed to have been built from 1917 to 1940. The largest barn at this site is reported to have been built using material from a previous farmstead that was located on this farm (41EL120), a set of structures tom down in 1917, The archaeological deposits, architectural remains, and historical and informant information all indicate that this site is important to the understanding of ethnic integration in the rural community (Research Question 14). The site was mapped and evaluated and a close interval (2 meter) pedestrian survey was conducted across the site. The stream bank provided over 200 meters of continuous soil profiles down to bedrock, and was closely examined. The Boz Cotton Gin was located at this site (Figure 7-43), which was both steam and electric powered. The complex was rather large and is estimated to have covered over 6000 square meters. Originally built as a steam-powered gin around 1900, it is believed to have been converted to electric or had additional electric facilities constructed by the 1930s. The three room gin office is still standing (Figure 7-44). It is a 6 x 6 meter wooden structure with a hip roof and wire nail construction. One corner beam has broken cut nails, evidence of recycling from an earlier structure. This structure probably dates from the electrification phase of the gin, around 1930. No other complete structure exists, but a cotton press and foundation, boiler base, coal bins, and wells still exist. The cotton press is still intact and could provide excellent information on this no-longer existent technology. Coal, commercial brick (1900-10), manganese solarized glass, and recent refuse are scattered about this 6000 square meter site. Impacts on this site have included the removal of structures, the construction of a modern septic system, and weathering. Approximately 50% of this site remains intact. This site has the potential to yield information relevant to Research Questions 10, 11, and 12, and is classified as high priority. Also, this is the only industrial facility identified in any of the impact areas and can provide pertinent information on early cotton gin technology and twentieth century technological innovations (e.g. steam to electricity). 41EL135 (SSC-5-30) The site is located 1.1 km south of FM 1446 and 550 meters northeast of Ewing Road. TABLE 8-1 THE NATIONAL REGISTER CRITERIA FOR SIGNIFICANCE The quality of significance in American history, architecture, archeology, and culture is present in districts, sites, buildings, structures, and objects that possess integrity of location, design, setting, materials, workmanship, feeling, and association, and: A. that are associated with events that have made a significant contribution to the broad patterns of our history; or B. that are associated with the lives or persons significant to our past; or C. that embody the distinctive characteristics of a type, period, or method of construction or that represent the work of a master, or that possess high artistic values, or that represent a significant and distinguishable entity whose components may lack individual distinction; or D. that have yielded, or may be likely to yield, information important in prehistory or history. Criteria Considerations and Exceptions Ordinarily cemeteries, birthplaces, or graves of historical figures, properties owned by religious institutions or used for religious purposes, structures that have been moved from their original locations, reconstructed historic buildings, properties primarily commemorative in nature, and properties that have achieved significance within the past 50 years shall not be considered eligible for the National Register. However, such properties will qualify if they are integral parts of districts that do meet the criteria or if they fall within the following categories: 1. a religious property deriving primary significance from architectural or artistic distinction or historical importance; or 2. a building or structure removed from its original location but which is significant primarily for architectural value, or which is the only surviving structure most importantly associated with a historic person or event; or 3. a birthplace or grave of a historical figure of outstanding importance if there is no other appropriate site or building directly associated with his or her productive life; or 4. a cemetery which derives its primary significance from graves of persons of transcendent importance, from distinctive design features, or from association with historic events; or — §-2

## Page 306

MAJOR RESULTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 8 An intensive archaeological and historical survey has been completed by Southern Methodist University for a large proportion of the lands and areas to be developed as part of the Superconducting Super Collider in Ellis County, Texas. As the previous chapters have indicated, this work has been focused on by Randall W. Moir, James M. Adovasio, and David H. Jumey specific, well defined tracts and parcels located within areas proposed to receive direct impacts or to be purchased in fee-simple or as easements. These studies by SMU have been conducted concurrently with another study by Hardy, Heck, and Moore, Inc., which has focused on architectural properties within all of Ellis County. The work by HHM consisted of a windshield survey which inventoried 3,714 structures in Ellis County and ranked them using a prioritization scale involving high, medium, and low priority categories for preliminary National Register Eligibility evaluations. A draft report covering HHM's work was received by SMU in July 1990, and pertinent information has been included in this report. A final report by HHM was received by SMU in October 1990 and information from it is currently being integrated into SMU's data base and site files. This chapter summarizes the major results of SMU's focused study on particular tracts and proposed project lands. Historic and archaeological properties greater than 50 years old and located within SMU's study areas were evaluated for their potential significance using National Register Criteria A, B, C and D. Table 8-1 provides these criteria and their definitions. Since HHM's study specifically focused on Criterion C but also included Criteria A, B, and to a lesser extent, D, this report deals most directly with Criteria A, B,.and D. Consequently, an archaeological property is reviewed not only for its artifactual contents but also for its association with significant events or broader patterns of events important to local and regional history, and finally for the importance of the people who lived or worked there. For prehistoric archaeological properties, Criterion A could include sites which may reflect band-based or more substantial population movements from the Brazos to the Trinity River drainages or from the High Plains to the East Texas woodlands when proper supporting evidence is identifiable. A Caddo mound site, for example, is also important under Criterion A as well as D. As these examples indicate, cultural properties may contain the variety of significance for their association with a particular event, place, setting, materials, or craftsmanship which goes beyond simply architecture or artifacts to embrace other qualities and entities important to a community's past and a region's history. This chapter reviews SMU's survey findings in regards to all four National Register Criteria and several sets of preliminary research questions useful for establishing contextual statements and evaluations (see Chapter 5). Recommendations presented here are naturally a direct result of the specific areas of significance 8-1 yy r fo

Finally, this chapter provides a brief overview of SMU's intensive survey of about 9635 acres. An additional 1100 acres of fee-simple purchase areas and 4740 acres, under which the ring and subsurface facilities will be located, remain to be surveyed. Specific research contexts are also reviewed to address properties considered eligible under Criteria A, B, C, and D. In addition, recommendations for further work and also for potential treatments are reviewed. In regards to data collection options, strategies for addressing historic ard prehistoric properties are also summarized. This chapter concludes with a listing of all the properties identified by SMU and some of those recorded by HHM to date that are located in the SSC's primary impact areas. A few land tracts as well as most of the ring have not been reconnoitered (totaling 5840 acres) to date and so the results given here do not cover areas where landowner permission has not been received or land access has been denied. West Campus The West Campus, located about 3.5 miles west of Waxahachie, is the largest single block of land to be acquired by the SSC, covering approximately 7500 acres. Forty-one archaeological properties (1 prehistoric, 40 historic) were recorded in approximately 6500 acres surveyed to date. The town of Boz, located in the West Campus, contains multiple historic resources which have not been fully recorded to date and would increase the number of historic properties by an estimated 10%. This number does not include another 10 (approximate) properties less than fifty years old, many of which have been addressed and duly noted by HHM (1990) in their comprehensive windshield survey of standing structures. While several more important archaeological and historical properties may emerge from the intensive survey of Boz itself, we do not expect, for the most part, any sizeable increase in high priority properties under Criteria A, B, C, or D. East Campus The East Campus, starting about two miles northwest of Ennis, is the second largest component of the SSC, covering approximately 1500 acres. It is much more linear in configuration than the West Campus (Figure 8-1). Twenty-eight archaeological sites (11 prehistoric, 1 prehistoric/historic, and 16 historic) were recorded in approximately 1000 acres surveyed to date. As these preliminary data revealed, archaeological sites seem to be more common in the East Campus area (1 site per 36 acres) than in the West Campus (1 site per 158 acres). This may be due in part to location or environmental setting. The West Campus is situated entirely on the Austin chalk uplands (600 to 700 ft amsl) where historic farmsteads tend to be larger and prehistoric sites are extremely rare. Historic farmsteads seem to be smaller with a greater emphasis on tenant farming in areas around the East Campus (400 to 500 ft amsl). Prehistoric sites are also much more common in the East Campus, possibly due to the presence of naturally occurring lithic sources (Uvalde gravels) used to make stone tools. Also, the larger drainages and presence of springs may have drawn prehistoric peoples, as well at the closer proximity to the Trinity River just to the east. Central Facility The Central Facility, located 2.5 miles east of Waxahachie, is the third largest land unit of the SSC which may be used in the future for ancillary support of the project. It covers approximately 450 acres and has both historic and prehistoric components. Its tract limits follow the nineteenth century boundaries of the Ellis County Work Farm (41EL58). The Uvalde gravels also cover this general area, and some cobbles appear to have been modified by human activities (knapping as well as plowing). The tract also contains 8-5

In all, seven sites (2 prehistoric, 5 historic) were recorded in approximately 1106 acres that were surveyed. « PRIMARY RESEARCH CONTEXT One of the primary research directions or overriding research framework behind the SSC archaeological and historical investigations is focused on human adaptations and human ecology of the Blackland Prairie in North Central Texas. While this focus for research and framework for property significance evaluations encompasses a broad array of historic and archaeological contexts, it does not eliminate the role that the National Register Criteria play in helping to identify significant properties. Instead, the human ecology research framework provides the fabric upon which individual threads or properties gain greater importance to our understanding of past peoples, places, periods, and events. The SSC project area is located in a major upland ecosystem known as the Blackland Prairies, which trend from northeast to southwest, and are flanked on both the east and west by very different ecosystems offering very different resources. Across the Blackland Prairies are major and minor tributaries which contain very different ecological resources than the adjacent upland blackland prairies and also offer both travel corridors as well as local obstructions depending upon seasonal conditions. ‘+ To the east of the SSC area, the Trinity River valley provides a zone of high biological potential. The Trinity River also served as a barrier to east-west travel, especially when flooded. Routes of travel were primarily north-south along the drainage divide of the Trinity and Brazos Rivers. The sediments which have been dumped into the Trinity River trench date through the Holocene into the Pleistocene. The forested Trinity bottomlands were the most extensive forested area in Ellis County. Narrower corridors of forested bottomlands projected westward along Chambers, Waxahachie, and Red Oak Creeks. The Trinity forest was composed primarily of post oak (20%), hackberry (16%) and ash (14%), and was conducive to the increased population of deer, wild turkey, bear, and other foragers of the forest. Also, seasonally available resources included waterfowl and fish. The Blackland Prairies located west of the Trinity forests range from gently rolling to level plains which were covered by dense tallgrasses throughout most, if not all of the Holocene and possibly portions 8-6 , —— = = > wd =

In the eastern and southern portions of the SSC, which lie within the blackland prairie zone, the valleys of Red Oak, Waxahachie, and Chambers Creeks were dominated by elm (30%) and hackberry (20%), with cottonwoods in lowlying or marshy areas. The portions of the upland blackland prairies fringing these stream valleys contained a transitional vegetation zone with saplings and mature trees dispersed within the tallgrass. Tree species included elm (27%), mesquite (23%), hackberry (16%), and cottonwood (11%). The lack of any substantial numbers of mast-producing oak trees provided a lower biomass for animal populations than in the Trinity floodplain forest. The majority of the West Campus falls in the medium to tallgrass prairie of the Austin Chalk. This was a relatively sparse environment with few water sources, primarily seasonal flow from surficial fissures. However some streams such as Greathouse Branch to the west did maintain water flow and the small floodplain contained mixed oak, pecan, and walnut forest. Therefore this vegetation zone undoubtedly atiracted deer, wild turkey and possibly small herds of bison. In Johnson County farther to the west, the Eastern Crosstimbers run north-south and was the nearest major forest to the west of the SSC. Even father west, the Brazos River supported a floodplain forest, but the dominant vegetation in this direction was prairie. Farther west of the Brazos Valley, the High Plains begins and contained shortgrass prairies and larger populations of herbivores. Consequently, the SSC project lands fall in a crucial ecosystem that itself forms a broad ecotone between deciduous forests to the east and shortgrass prairies to the west. Human use or lack of use of the SSC general area is both influenced by and a product of the Trinity prehistoric populations and those in adjacent areas. In this regard, even short term and low density lithic scatters potentially provide critical information on both transhumance and sedentism in a hinterland setting. Thus studies and research domains like those cited in Talmadge and Chessler (1977) have great applicability to research contexts and to the SSC National Register evaluations. Bottomland Versus Upland Studies The preliminary Research Questions outlined in Chapter 5 provide an empirical means of evaluating the potential eligibility of each site for nomination to the National Register of Historic Places. Also, the nature and contents of each site can be evaluated against their potential to address each Research Question. These Research Questions are not meant to be rigid, and will be refined and focused as more information is received from each site. The location of the SSC project area is quite different than the reservoir projects from which most of the prehistoric and historic archaeological evidence has been recovered in North Central Texas. In contrast to the previous studies, nearly universally conducted in lowland and generally better watered settings, the SSC area allows examination of a very different facet of human adaptation that is not possible in large scale Reservoir projects. Prehistoric archaeological sites in lowland settings which normally receive the greatest research attention, and which are usually considered National Register eligible, are in many cases “artifact mines” representing many different occupations by multiple generations and for ethnic/cultural groups, although some stratified alluvial sites are coming to light & North Central Texas. Unfortunately, the term "marginal" has assumed negative connotations in CRM planning where none are actually implied by that label sui generis. We stress that by marginal, we are employing the term in a non- pejorative, strictly archaeological sense and are referring to a state or condition in which the apparent prehistoric and historic record of the study area is simply outside of or more accurately, peripheral to the mainstream of socio-cultural development as known elsewhere in adjacent portions of Texas. Put another way, marginality of and by itself is neither "good" nor "bad", “significant” nor “insignificant”. It is a condition or state which the vast majority of the world's archaeological and historic sites occupy yet marginality per se is a poorly studied phenomenon archaeologically or historically. ‘¢ In the specific context of the SSC study area, marginality describes a condition or set cf interactive conditions in which both the archaeological manifestations and the geoarchaeological settings in which they occur are different in degree and kind from their counterparts to the north and southwest and east. The sites, as noted above, are ephemeral and seem to reflect on the basis of surficial materials, transient utilization by highly mobile groups for short periods of time. Moreover, the array of distinct behavioral sets reflected by these sites seems, again on the basis of surface remains, to be highly circumscribed. It is, in our view, highly significant that several large scale and small scale projects recently executed in CRM contexts rather precisely address the issue of marginality both methodologically and theoretically. Moreover, it is useful in the context of this discussion that one of the principal investigators of several of those projects is also now an active participant in the SSC project. eS: = as CS) acum

t C7 ZT mE Comparative Studies in Marginality Recent CRM studies which have thoroughly addressed the archaeology of marginal areas include the massive Nashville District Corps of Engineers efforts in the Tennessee Tombigbee Waterway, the Huntington District Corps of Engineers studies in the Paintsville Lake Reservoir Area of Kentucky (Adovasio 1982) and the U.S. Forest Service multidisciplinary research in the Badlands of North Dakota. Individual smaller scale projects with similar goals notably include SMU's Joe Pool Lake project and parts of the Richland Creek project as well as the University of Pittsburgh investigations in Berks County, Pennsylvania. In all of these cases, the archaeological (and historical) sites and complexes identified and examined lay well outside of so-called "mainstream" developments in their respective regions. Moreover, most of the individual sites in all of these peripheral areas were at first glance as apparently "insignificant" as many of those identified to date in the SSC project area. This is especially true in the Paintsville Reservoir, North Dakota and Berks County situations cited above. The Paintsville Reservoir in Johnson and Morgan Counties, eastern Kentucky is even today a remote region physically isolated from the major tributary valleys like the Ohio River adjacent to it. However, the entire occupational sequence now known in this portion of the midwest is represented within the Reservoir boundaries at best by sites far less extensive and/or spectacular than their chronological peers nearby. Careful examination of selected sites and site types of all time periods allowed for the development of tightly controlled local chronology as well as for the elucidation of a wide array of cultural and behavioral patterns of groups operating in the "boondocks" of the midwest (Adovasio 1982). A broadly similar situation was evidenced in the Mackenzie County Badlands of North Dakota where "conventional wisdom" dismissed the possibility of significant archaeological sites and suggested instead that no long-term human occupation, utilization or even transit corridor ever characterized this extremely inhospitable region during the bulk of the Holocene. It is significant in this context that this picture of the Badlands exhibits certain broad characteristics not unlike those evidenced in the SSC study area. The Mackenzie County Badlands are an upland region, generally poorly watered, heavily dissected and with substantially fewer resources than the major river valleys on its periphery. However, like the SSC project area there are significant lithic resources in the form of local gravel veneers. Phase 1 research in this area conducted under the auspices of U.S. Forest Service and explicitly aimed at the location of low visibility, ephemeral sites, resulted in the location of hundreds of individual, predominantly single component loci which in overall size and properties clearly approximate many of those in the SSC study area, Rather than ignore these seemingly insignificant loci, the Forest Service mandated detailed scrutiny of many of them. This examination included instrument plotting of surface artifacts with attendant collection of the mapped artifacts followed by extensive shovel probing and ultimately the emplacement of numerous randomized test excavations at each selected locus. In the Berks County situation, a relatively small (29m by 50m) and quite unobtrusive lithic scatter lying in the right of way of a Texas Eastern Gas Company pipeline was intensively examined both in the field and the laboratory and yielded invaluable data on a class of site which until that time had been ignored completely in local archaeological research designs. Berks County, like Johnson and Morgan Counties, Kentucky, and the Dakota Badlands is clearly on the fringes of major developments in the Archaic and Woodland periods of local prehistory but its investigation shed much light on the role of less preferred habitats in the activities of aboriginal hunter-gatherers in the greater Schuykill drainage of Pennsylvania (East et al. 1989). + Another example of intensive and productive archaeological investigations of marginal upland sites is Windy Ridge, a Middle Archaic site in South Carolina (House and Wogaman 1978). This site has no vertical stratification, but sampling and block excavations (point plotting of artifacts) yielded firm evidence of clustering ranging from casual loci where one or two cores were worked to relatively intense clusters of projectile points and tools of Morrow Mountain affiliation. At Windy Ridge, Archaic groups apparently used the site as a location for refurbishing their tool kits, leaving broken and resharpened tools and removing desirable raw materials (John House, Arkansas Archeological Survey, personal communication 1990). In the Southwest, archaeologists (Carmichael 1985; Cordell et al 1987; Johnson and Upham1986) have recently begun to focus on sites associated with mobile hunter-gatherers, which have been generally overlooked in favor of more obtrusive remains associated with sedentary populations. Upham (1988:245- 261) presents two examples of surveys in the Colorado Plateau region where limited activity sites (i.e., marginal) were systematically recorded and investigated. The results of these studies show radically different adaptive stragegies than previously supposed. The tempo of cultural development appears to be episodic, punctuated by periods of rapid cultural change, where large groups of mobile hunter-gatherers were assimilated into sedentary lifeways, and concludes that low visibility or marginal remains must be investigated along with more obtrusive sites in order to fully explain regional occupational pattems (Upham 1988:257-258). This approach augments the phase-based approach to cultural-historical reconstruction currently employed in archaeology and emphasises the heterogenous nature of local and regional settlement patterns. The importance of small, surface, and other marginal types of prehistoric sites, is unquestioned in order for archaeology to explore the full dimensions of past human experience. Also, since small sites often represent “instant” archaeological time (Mosely and Mackey 1972) where assemblages may be relatively pure and unmixed by subsequent occupations, limited activity sites can be helpful in delineating culturally 8-10

Specific research issues and suggested methodologies are detailed below. ORIENTATION FOR PREHISTORIC RESEARCH The prehistoric research questions for the SSC area originally articulated in Chapter 5 as well as the broader issue of marginality discussed here and the potential ability of the SSC sites to address them are presently hampered by the lack of surface collections or any detailed stratigraphic data from any of the identified sites. Resolution of these questions is also severely constrained by the fact that substantial portions of the "ring" area have not yet been systematically examined. Moreover, there is a distinct possibility that buried archaeological sites with no surface components exist in portions of the study area where aggredation has demonstrably occurred. To date, none of these localities has been invasively probed either to delimit sites or buried paleosols or their episodically stable surfaces. As a result, our present site sample must be considered presently unrepresentative of the full suite of archaeological resources which may exist in the study area. ° In all, thirteen prehistoric sites and two multicomponent prehistoric/historic sites have been recorded in the SSC project area. These range from isolated finds to light scatters of chipping debris and broken tools. Artifacts noted include broken dart points and tools made from non-local cherts. Based on the fragmentary items, some of the dart points may date from the Early or Middle Archaic. Six sites (41EL98, 41EL99, 41EL110, 41EL116, 41EL119, and 41EL127) have yielded sufficiently large and variegated assemblages to provide information on individual site use, differential occupation of the region through time, prehistoric 8-11 shove! a +e ted .

Also, certain types of materials may have been removed from the Uvalde veneer gravels, and it may be possible to model what types of materials were seledea by prehistoric groups through time. Finally some lithic materials are definitely nonlocal in origin. The use of nonlocal cherts suggests (1) that groups (or bands) were engaged in long range movements which took them to sources of cherts such as the Red River or Brazos River, or (2) nonlocal cherts and possibly tools were being exchanged as a part of broader regional systems of reciprocity involving several groups (bands) who most likely (but not necessarily) spoke similar languages. Secondary Research Questions for the prehistoric period have been included for additional comparison of archaeological properties, but further information will be necessary to evaluate each site's potential to address them. The presence of bison requires preservation of faunal remains in datable contexts. Sites which could potentially address the use of bison include 41EL110 and 41EL116. As discussed in Chapter 5, bison remains have been recovered from riverine contexts within 50 miles of the SSC and similar deposits may be present in those floodplain areas of Big Onion and Red Oak Creeks which will be impacted. by penetration shafts. Sites in depositional settings which may have protected archaeological remains include 41EL96, 41EL97, 41EL99, and 41EL110. These areas have received alluvial and/or colluvial deposition and stratified deposits may be present. Also historic land modification processes may have buried the original prehistoric landscape. Additionally, a systematic geologically and geomorphologically based deep testing plan should be initiated to address the identification of buried sites in these SSC contexts. The distribution of all prehistoric sites will be evaluated against the presettlement vegetation for Ellis County. ORIENTATION FOR HISTORIC RESEARCH Studies of upland historic sites have also been relatively limited in Texas, with the major focus again from Reservoir projects (Moir and Jumey 1987; Jumey and Moir 1987; Jumey et al 1988). In some lignite mines, a limited number of historic farmsteads have recently received attention. Over the last decade historical archaeologists have conducted multidisciplinary approaches to the study of the recent past that involve many disciplines and alleviate any weaknesses inherent in a single field. For instance, cultural geographers have employed strict diffusionist paradigms and closed system models in their mapping of cultural areas, overlooking the fact that culture is an open social system (Green and Perlman 1985:6). Architectural historians focus on floorplans and ornamental details to establish dates of construction that in actuality denote periods of popularity. Often integral contruction technology and the over physical and historical context is overlooked in such attempts at absolute dating. Oral history is a valuable method of providing humanistic details about cultural properties or study regions, but these depend on the quality of mental recall, cultural biases of the informants, and after-the-fact perceptions of preceeding events or circumstances. History is totally dependent on the written record, which is frequently non-comprehensive in scope, dependent on the personal record (e.g., many deed records and tax rolls have bumed along with courthouses), and biased toward the history of socially prominent individuals. For instance, Carlson (1983), in the urban investigation of the Richard Carter family many types of documents that allowed the reconstruction of a fuller family profile. For tenant farmers, many ethnic minorities, and even some landowners (¢.g., the history of the Mingo Burleson family in Richland Creek; Jurney and Moir 1987), such a complete family history is lacking or is fragmentary. The investigations proposed for the significant historic cultural resources within the SSC will attempt to minimize the weaknesses of these disciplines and instead maximize their strengths through a synergistic approach. Dendrochronology, for instance, will be employed to determine the dates of construction of buildings as well as remodeling episodes. This information will then be compared to deed, tax, and census records, along with oral history and architectural analysis to reach a more comprenhensive picture of the historical context for a given property. Archaeological investigations will supplement this approach to determine if a structure has always served as a domicile or if it has always been at the present location. This approach, employing nonarchaeological professionals and multiple lines of evidence, is a dynamic method which will allow proper coordination of research necessary to apply federal guidelines in cultural 8-13

OPTIONS FOR SSC RESEARCH DOMAINS In the short view, the archaeological and historic survey of the Superconducting Supercollider Study Area has been very informative. The great majority of the impact zones and easements have been examined and based on non-invasive scrutiny, a large "sample" of potentially representative historic and prehistoric sites have been identified. However, as so-called "traditional" and CRM archaeological consensus dictates, the present effort represents only a first step not an end product in a much more involved research and mitigative undertaking. Since much of the SSC involves "marginal" types of resources these next steps are not expected to be overwhelming but do require a well-founded approach. = This well-founded approach requires us to look closely at the types of cultural and environmental resources present and match them with the necessary applied technology available to recover data pertinent to the research design. Perceiving the research potentials of SSC upland sites literally means maximizing their informational value. The SSC sitesShould be explored with cost-effective state-of-the-art methods to produce a series of data sets which will add immensly to Texas archaeolo d equally implement the letter and spirit of Federal and State cultural resource management legislations. The overall research strategy and specific excavation methods proposed below, in conjunction with detailed analysis, integration, synthesis, and publication of results of materials will accomplish these CRM goals. In so doing, a significant increment will be added to the corpus of Texas prehistory and history and hopefully a model of how such upland site characterizations and mitigative efforts can proceed in the future will emerge. Not all of the techniques presented below wil be needed or required to pursue SSC research domains. a Es a ee fe 1 , Geoarchaeological Analysis An in-depth understanding of the regional geology is necessary for the proposed research. First, it is essential to reconstruct the study area's physical and environmental setting during the period(s) of aboriginal occupation. This will involve a detailed reconstruction of the topographic setting of each site to be excavated, and as far as possible, a reconstruction of the paleohydrology for the purpose of estimating not only water resources available to the occupants but also the effects of water related site degradation. Second, it is necessary to develop an inventory of the locally available geological resources. This will allow for an analysis of the sources of lithic materials, sources for ceramic paste and temper, and availability of any structural building materials. The establishment of the region's topographic setting during the time of its aboriginal occupation is critical in ‘determining whether erosional and/or climatic changes contributed to the termination or modification of any part of the cultural sequence (Donahue 1985). Establishment of a reference collection of local rock and soil types is important in determining the province of artifactual raw materials, especially lithics and ceramics, as well as that of any structural building materials. Lithic Analysis We plan to characterize the range of@ay-recovered)lithic material in terms of mineralogy and rock type and to establish whether any "exotic" lithic materials exist within the study area (Banks 1990), and if so, to determine their probable province and methods of acquisition. We also wish to ascertain whether the lithic resources have been heat-treated to improve their knapping qualities. The Uvalde gravels, which are the principal local lithic raw materials, have not been systematically mapped or described (Banks 1990). Two general methods will be used to characterize lithic resources. First, thin sections of representative samples will be prepared for examination with the petrographic microscope. In addition, thin sections of possible source materials will be made. Second, the mineralogy and elemental composition of different lithic types will be determined using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and atomic absorption (AA). Where necessary, computer controlled scanning electron microscopy (CCSEM) and electron micro-probe analysis will be utilized. The exact number of all of these analyses that will be required shall be determined by individual work orders. These analyses will allow us to characterize the range of utilized lithic resources. They will also potentially allow the determination of internal and external trade/exchange patterns, In addition, petrographic and XRD examination should allow us to determine whether heat treatment was employed in the manufacture of lithic artifacts, the nature of the heat treatment, and what effect this treatment had on the flaking or knapping properties of lithic raw materials. Finally, lithic materials will be heated experimentally and the results of these treatments will be compared with the artifacts and the source material. 8-17

The results of morphological analysis will be intégrated with those from the technological and functional analyses to establish the extent to which tool form may have affected or was affected by tool use and the processes by which such tools are made. The database built up via such comparisons is useful in establishing technomorphological types for all categories of worked/shaped flaked stone and ground stone implements. Technomorphological types, in turn, can be used to investigate spatial and temporal variability among different lithic activity sets, these are lithic tool types which most frequently are found together and therefore covary over time and space. Lithic activity sets, in turn, are important indications of the aboriginal human behaviors which created or used these tool sets in culturally defined ways. Lithic analysis, therefore, is a means for understanding a cultural system. Technological Analysis As previously indicated, technological analysis will be conducted for the entire drawn sample of flaked stone and for all ground stone artifacts from excavations in the study area. All of the sampled unmodified debitage, cores and core fragments, utilized flakes, worked/shaped flaked stone implements, and all complete and fragmentary ground stone artifacts will be analyzed to identify the full range of lithic technological variability represented within the site assemblages. Both continuous and discrete technological attribute sets for identifying flaked stone and ground stone tool modification and reduction processes will be assessed. Attributes ranging from raw material acquisition, or its entry into the aboriginal lithic technology "system," to patterns of implement discard or presumed loss will be recorded. Patterns of lithic raw material procurement and preference, processes of primary and secondary raw material reduction, stages of tool manufacture, patterns of breakage, the range of manufacturing techniques employed, patterns of international heat treatment (e.g., is heat treatment used with only particular raw material types?), as well as patterns of tool rejuvenation, reworking, and discard will be assessed using standardized sheets. The proposed analysis of the unmodified lithic debitage utilizes many variables (including flake size) that are sensitive to and reflective of the general process of flaked stone reduction. Specific factors affecting flaked stone tool manufacture will be evaluated which have been shown in other studies to correlate with specific aspects of human behavior (e.g., tool rejuvenation). Finally, the proposed technological analysis of flaked stone artifacts from the study area will include an investigation of the effects of intentional heat treatment on the flaking or knapping properties of chert and other lithic raw material. As a last step in this phase of the lithic analysis, samples from the archaeological sites that appear to have been heat treated will be scrutinized using the same scientific methods of investigation. This step will permit comparison of aboriginally treated and laboratory treated lithic material. These analytical methods may help to determine whether putative thermally altered lithics in the archaeological assemblage were, in fact, aboriginally heat-treated and, if so, under what conditions such treatment was carried out. Replication and comparison with archaeological specimens should enhance knowledge about the exact physical changes that occur within these lithic raw materials that facilitate knapping. Results of the technological attribute analysis will, of course, be incorporated with those from the morphological and functional analyses to determine the extent to which strictly technological parameters affect or condition final tool appearance and the functional capabilities of lithic artifacts. Demonstrated changes or adaptations in lithic tool technology will be assessed for how they covary with changes in tool morphology and function for each site component. Functional Analysis A functional analysis will be conducted for all of the identified flaked stone technomorphological types (including worked/shaped implements, utilized flakes, cores and core fragments, and apparently unmodified debitage), For the most common flaked stone tool types, a subsample will be drawn for functional analysis. For less common types, all examples in the original sample will be analyzed. Functional anclysis will be conducted for all of the selected ground stone artifacts. The primary goal of this analysis is to establish the ways in which components of the lithic assemblage were utilized aboriginally. This can be accomplished by examining macrowear and microwear patterns and by blood antigen analysis. Examination of stone tool edges for blood antigen residues is a new technique in lithic use-wear analysis (Loy 1983; Downs 1985; Yohe et al. in press; Hyland, Tersak, Adovasio, and Siegel 1990). Blood antigen is relatively resistant and is more likely to be preserved in dry microenvironments and/or within a clay-rich soil matrix. Given favorable preservation, the technique is not constrained by the duration of an artifact's deposition. All requisite instrumentation and technical expertise for performing this type of - analysis are available. Functional attribute analysis of the flaked stone artifacts and a portion of the ground stone artifacts will examine patterns of use-wear variability along the edges and surfaces of selected artifact types (e.g., 8-20 ane) E cS paws) CS

Replicative Experimentation Experiments in lithic replication will be conducted to understand better the stylistic, technological, and functional variability in the lithic assemblages from each of the sites. A lithic raw material sample of considerable mass and mineralogical diversity (representing all known chert vareities utilized prehistorically in the study area) will be required to execute the proposed replicative studies (see Geoarchaeological Analysis). It is currently expected, though not rigidly assumed, that two major lithic reduction processes will be represented in the artifact samples: opportunistic (i.e., prepared) core reduction and biface manufacture. Each of these manufacturing pathways will be studied through replication experiments. Replicative cores of the most commonly utilized raw material varieties will be decorticated. These cores will be prepared (i.e., proper core morphology will be established and maintained) and reduced to primary and secondary unmodified flake debitage in the ways suggested by analysis of each component of the archaeological assemblage (e.g., direct freehand percussion, indirect percussion, "hard-hammer" and “soft-hammer"/billet flake removal, etc.). In each instance, the resulting unmodified debitage should produce comparable data on prepared core reduction techniques for each cultural/technological "tradition" represented in the archaeological collections. How these technologies changed or maintained stability over time will also be investigated. Data on “artisan errors” (Muto 1971:59-63), overshot terminations, feather-to-hinge/step fracture termination ratios, and lithic raw material quality will be compared carefully with archaeological samples to understand the maintenance, decline, or improvement in aboriginal flintworking expertise over time and throughout the study area, Idiosyncratic or “signature” pieces from the archaeological collections may or may not point to similarities among the aboriginal human populations who occupied the study area sites. Finished and unfinished worked/shaped lithic implements, cores and core fragments, and unmodified pieces of debitage from various raw materials (some heat treated) will be employed experimentally. The interrelationship between tool raw material, shape, the nature of the material worked by the stone tool, work direction, manner and duration of working, etc., will be examined. These factors combine to produce observed macroscopic and microscopic patterns of use-wear on the tools. Tool functions within the archaeological samples therefore can be inductively studied by examining similar patterns of use- wear on replicated specimens. The anticipated result is that at least some specific prehistoric functional activities for stone tools (e.g., cutting wood, bone, or meat; scraping wood or hide; piercing hard or soft materials; etc.) may be identifiable at one or more of the sites as well as within particular areas at each site that may have served job-specific functions. In the proposed lithic analysis, statistical techniques whose strengths lie in searching for artifact patterns rather than in testing hypotheses will be employed. A thorough statistical exploration for the kinds of patterns of variability to be sought will require the application of several techniques and variants of them. K-means clustering is one technique well-suited to this task. In applying K-means clustering, the same entities that form the units of ‘sampling design (i.e., the assemblages, component by component and site by site) will form the basic. assemblage units. The frequencies of the various artifact types in these assemblages will form the basis for measuring differences among the artifact types, which are the entities to be clustered. The end product of such a K-means clustering is, of course, a series of sets of artifacts whose frequencies in different assemblages covary. A different approach, which is sometimes more successful in delineating the kinds of patterns sought in this analysis, is nonmetric multidimensional scaling. As in K-means clustering, the artifact types form the cases in the analysis, and differences between them are measured on the basis of their frequencies in the different assemblages. A wide variety of similarity or dissimilarity measures can be employed, however, making it possible to avoid undesirable effects sometimes involved in the application of Euclidean distance to certain data sets. Nonmetric multidimensional scaling also makes no assumptions about the nature of the metrics involved in measuring similarities between artifact types. The results are readily displayed graphically in two or more dimensions and often make it possible to screen out variability deriving from sources not relevant to the interassemblage variability analysis. Graphic displays of results can be examined visually, of course, for various kinds of patterning, including a tendency for artifacts to group into sets. Such sets can be defined, and the probabilities of their “reality” as sets also can be evaluated by further analysis of the geometry of the point configurations which are the results of the scaling. Both K-means clustering and nonmetric multidimensional scaling, then, are ideally suited to the Statistical exploration of a data set composed of frequencies of artifacts in different assemblages. Both analytical methods provide systematic ways of isolating sets of artifacts whose frequencies covary; this is, of course, the kind of result that archaeologists ordinarily expect of such analysis, for it provides a systematic view of what ordinarily are presented as individual artifact “types.” Both methods also provide indications of the extent to which such a result (i.e., the identification of artifact sets or clusters) is an accurate and complete reflection of the patterns of variability in the data. These methods also provide the means for the analysis of large numbers of cases, unlike many clustering techniques. Finally, and principally through the graphic and geometric representation of results, both forms of statistical analysis make it easy to examine other aspects of patterning in the data, such as the internal structure of the clusters identified and ambiguous or multiple-cluster membership exhibited by particular artifact types. The flaked stone analysis simultaneously deals with variability among sites as well as variability through time at the level of chronological components. The study of such variability within components at individual sites will be based on the provenience units where material was piece-plotted during the fieldwork. Form and Function It is possible that some of the sites recorded to date may yield ceramic remains. The first goal of the proposed research for any ceramic analysis is to utilize a methodological protocal for interpreting site function from ceramic assemblages. Using ceramic collections obtained from the fieldwork, a formal- functional analysis will provide the basis for an interpretation of site use at the regional level. Two problem areas is particular will be addressed in the proposed work: 1) the recognition of the patterns of production and distribution of any recovered types; 2) the definition of patterns of functional variability in ceramic assemblages from site to site within the universe of sites to be examined. Each of these topics is further discussed and developed in the remainder of this proposal section. Patterns of Production and Distribution of Ceramics Problem-oriented research in the study of contemporary aboriginal ceramics is among the most significant of archaeological endeavors as it combines the results of physical methods of analysis with more traditional typological studies. The ultimate objectives of these holistic inquiries is to leam more about the potter, the user of the potter's wares, the level of aboriginal technical command of the ceramic medium, and the sources of clay and temper. One example of the applicability of such studies can be seen in the American Southwest, where the ceramics of the Salado culture of Arizona are now being examined and the data are being assessed for evidence of patterns of extra regional cultural interaction. For example, painted ceramics of the Salado series have been identified throughout Arizona, as well as western New Mexico and northern Mexico. This widespread distribution often has been interpreted as representing evidence for extensive trade networks with the Salado area. This interpretation contains two critical assumptions: 1) that Salado ceramics occurring outside the Salado “heartland” are nonlocal in origin; 2) that the area of greatest abundance of Salado ceramics (i.e., the Salado “heartland") was the nexus of production, if not distribution. Compositional analyses suggest, however, that both of these assumptions may be wrong. Contrary to the first assumption are several compositional analyses that suggest that local production of Salado ceramics may not be ruled out, even in areas lying outside the Salado "heartland" (e.g., Martin and Rinaldo 1960). Contrary to the second assumption is the finding that even within the Salado “heartland,” the presence of several production areas is indicated, and, further, that abundance may not necessarily be a good indicator of local production. Further research on patterns in the production and distribution of Salado ceramics is therefore needed in order to answer some basic questions about trade and exchange, and to assess the implication of this data in the analysis of regional and inter-regional interaction in the SSC area. As is true of the Salado culture, the proposed project in the SSC area affords an unprecedented opportunity to refine further our interpretations of the production and distribution of various wares 8-25

They have further recognized that the traditional bipartite site types of "habitation" vs "limited activity" are of little use in understanding the range of activities conducted at ceramic bearing archaeological sites. The analysis of functional variability in ceramic assemblages is an important interpretive method for understanding variability in the use of sites, both within and between regions. The most common approaches have included the use of bowl/ar ratios (e.g., Acklen 1982; Goodyear 1975), the relative frequencies of general form and surface treatment variables (e.g., Doyel 1978a, 1978b, 1980; McAllister and Plog 1978; Mills 1986; Plog 1980; Sebastian 1983), and the variety or diversity of vessel classes present in an assemblage (e.g., Braun 1980; Pilles 1978; Powell 1984; Reid 1982). With few exceptions, these analyses have used a priori settlement types and have then looked at the correlation of ceramic assemblage variables with these types. The independent analysis of ceramic assemblages to help define differences in the use of sites has not been widely employed. Settlement types have been expressed in very general categories, such as habitation site vs. limited activity sites. These types, however, are based on a limited number of site attributes, such as the presence/absence of architecture or overall site size (Whittlesey and Reid 1982). In fact, one of the most interésting results of these previous studies has been the lack of clear correlations between ceramic assemblage variables and such basic settlement types as "habitation" or “limited activity.” These cases of incongruence among the archaeological expectations and the reality of the observations should have pointed out the need for a re-evaluation of methods. Specifically, analyses are needed that attempt to define site typologies on the basis of assemblage variables, and that then test these typologies against independent data. Such studies are notably rare. In any analytical program, the units of analysis should be appropriate to the problem under investigation. Ethnoarchaeological and ethnographic descriptions indicate that vessel morphology is a highly variable, yet universal indicator of ceramic vessel function. In other words, while the specific shapes and sizes of the vessels that are used for particular functions may vary between cultural groups, it can generally be inferred that vessel form is an important and useful means of identifying vessel function. The first research objective for understanding function, then, is to identify morphological classes of ceramics in the project study area. Using the ceramic classification developed in the first proposed step, the content of the project's ceramic assemblages will be characterized. The covariation of assemblage variables will be used to define assemblage groups that hypothetically reflect underlying and corresponding differences in the use of sites. Covariation in ceramic patterns with data on site features and lithic assemblages will then be tested. In order to investigate differences in site use, the independent analysis of ceramic assemblages has been incorporated into the research program proposed in this document. Methods for identifying functional types of ceramic vessels can be divided into five approaches: 1) morphology; 2) use-wear; 3) residues; 4) composition; 5) context. Definition of vessel classes based on morphology offers greatest consistency as each vessel has an overall morphology; however, this should be augmented by data available from other modes of analysis. General form, surface treatment, and metric data on size and shape together offer a level of functional specificity that can be justified from the ethnographic descriptions of vessel use at a general level. Also, these attributes are suited to fragmented vessels. In addition, these variables will be used to distinguish general functional categories among sherd collections, especially where the frequency of rim sherds is high. +Paralleling current interest in the study of lithic use-wear, studies of wear marks on ceramics have been conducted to identify patterning that can be attributed to vessel use (e.g., Bray 1982; Fenner 1977; Griffiths 1978). Residue analysis, including the visual evaluation of sooting or fire-blackening as well as chemical and microscopic analyses of deposits, has been the method most commonly used for differentiating cooking vessels from other vessel types (Acklen 1982; Doyel 1980; Nelson 1980; Hally 1983a). Phosphate (Duma 1972) and other chemical analyses (Condamin et al. 1976) also have been used to identify the previous contents of vessels. Both use-wear and residue analyses have advantages over approaches that stress variables of construction because they monitor actual use rather than intended use (Hally 1983b). Wear marks and residues are heterogeneously distributed over a ceramic vessel and often are restricted to certain parts of vessels, such as the bottom. The absence of diagostic sherd wear or residues therefore can be interpreted in two ways: 1) either the vessel was not used for the function producing the distinctive type of alteration, or 2) the sherd was not originally from the part of the vessel where these alterations are visible. - Compositional anlayses traditionally have been used for the interpretation of patterns of trade and exchange, but they can also be used to investigate ceramic function (Bishop et al. 1982). Ethnographic descriptions of ceramic production indicate that patterns in the selection and manipulation of raw materials - especially those of clay and temper - are often correlated with the intended function of the finished vessel (Amold 1971; Balfet 1965; DeGarmo 1975; Ericson et al. 1972; Matson 1951; Plog 1980; Reina and Hill 1978; Rye 1976, 1978; Shepard 1956). Borrowing approaches from the field of material science, many recent archaeological analyses have attempted to identify vessel function through an understanding of the selection and manipulation of raw materials (Braun 1982, 1983; Bronitsky 1984; DeAtley 1973; Mills 1984; Plog 1980; Raab 1973; Steponaitis 1983; Stone 1984). These methods have been used to identify specific physical properties, such as thermal shock resistance, porosity, and durability. There are two major problems with using compositional approaches to identify ceramic vessel function. First, very different patterns of raw material use may be present from one region to another (and possibly on an intraregional level) which may represent solutions to the same problem. Second, because of the hierarchy of technological problems, there may not 8-28

If the goal of the ceramic analysis is to look at patterning in the presence of different functional classes of vessels, it must be recognized that patterning in the selection and manipulation of raw materials may not reflect the same functional typologies identified through a reading of the ethnographic literature. The number of technological classes will usually be fewer than the number of functional classes, usually consisting of cookware vs. noncookware - too few classes for the meaningful study of ceramics at the level of the assemblage. The location or context of a ceramic vessel within a site also may offer potentially useful information on vessel function, but as ceramic vessels are less often found where used than where discarded, most inferences rooted in vessel deposition will be fortuitous rather than analytically rigorous, and they will depend upon unusual preservation conditions, such as the rapid burying of remains (cf. Braun 1981b). Returning to the first type of analysis used for the identification of ceramic function, the anlaysis of vessel form is one of the most commonly found in the archaeological literature. Despite long attention, formal-functional approaches have varied in their explicitness. Many studies have tended to assign functional identifications to formal classes based on an implicit, often analogical form of logic. This form of argument reasons that if a specific vessel form is used for a particular function in an ethnographically documented culture, then when that form occurs in an archaeological context, it may be inferred to have been used for the same function. This has been a common approach in the Southwest (e.g., Goodyear 1975) where there are cultural groups who have continuities with the archaeologically documented societies. The inferential basis for using formal-functional approaches has, however, become more explicit in recent years. Using Binford's (1965) distinction between primary and secondary functions, Ericson et al. (1972) noted several formal properties of ceramic vessels that may be related to the primary functions of pottery, viz., their use in the activities of preparing, cooking, storing, acquiring, and transporting various materials. More recent analyses include those that have used ethnographic data to develop expectations for formal-functional classes in subsequent archaeological analyses (Braun 1980; Hendrickson and McDonald 1983; Lischka 1978; Smith 1980, 1983, 1985). In these latter cases, cross-cultural regularities in the form of vessels used for specific functions, such as cooking, storage, or serving, have been sought and then applied to the analysis of archaeological collections. The goal of these analyses has been the identification of a particular morphological signature for each functional class that subsequently can be used to assign members to that class, The results of cross-cultural analyses of vessel form and function are interesting for several reasons. First, they have demonstrated that there are morphological regularities in the way that vessels are constructed for particular functions. They have shown the value of characterizing ceramic vessels in terms of their morphological properties for questions of a functional nature. Quantitative variables such as height, rim diameter, orifice diameter, volume, and ratios of these variables have been identified as useful measures for assigning ceramic vessels to functional classes (Henrickson and McDonald 1983; Smith 1980, 1983). By using ethnographic data to infer the presence of these general functional classes, these studies have 8-29
