Analysis of Assemblage Variability and Identification of Assemblage Classes This stage of analysis requires the use of the classes identified in the previous step. As rim sherds have the potential for more specific functional assignment, the analysis will proceed in two stages. The first stage will consist of the analysis of all sherds that are recovered using general form (e.g., bowl, jar, etc.) and surface treatment (e.g., slipped, unslipped) variables to distinguish categories. A variety of analytical techniques could be used at this stage, such as K-means cluster anlaysis of proportions of each category, in order to identify different assemblage types. The second stage of the assemblage analysis will involve comparison of the assemblage classes identified in the previous stage using rim sherds. Here, rim diameter, orifice diameter (if present), and angle of rim aversion will be employed to test whether vessel size and rim form differences are present between the different assemblage types. Alternatively, the rim sherd attributes may be included in the differentiation of assemblage types along with general form and surface treatment. The ultimate goal of these analyses is to identify significant differences among site ceramic assemblages that can be compared at a more synthetic level with other independent analyses of functional variability, such as those of lithic or site structures. Using ceramics in this way avoids a major problem present in most identifications of site function, that is, confirmation of predetermined site types. Flake Stone and Ground Stone Artifact Analysis Various forms of analysis are discussed below for the flaked and ground stone artifacts that may be recovered from any archaeological investigations within the SSC project area. Collectively, these analyses are designed to address morphological (i.e., stylistic), technological, and functional variability, as well as the chronological trends that are expressed at each of the previously recorded sites and associated archaeological remains. Traditionally, comprehensive analysis of many lithic assemblages from the Texas sites have minimized the importance of flaked stone artifacts as documents of human behavior. However, it has been demonstrated recently that answers to many relevant questions about the character of prehistoric communities can be derived from the study of recovered lithic materials (see Irwin-Williams and Shelley 1980; Shelley 1983; Linford 1986). To this end, formal analysis of lithic (flaked stone and ground stone) artifacts will be undertaken to develop and test hypotheses about the behavioral systems of prehistoric communities within the study area. The specific areas of inquiry for this aspect of the overall study, and those capable of reflecting behavioral variability with respect to lithic artifactual remains, include: 1) decisions about the selection of local lithic raw material resources (e.g., Ogallala quartzite), or material (cherts) from extralocal sources; 2) procurement and transportation of unmodified or partially worked materials to the communities; 3) trade or exchange of extralocal raw materials and/or distant raw material resource areas; 4) distribution of raw materials within the sites; 5) stages of production, and techniques involved in tool manufacture; 6) activity area analysis and prepared tool use pattern; 7) maintenance and refurbishing of implements; and ultimately, 8) mechanisms of deposition through breakage, loss, and discard of implements. The most difficult goal of any analysis of lithic artifacts is the identification of possible social inferences from the data. Therefore, a major assumption of this proposed study is that all material culture reflects, to some extent, the past behavior of human populations (Schiffer 1976). It then follows that the lithic assemblages, when properly studied, should reflect patterns of behavior among the aboriginal creators and users of those assemblages, The proposed lithic analyses for this project include three interrelated levels of investigation to address morphological, technological, and functional variability, and trends within the recovered lithic artifact inventories. Vertebrate and Invertebrate Faunal Remains The recovery, identification, and analysis of vertebrate and invertebrate faunal remains from the sites in the study area will follow standard procedures with the following exceptions (Dirkmaat 1982, in preparation a). Processing protocol, from the initial processing of remains in the field to the final analysis, is based on widely accepted methods (e.g., Chaplin 1971; Binford 1983; Klien and Cruz-Uribe 1984; Hesse and Wapnish 1985; Burch 1962, 1973; Pilsbury 1948) and is described below. “Preparation for the analysis of archaeologically derived vertebrate and invertebrate faunal material will first include a comprehensive review of archaeological and paleonotological site reports from late Quaternary/Holocene contexts in the project area. The range of vertebrate and invertebrate species commonly encountered in archaeological deposits, taxa unique to the area, and special research problems germane to the project area will be identified at this time. Descriptions of late Pleistocene and Holocene biotic communities (phytogeographic as well as zoogeographic distributions) in the area will also be prepared in order to provide an insight into the entire vertebrate assemblage available to the aboriginal inhabitants of the project area and to document changes in biotic distributions through time (see Dirkmaat 1989). Following the excavation and initial processing of vertebrate osteological and odontological remains and molluscan shell material, clean bone and molluscan shell specimens will be labeled according to site designation and accession number. The vertebrate faunal remains initially will be sorted into potentially identifiable and unidentifiable fragments. Potentially identifiable specimens will be described as completely as possible utilizing an analysis form in order to standardize observations. This analysis form will facilitate the recordation of the following information for every potentially identifiable bone fragment: 1) specific taxon represented; 2) bone; 3) bone portion; 4) side; 5) state of preservation; 6) age; 7) modifications present, and 8) number of spécimens, Separate analysis forms will detail bone modifications, pathologies, and metric data. > Taxon determinations will be made to the lowest taxonomic level possible, preferably to the level of species. Bone portion descriptions will be referenced according to the specimen’s exact anatomical position (e.g., proximal 1/2, anterior 2/3, etc.). Specific taxon and bone identifications will be facilitated by comparison to vertebrate osteological collections and by comparisons to descriptions and line drawings of individual skeletal and odontological elements presented in various osteological handbooks (e.g., Brainerd 1939; Glass 1951; Olsen 1967, 1968, 1973, 1979; Gilbert 1980; and Gilbert, Martin, and Savage 1981). Bone specimens that remain unidentified after these two identification phases will be compared to specimens ‘ curated at ARP. 8-32 Co

## Page 339

Eh Ss The study of the effects of preservation factors on the composition of the vertebrate assemblage will be aided by noting the general state of preservation of each bone specimen. Preservation assessments will include categories that range from “well-preserved” to "highly eroded.” The determination of age at death of individual bone specimens will be based on: 1) the state of epiphyseal union in post-cranial remains (employing categories that range from “unfused” to “fusing” to "fused'); and 2) dental development, including whether the dental fragments are deciduous or permanent teeth, the state of tooth root and crown enamel development, and the degree and pattern of occlusal enamel attrition (Silver 1969; Watson 1978; Wilson, Grigson, and Payne 1982). Data obtained concerning bone surface modifications will include the presence/absence of: 1) thermal alteration; 2) gnathic and gastric-induced modifications; 3) modifications incurred during the butchering process; and 4) pathologically-induced bone alterations. The coloration of bone specimens that have been thermally-altered will be noted, employing terms such as “bummed black” and “calcined white." These data will be utilized in conjunction with data on the state of preservation of the specimen in order to identify the processes by which the bone was thermally modified (e.g., by boiling or direct flame), as well as meat preparation methods. Bone surfaces will be carefully inspected for the presence of dentally-induced modifications including those produced by chewing of the specimen (usually by camivores), by gnawing (by rodents), and by swallowing of the entire fragment. This data will help identify bone reduction and fragmentation factors. A separate analysis form will be used to collect data on butchered and pathological specimens. Parameters used to identify and evaluate butchering evidence will follow procedures described in Guilday, Parmalee, and Tanner (1962); Lyman (1979); and Dirkmaat (in preparation c) and will include information concerning: 1) the implement used, based on the morphology of the cut or cutmarks; 2) exact anatomical position of butchering evidence; and 3) the exact orientation and direction of the cuts (in three planes). The representation of such evidence on schematic line drawings of skeletal elements will facilitate the analysis of the entire butchering process. Pathologically modified specimens will be described according to the exact anatomical location of the pathology and by the morphology of these afflicted areas. These detailed morphological descriptions in conjunction with photographic references available in the literature (Tyson and Dyer Alcauskas 1980; Ortner and Putschar 1981) will be utilized in an attempt to identify the etiology of all pathological conditions noted. Measurements obtained from the skeletal and odontological material will be included in a separate data analysis form and will used to identify sexual dimorphism in the sample. Metric parameters will follow definitions presented in von den Dreisch (1976). Unidentifiable bone specimens will be stored into class level taxonomic groupings and assigned to a size-related subset within this category (e.g., "Small Mammal, species?"). Evidence of modifications will be noted and the number of specimens in each category tabulated. 8-33

Human Remains Analysis The discovery, treatment, and analysis of human remains will be handled with utmost respect to the deceased and any potential descendants. All attempts will be made to discover lineal descendants and solicit their approval/disapproval of treatment options. The level of information potentially available in recovered human osteologic remains is directly proportional to the sophistication of the analytical techniques employed. During the past 25 years, archaeological reports containing descriptions of skeletal populations or individuals have moved from compilations of age, sex, stature, and race (skeletal inventories) to more elaborate attempts at reconstructing demographic pattems. These early studies relied on standards set by Krogman (1962). Presently, we can divide the types of information obtainable from skeletal remains into two major categories: 1) parameters of the individual, and 2) population decriptors. Often, the former, as distributions, are used in estimating the latter. From either complete of fragmentary remains, estimates can be made as to the age, sex, and stature of. an individual, The more material, the better the estimate. Recently, Holland (1986) has demonstrated that, based on remains of the cranial base alone, a correct sex estimate can be obtained with 71-90% accuracy. By examination of the gross morphology of the bones many pathological conditions can be detected, such as 8-34 Sa eisai)

Similarly, in addition to general morphological description, dental pathology (e.g., Clark et al. 1986) and dental wear can be assessed for the individual. With regard to the population, particularly when large numbers of individuals are involved, many estimates are possible. In the most recent of such studies, Morris (1986) reports data from Arizona which is limited mostly to category one while making an attempt at demographics. More sophisticated studies, though, attempt to correlate individual physical data with cultural inferences. For instance, distributions of age are used to produce estimates of "mean-age-at-death” and fertility levels Johannsson and Horowitz 1986), and sometimes can be related to changing subsistence patterns (e.g., introduction of agriculture at Dixon Mounds; Goodman and Armelagos 1985). From discrete skeletal traits and particularly dental characteristics (e.g., shoveled incisors and cusp pattern), the relatedness of populations or subsets of populations may also be assessed (Sofaer et al. 1986). Metric characteristics of teeth and bones, where bilateral structures are present, are used to determine the overall exposure of a population to stress for various time periods during its life cycle (Benyon and Siegel 1981; Brandt and Siegel 1978; Doyle and Johnston 1977; Doyle et al. 1977; Gest et al. 1983, 1986; Mooney and Siegel n.d., Mooney et al. 1985; Sciulli et al. 1979; Siegel and Doyle 1975a, 1975b, 1975c; Siegel et al. 1977a, 1977b; Siegel and Mooney 1986; Siegel and Smookler 1973; Smookler et al. 1973). Finally, information about diet is obtainable from dental wear patterns and analysis of bone composition with new techniques recently developed in both areas. Irish and Turner (1987) have defined wear of the surface of the front teeth .SAMAT) which can be related to processing of abrasive carbohydrates. Klepinger et al. (1986) have improved the reliability of elemental anlaysis relating bone chemistry to diet, and Price et al. (1986) have found differences in bone strontium between virgin and pregnant rats, which has direct application to demographic studies. Floral Analysis Analysis of any floral remains that may be recovered in the course of fieldwork is expected to provide ancilliary evidence for localized microenvironmental changes and adaptations - specifically, the changes and similarities in the human exploitation of food plants, as well as plants utilized for medicine or the aboriginal production of perishables. Macrobotanical and microbotanical studies are proposed as are pollen studies. The results of all three analytical approaches will be integrated to develop a comprehensive picture of aboriginal man’s exploitation of his floristic environment. Macrobotanical remains will augment paleoecological and paleoenvironmental studies by contributing data derived from the study of nuts, seeds, wood, charcoal, and other plant parts. Macrobotanical data, when interpreted in conjunction with microbotanical (pollen) information, will provide insight into the resource potential of prehistoric plant communities, as well as into prehistoric man's interactions with the overall character of his environment, 8-35

The work proposed for sites listed below includes further evaluations and in specific cases systematic surface collections and text excavations to refine the cultural-historical contexts at each site. Since many sites appear to consist of shallow deposits, horizontal separation of components may be possible through surface collections, which are a cost effective means of identifying the structure and integrity of plowed sites. In areas which seem to offer the potential for buried sites or where buried sites are actually known to occur, selective use of backhoe and trackhoe trenches or deep hand excavated 2 m x 2 m units should be initiated to identify, define, and delimit these occupations. Fundamental to any understanding of the distribution of archaeological and historic sites anywhere is the realization that human beings and, per force (by necessity), the loci of their activities are not randomly distributed ‘across the surface of the earth. Rather, the distribution of human beings and "their sites" is non- random in response to certain basic verities about human biological and cultural requirements and the satisfaction of those requirements at any time in any space. There is nothing profound or new about this observation but the design and execution of any archaeological investigation must operationally take this non-random distribution of human activities into account in every phase from reconnaissance survey, to testing and data recovery. No one factor or condition accounts for the non-random distribution of archaeological sites. Rather, it is the complex interaction of a whole series of parameters which must be, often tediously, extracted from the archaeological, geological, and environmental record of a given study area or portions thereof. Certain factors are, of course operative virtually anywhere humans have lived or still live. The presence of potable water, relatively level ground (slopes usually less than 15°), access to food resources, potential for shelter in inclement weather, available technological resources and raw materials are but a handful of the more basic conditions which influence site location in time and space. Of course, dozens of other environmental and cultural factors can be added including, where appropriate: access to arable land, defensibility, access to major and minor "avenues" of human movement, religious and ritual considerations, etc. The delineation of settlement pattems in any part of the SSC Project is therefore a process of determining which factors are operative in particular environments via the systematic scrutiny of representative samples of these environments. Both Dr. Brooks Elwood and Dr. James Adovasio have had considerable success with this technique in a wide variety of contexts and the use of resistivity meters has allowed the accurate delineation of such diverse phenomena as structures, hearths, storage pits, refuse pits, burials, activity areas and even small artifact concentrations. In high probability areas where deeply buried sites are suspected, backhoe trenches or deep piston cores will be employed to detect and delineate subsurface sites at greater depths. The spacing of trenches and/or piston-core probes will be determined as local circumstances dictate. ~Herein it should be forcefully stressed that in any low visibility area with high site potential, it is absolutely critical that subsurface probe intervals be as tightly spaced as possible. As Drennan (1988), Shott (1989), and Kintigh (1988) indicate, vastly differential recovery of sites occurs when probe intervals are substantially expanded. This in turn results in a highly skewed site sample which essentially “loses” small loci of “all functional" types. The so-called Drennan Interval Model has been field tested in thousands of miles of upland surveys and the results are indisputable. If the excavation is a testing operation, a fixed number of randomly selected 1 m2 (10.8 ft2) units will be emplaced in order to characterize the site. In data recovery or full scale excavations, local circumstances will determine whether random squares, continuous trenches or a judicious combination of both are appropriate excavation strategies. In either case, excavation of all sites will proceed by natural stratigraphic or micro-stratigraphic levels. Arbitrary 10 cm (3.9 in) levels will be employed within the excavation of natural strata greater than 10 cm (3.9 in) in thickness. Micro-stratigraphic profiles of at least one wall of each excavation unit or trench will be generated by hand or via a Leitz Set-2 Total Electronic Station. All excavation of culture bearing strata will be by hand. The fill from all culture bearing strata will be dry-screened through 3.2 mm (1/8 in) hardware cloth or, where this is not feasible due to soil properties, through 6.4 mm (1/4 in) hardware cloth. Additionally, in order to recover items smaller than these sizes, constant volume samples (CVS) measuring 3000 cm3 (183 in3) will be collected from every natural and arbitrary level identified on any site. These samples will be processed through graded sieves using an aqueous solution of hydrogen peroxide (HO) to facilitate recovery of small items. The use of hydrogen peroxide instead of water will minimize damage to charred organics, especially those which may be preserved in open site contexts, and will ensure representative recovery of thermally altered plant materials, etc. The use of hydrogen peroxide as a flotation medium precludes the necessity of agitation and hence damage to any organics as the solution functions as a high-level deflocculant. Artifacts and features identified on any structure or “living floor"/surface will be mapped in situ using the Leitz Set-2 Electronic Total Station and all features will be mapped and photographed in planview and profile. For most sites, the number of test pits excavated will range between 12 and 25 depending upon their areal extent, complexity, site history, and depth. The placement of test pits will provide a general sample of the numbers and types of artifacts, kinds of cultural strata or features, and integrity of subsurface deposits present at each site. Surface collections will be recovered from sites where this method will provide an efficient sampling approach. Test excavations and surface collecting will be directed toward identifying the occupational periods present, range of activities and site functions, historical and scientific importance, and National Register eligibility of the property. Test pits will be dug by natural or cultural stratigraphic units unless artifacts indicate mixed deposits or lack of component separation. A grid system will be established for those sites which contain potentially significant archaeological deposits or features. Systematic placement of test pits will be preferred unless site size, surface features, or age dictate a more efficient approach. Fieldwork will identify the limits of the site, presence and general frequency of cultural features, and major intrasite components and integrity. Generally, the fieldwork entails three to five crew days depending on the total area of the site. Sites with complicated occupational histories and with numerous buildings may require substantially more time. Other small scatters with few visible features may take less than one day, especially if they yield negative information regarding eligibility. One aspect of SMU's historical archaeological research has been the development of sensitive artifactual indicators of time that help to qualify actual construction/occupation dates for historical properties. Dendrochronology can provide absolute dates for initial construction and remodeling of houses and buildings, as well as the potential dating of artifacts such as gates or portable items made of wood. Tree rings also help provide an indication of how long a floodplain has been at its present level or how fast it may be aggrading by sampling the extant vegetation. Also, culturally induced vegetation (oak, cedar, pecan) and trees can be dated, thereby enlarging the data base for site occupation and use. Table 8-4 lists the recommended data recovery options for the historic archaeological sites recorded in the SSC project area. All properties will receive further historic, archival, and informant studies, to determine if previous occupants, occupation periods, socioeconomic, and ethnic affiliation and significant events can be determined. For instance, mapping and surface collection could be performed in .25 to 2.0 crew days per site, depending on scientific and historic importance, as well as the size and number of surface features. ## Page 349

i (41EL58, 41EL59, 41EL75, 41EL93, 41EL100, 41EL104, 41EL119, 41EL134) are judged high priority and are potentially eligible for intensive data recovery as well. An additional 22 (ranked as medium priority) of the 36 properties may require further studies to evaluate their National Register eligibility. A final six properties are listed as low priority, but low-level documentation may be necessary. Systematic testing to determine National Register eligibility is potentially necessary at 27 properties. Again, only 8 are listed as high priority, and 19 are currently medium priority. One site (41EL132) has not received sufficient examination (it was recorded from windshield survey) to determine if testing is required. Deep testing, to examine known features or buried deposits is not required of most historic sites since they are situated in shallow upland soils in non-agrading settings. The only deep testing (mechanical) will be to determine if intact deposits and structural remains are buried under the gravel stockpile at the Buena Vista Methodist Church and Tabernacle (41EL100). Also, the Boz cotton gin, (41EL134) located in the floodplain of Cottonwood Branch, has been landscaped over the 100 years of its existence, and may contain buried deposits or structural remains dating to earlier episodes in its history. Potential intensive data recovery, as mentioned above is thought to be necessary on only eight high priority sites. These are the Ellis County Farm (41EL58); the Boz Cotton Gin (41EL134), the Buena Vista Methodist Church and Tabernacle (41EL 100); and farmstead sites 41EL59, 41EL75, 41EL93, 41EL104, and 41EL119. This level of work, of course, is dependent upon the results of the mapping and surface collection, systematic testing, and deep testing phases of mitigative options and consultation with the SHPO. All historic improvements (fences, wells, cisterns, structures, stock tanks, etc.) will be eliminated from the landscape prior to the construction of the SSC. Historic wells and cisterns (some partially filled with rubbish, others still in use) will be filled. This provides a unique opportunity to document and investigate the technologies and strategies involved with water use in the project area. For instance, in the chalk rock, large chambers appear to have been dug for seep wells; while in the Taylor Marl, brick lined wells and cisterns were the only feasible means of obtaining water. All sites with wells should receive basic documentation (size, depth, water draw) prior to their destruction. Other levels of documentation that could be performed on sites include the collection of dendrochronological samples from standing or ruined buildings and archaeological contexts. Dendrochronological samples have been obtained from buildings adjacent to the SSC project area and demonstrate that absolute dating of the construction of buildings is possible. Such samples can also provide proxy climatic information in wet and dry periods, frost rings (false spring events), and the rate of forest migration onto the Blackland Prairies. CONCLUSIONS 8-42

## Page 351

As noted above, work conducted to date in the SSC project area has consisted of limited pedestrian reconnaissance and test excavations, archival research, and informant interviews. No artifacts have as yet been collected, mapped, excavated, and analyzed. To address effectively both the Primary and Secondary Research Questions as well as the overreaching issue of "marginality”, it is imperative that five courses of action be initiated. The first three steps can be conducted concurrently while the last two must in part be initiated at a later date. 1. The pedestrian survey of the remainder of the ring should be initiated and completed as soon as is feasible, 2. The surface mapping and systematic collection of medium and high priority sites should be effected and the results scrutinized to generate a finalized list of medium and high priority localities suitable for phase II testing. 3. Deep testing should be initiated in appropriate geomorphic settings. 4, Systematic randomized test excavation of selected medium and high priority sites should then be pursued via rigorous data recovery procedures. 5. Systematic comparative scrutiny and analysis of excavated materials from test excavations will be effected in order to address all of the Research Questions noted above as well as to determine which, if any sites, are amenable to or suitable for extensive data recovery. 8-43

| APPENDIX A GEOTECHNICAL REPORTS by Gathel M. Weston, Bill R. Chada, and David H. Jurney From November 1989 to July 1990, personnel of the Archaeology Research Program (ARP), Southern Methodist University (SMU), conducted intensive reconnaissances to identify and inventory cultural resources within impact areas of geological bore holes, trench sites, survey monuments and vehicular traffic routes. All work was completed under contract ESC-98201 with Universities Research Association, Inc. (URA) pursuant to contact with the Department of Energy. The scope of work and methods employed follow stipulations agreed upon during consultations between Diana Lowrey of EG&G Idaho Inc. (EG&G), and William Martin, archaeologist for the Texas Historical Commission (THC) and the Texas State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO). The geotechnical reconnaissances were undertaken to identify all cultural resources, and to design means of avoiding-all archaeological sites or deposits. The survey was conducted in advance of ground disturbance to insure that traffic or excavations could not damage any identified resources which exhibit potential eligibility for the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP). Protection of those sites is required by a number of federal laws and regulations, including but not limited to the Antiquities Act of 1906 (34USC225); Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act of 1935 (49USC666); Archaeological and Historical Conservation Act of 1974 (88USC174); National Historical Preservation Acts of 1966 and 1980 (80USC915 and 94USC2987); National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (83USC852); Executive Order Number 11593 of 1971 (36CFR9821); and Archaeological Resources Protection Act of 1979, 1980, and 1988 (94USC2987, 102USC2778, and 102USC2983). All of these regulations direct federal land managers to implement cultural resources inventory and assessment programs with the consultation of the SHPO, Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, and interested parties. Appropriate treatment or protection programs are to be initiated when the integrity of such resources is threatened by ground disturbing projects, such as the geotechnical exploration program of the SSC project. In addition, the reconnaissance survey was designed to comply with the Secretary of the Interior's Standards and Guidelines (Federal Register 1983). The Council of Texas Archaeologists Guidelines (CTA 1987) and the regulations of the Texas Antiquities Code (13 TAC 41) were addressed as well. The survey was to identify all visible cultural resources in the project area and to investigate the potential for buried cultural resources. Identified cultural resources were to be described as to setting, nature, and extent and condition of preservation. As far as possible (given limited land access and a no collection policy) the identified cultural resources would be evaluatedn for their potential eligibility for the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) or as a State Archaeological Landmark (SHL). If potentially significant resources or resources for which significance could not be determined at this Stage were located, recommendations were made for various cultural resource management options, including preservation, avoidance, testing, surface collection, and further data recovery. The specific guidelines for the survey methodology were also developed in consultation with members of the Texas State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) in Austin, Texas. The guidelines include: (1) in disturbed soils, pedestrian intervals of 20 meters were necessary to examine all access, egress, and turnaround routes; (2) in undisturbed soils, visual transects (20 m) would still be employed, augmented with shovel and trowel testing of at least one cubic foot of soil; (3) no screening was required, but soil profiles were to be closely examined and the soil sifted by hand during and after excavating; (4) if cultural resources were encountered, all ground disturbing activities would immediately halt, and an alternate route investigated and clearly flagged; (5) the SHPO would be notified and the site marked for possible further investigation. All of the above mentioned guidelines were met or exceeded during the Geotechnical Survey. In addition, drill locations were revisited to monitor damage, investigate altemate routes, additional borings, or document the lack of any disturbance. In concert with the ongoing survey of fee-simple areas, State of Texas archaeological site records were examined at the Texas Archaeology Research Lab (TARL), and deed/title and other archival and informant information were collected to use in evaluation of site specific A-l

APPENDIX B GENERAL LAND OFFICE AND WORKS PROGRESS ADMINISTRATION/U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE SURVEYS GLO The original field notes for the initial land grants of Ellis County are kept on file with the Archives Division of the Texas General Land Office (GLO) in Austin. These documents record a number of facts concerning the distribution of the Public Domain. Each certificate file contains affidavits that provide the paper trail for the individual to whom the land was granted, including early sales. For instance some individuals sold their certificates prior to any survey. Also, when the individual was granted, land circumstarices may have prevented the location of all land where desired, necessitating the survey of more tracts, sometimes far removed from the home, to secure the full acreage that was granted. As noted in the Historic Background chapter, there are multiple origins for the land grants which were located in Ellis County. Methodology The contiguous land tracts for all fee simple purchase areas and the ring itself comprise the majority of land tracts that were inventoried. Also, some tracts were selected within the ring to fill out the area of Ellis County which has been samples for this study. In all, 18 land tracts (Table B-1) were recorded. The dates of the original grant and the source of the grant were noted, as well as the actual date of the survey, the surveyor, and the surveying land district. Not all information was recorded within each GLO file, but a representative matrix has been collected. The dates which each land tract was granted range from 1830-1874 (Table B-2). From 1830-1847, these grants were primarily Republic of Texas; from 1847-1856 Peters' and Mercer's Colony grants dominated; landscript and miscellaneous land grants were present from 1856-1861. There was a gap in grants from 1861-1870. At this point (1870) until 1874 only pre-exemption certificates, all from Ellis County were granted (n=11). There is a significant lag effect from the date of the grant to the actual date of the field survey, extending back to the earliest survey (Rafael de la Pena) which was granted in 1830 and surveyed in 1835. A lag of as much as a decade or more was noted for many surveys of the Republic of Texas, many of which were still being located after Texas became a state. Also, the Mercer's and Peters’ Colony grants frequently took several years. It should be pointed out that many of the tracts surveyed were actually the remaining land granted under the terms of the certificate, a portion of which had already been located elsewhere. Of the 185 land tracts, the majority were administered through the Robertson Land District, who also surveyed for the Peters (n=18) and Mercers (n=30) colonialists, and granted 18 tracts directly. ## Page 406

originated from other land districts, but were surveyed by the Robertson Land District. Ellis County administered 62 land grants. The actual field location of surveys began in Ellis County in 1834 (Table B-2). There was a hiatus until 1837, when the Republic of Texas began the operation of disseminating the Public Domain. The Robertson Land District was strictly in charge of surveys until 1848, when Ellis County began a limited number. The Robertson Land District continued to administer most surveys until 1857. The Peters’ and Mercer's certificates or remaining portions of certificates were surveyed by the Robertson Land District from 1850 to 1857 (a single Mercer's certificate was located in 1860). In 1858, Ellis County became the principal administrator of the Public Domain. Even after the Civil War, the remainder of some early land grants from other land districts were still being surveyed in Ellis County. - In all, twenty-two surveyors are represented in the sample of the GLO tracts. Table B-3 lists these surveyors ‘in chronolcgical order. J. G. W. Pearson was the single Mexican Colonial surveyor. Six principal surveyors (B. J. Chambers, D. K. Webb, C. C. Taylor, Dr. Mitchell, J. E. Patton, and G. W. Cunningham) worked for the Robertson Land District. Patton and the Peters' and Mercer's certificates respectfully. Four addition Robertson Land District surveyors, B. P. Hollingsworth, W. W. Partis, Milton Wright, and Posey Gordon performed surveys only in the middle or late 1850's. Ellis County surveyors began with R. A. Davis and were followed by J. Richardson, Milton Knight, J. Hogue and R. Wyatt, R. M. Wyatt, W. W. Knight, C. K. Goodwyn, George Partis, J. G. Gibbons, and J. P. H. Nelson. In summary, the General Land Office surveys provide a detailed history of the dissemination of the Public Domain within the SSC Project area. In all, 48 of the 185 land grants were sold to other individuals and 18 were transferred to heirs. In all likelihood all 66 were never occupied by these individuals. Script surveys were given to individuals for compensation due from the Republic or State, and also were probably never occupied; (an additional 30 tracts). This leaves only 89 tracts which potentially were occupied by those individuals to which the land was granted. Only four certificates mentioned that these were actually homesteads. An additional 11 were specifically pre-exemption certificates which required 3 years of on-site residence. Although some of the Peters’ or Mercer's Colony could have been occupied, this is not necessarily so, since there were complicated residence patterns and legal problems that these people had to surmount. In the final analysis only 15 tracts were definitely occupied by the person to whom the land was granted. The principal point of this exercise is that the division of the Public Domain in Texas is complicated, and interpretations can be biased by certain assumptions. It is not certain that an original grant was occupied by the same person (50% of the SSC tracts were definitely not). Pre-exemption certificates required residence, but even these were sold to other individuals soon after initial filing. The Peters’ and Mercer's grants suffered several problems. First, not all the acreage that a person was entitled to could be placed near to their residence, and second, the legal and social opposition to this impresario system prevented many quan | ——w j = (ila = “7 f i]

Although Peters’ was granted contracts in August and November 1841, and July 26, 1844 (and revised 1843) and Mercer's was granted January 19, 1844, both empresarios had trouble bringing in sufficient numbers of settlers to avoid forfeiture (Connor 1959:36-67). The Ellis County area was the southernmost extent of Peters’ Colony settlers prior to the 1850s; with 57% of the Ellis County population in 1850 (Connor 1959:119). The region's population was opposed to the impresario system, which spawned to Hedge core ware (7-15-1852) during which all Peters' Colony certificates were destroyed. These had to be resurveyed (along with contraction) in the 1850's. WORKS PROGRESS ADMINISTRATION In various arez. of the south and in several Texas counties, the Works Progress Administration and US. Department of Agriculture conducted land tract-by-land tract inventories. These consisted of a preprinted series of questionnaires listing deed/title information, acreages divided to various components of farms, descriptions of selected buildings, landowner/tenant identifications, and dates of land acquisition, and in some cases, building construction or remodeling dates. There is variable quality of recording, but these files are systematized. Unfortunately, curation under County jurisdiction was unsystematic and hazardous. Ellis County is missing 600 files due to water damage. Circumstances could be worse, Navarro County destroyed all of its files in the early 1980s. The data were derived from the WPA surveys for tracts within the East and West Campus areas, Data files have been compiled for the footprint as well, and will be used as needed. Land acquisition (Table B-4) for the farms surveyed in 1936 indicates the approximate initial date of occupation, provided the land was purchased and then occupied by the same family. Generally, it appears that several farms which were purchased during the mid to late nineteenth century remained until the 1930s. There was a peak of land purchases in 1900 with a maximum in 1930. However, in the East Campus area it appears that land changed hands frequently, with current (1936) farms initially purchased at low rates in the nineteenth century, and a major wave of purchases between 1920- 1930. The recording of initial house construction dates (Table B-4) was not consistent in the WPA files, with many of the West Campus buildings noted, but with little associated information or dates of construction. In all 146 building dates are available for the East Campus and only 27 for the West Campus. A trend similar to the land purchase dates is noted with early 1850 and 1870 dates. In the East Campus area more 1890 dates were noted. Construction with East Campus peaked in the 1910 decade (41 structures from 1905 to 1908 and 14 in 1910), with half as many in the 1900 decade and the 1920 decade. This same trend for the early twentieth century is also present in the construction of West Campus buildings. The first page of the WPA files was reserved for land and farm data. The land and farm page contained systematically and consistently recorded data. The area reserved for a house was recorded for 175 tracts in the East Campus area and 63 tracts in the West Campus (Table B-5). In the East Campus the majority of house reservation sizes were within the .5 to 1.0 acre range, with some relatively large house complexes. In the West Campus, house reservations were larger, 1.0 to 2.0 acres, with some large house complexes. The area acreage in cultivation (Table B-6) was recorded for 170 tracts in the East Campus and 89 tracts in the West Campus. The distribution among 17 acreage classifications (1 to 200+ acres) is relatively even. B-4 > op! ft Le — oe a CS

## Page 421

APPENDIX C BRACING FOR THE SUPER COLLISION: THE PEOPLE AND HISTORY OF BOZ, TEXAS by Michael S. Harris The community of Boz, Texas, is about to be erased from the landscape of western Ellis County, Texas. The Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) campus will cover 7800 acres of the immediate vicinity of this area. Hundreds of people will be forced to sell their property and move to different circumstances. This paper is a record of some of the community's history, translated through the words of some of Boz's inhabitants. METHODOLOGY The initial research plan called for a broad-brush sampling of communities and individuals along the circumference of the SSC ring. However, it quickly became apparent that the small community of Boz, Texas, was the area to be most affected by the SSC project and thus it was decided to give special attention to this area. The research perspective employed in this study focuses on an "emic” (Spradley 1980) methodology. The attempt is made to present much of the material from informant’s own point of view (Malinowski 1922). Such approaches have benefited cultural resource management studies in Texas (Nunley 1987; Saunders 1988). Much of the material presented is in dialogue form with speech patterns left intact. In all, ten interviews were conducted with individuals from the Boz area. The responses of several individuals were exerpted to provide a synthetic overview of the mental templates within a small rural community. The information provided in this report was solely based on interviews with current, and former residents of the community. A total of ten people were interviewed in periods lasting from two to six hours each. Some informants were interviewed more than once. These interviews have been synthesized. Oral history is dependent on a person's remembrance of past facts. This, however, is the most pristine method of reconstructing the 1940-1990 settlement. Thus, it should be borne in mind while reading that some of the dates and time periods cited by informants are of only general validity, rather than necessarily calendrically correct. The important aspect of the research, however, is not historical validity, but a reflection of the perceptions and lives of the people of Boz (cf. Langness and Frank 1981). Boz, Texas Today, the community of Boz consists of approximately 60 residences scattered within a 3 mile area southwest of Waxahachie, Texas. Boz is part of a local area consisting of Five Points, Greathouse, and Bethel, which together have historically been connected through the Bethel Church. Approximately one-

## Page 422

third of the residences are trailer homes, there are four or five government built houses and a number of old farming homesteads. Boz is interesting from a number of perspectives. Upon seeing the small community, immediately apparent is that this is a residential, farming, and ranching area with no majcr facilities such as, stores, gas stations, etc. Boz is simply a geographic area with numerous settlements in it. To the outsider, then, Boz is just an agglomeration of homes for people that must work and do their shopping in the nearby town of Waxahachie. To the descendents of some of the original inhabitants, however, the memory of Boz is of a different order. As(_) says, “Boz is like a clan. We tend to our own business and everybody tends to theirs. It's not that we're just neighbors, we're friends. We all know each other's business. Half of us have been there when the children were born and when the mother and daddy died. Just one big family." ( ) contends that Boz is different from nearby communities even in terms of "philosophy." He says, "Most of the people heré in Boz live within their means. They don't try to impress people with cars and expensive houses. If they can't afford it they don't buy it." From the mid-1800s until World War II Ellis County was one of the most productive agricultural areas in the country (Bizzel 1924). Boz, located southwest of Waxahachie, the county seat, was part of the great cotton boom in the U.S. All that the cotton boom entailed is part of the small community's history. The original settlers had black slaves and much land was let out on sharecrop. The names of some of the founding families of Boz are: Brack (actually from Greathouse), Dunaway, Whitefield, Forrester. As was common in new settlements the first generation of children from the community often married each other. Thus, from among the families listed above, Brack married Whitefield, Dunaway married Brack, and Forrester married Dunaway. Slightly later settlers were: Bearden, Jenkins, Sims, and Macready. The pattern was similar. Bearden married Jenkins, and Sims married Whitefield. The second generation from these unions, however, were much more likely to marry outside of the community. The reasons for this are obvious. First, the great amount of first generation intermarriage largely precluded further intermarriage. Second, by the early-to-mid-1900s communication and transportation in the U.S. had improved to the extent that people were much more aware of other places and people. Thus, increasing interaction of people over a wider area led to marriages from further away. Nonetheless, some of the descendents of the original settlers and farmers of Boz are still in the area, living on farms that have been handed down at least three generations. For these people the loss of their land is much more than just a physical loss, much more than simply an exercise in which just compensation will be given for their homes and land. For the descendents, the erasure of Boz is the obliteration of history, a history of people, places, and their relationships. As(_) says, “The mighty oak - you can cut its branches, carve your name, hack at it - but when you cut the tap root it dies. That's us." In this report some of the people of present-day Boz will be presented. Two are old settlers whose families go back almost to the beginning of the area. Another is an old African American man who worked a) a) ‘aa =)

## Page 423

in Boz as a sharecropper during the 1930s and 1940s. The last is a couple who have lived there since 1980 in an old trailer home. In this report, the people speak for themselves with some editing and organization. These people are eloquent and their words ring with such sincerity that to present a distilled version of their words would have been a disservice not only to them, but also to the memory of the community. (_ ), 82 years old, is in good health and retains an active and lively demeanor. Her story is an illustration of some of the history of Boz, particularly of the succession of families living in her and her father's house. She has had a hard life, surviving a couple of marriages and numerous deaths in her family. Yet, she has been able to live as a woman rancher in this overwhelmingly male activity. "I was bom August 7, 1908. I was born just across the branch on the same farm where I live now. I married when I was 18 years old. Maiden name (_—+). After two years of marriage, we moved over to near Greathouse, and then after a year we moved over near Maypearl. Outside of that I've lived in this house 55 years. My mother lived in Alabama and Tennessee. My mother's family began to drift in here during the 1880s. And she come to Texas in 1887 (her mother and father sent for her after they were settled). Daddy was already here. Daddy was from Alabama too. They didn’t know each other there. His mother died when he was 13 years old and his daddy remarried about a year later, and daddy began to drift and he wound up here working. He happened to be working and living with her sister's husband. It was over by the field off of Ganaway Road, on what used to be the Nelson Farm. That's where they met. They married in Boz in 1899 in the middle of August. In the meantime he enlisted and spent three years in the Spanish-American War. Before they lived at their house, they worked land for the Dunaways and Cunninghams. They worked sharecrop. In 1904 my daddy bought the farm right across the branch from where I am now. Daddy bought the Whitefield place, that's where we got the history because the old Whitefield lady was still living. They bought this place (the house that( _) now lives in) in 1932 from the Maxwell's. In 1913 it belonged to the Jennings, then the Lyons (had an old maid daughter), and then Mr. Maxwell (bought 1917-18) and then in 1932 Daddy bought it. This front part of my house is 150 to 170 years old. This was used for slaves. They came twice a year and gave food to the slaves. This was called the commissary. During the depression they'd let you go over there and pick that cotton but you couldn't sell it. But you could make a mattress out of it. I did that. When I married in 1926 I made a mattress. I still have it. In 1936 they killed the cattle. I seen them drive the cows down here and shoot them and cover them up. Because of the government. That's when things went bad. And they didn't give hungry starving people a piece of that meat. They gave the farmers $6 a head. Over there where my Daddy lived, used to be Judge Brack's. They had a two room house. They tore away the slave quarters. Course that's where I was born. A big screened in porch we called the sleeping porch. Course my brother's daughter and her husband moved in there and they finally tore the house away. That was a landmark all those many years. That's the way this young generation will do you. History In the old days the community of Boz was the midway stage coach point between Dallas and Waco and was a bustling village located not far from Waxahachie (for Ellis County history see: Euis County. Historical Workshop 1972; Ellis County Historical Society 1972). The center had three small general stores (one with the post office), a blacksmith's, barber, and a doctor (Dr. Sims). Just across the creek was the cotton gin. The stores were owned by: Graves, Clayton, and Rumsey. One of the stores was later owned by Mr. Self. There were two lodges in the village, Rebeccas and Oddfellows. Oddfellows Lodge was held above Mr. Graves store once a month. As(_+) says: "we did all our shopping there. Momma sold her butter and eggs there. Bought our ice there. Bout twice a year we went to town, The mail was brought once a week by Tom Allen on a mule. We voted in the store where the post office was. We voted there until 20 years ago and then it moved over to Five Points." Similarly, Clayton's store and the blacksmith shop also moved to Five Points during the 1950s. The cotton gin was originally run with a steam generator. In 1915 a power plant was built next door and it switched to electricity. The new electricity also was wired up to the stores across the creek. In 1934 the stockholders of the gin had a falling out and a new owner took over and it operated until 1947. The owner, Mr. Mosely, sold out the gin and its property in the early sixties. Boz experienced floods and drought in the early 1900s and again for seven years in the 1950s. (_) tells how (_ ) father,( +), “witched" for people, a gift which ( ) also has.( _) father found the first community well using the forks of a peach tree (the best for water witching). The fork is held straight up and when water is sensed the fork bends down to the ground. (_) told of the seven year drought in which the only well that didn't go dry in the community was the one owned by J. H. Sims. "He let everyone get drinking water." Still, many people had to haul water for cattle from Forreston, and one man, Pud Maxwell, "would sell water." The Maxwell name is one commonly mentioned by the residents of Boz as one of the former larger landowners of the community. Pud Maxwell is remembered most frequently and less kindly, however: as the one who sold off his land to a developer. The lots are the sites of most of the trailer homes and government houses in Boz. r— f } med C23

EE | | The Boz school had four rooms with a hall down the center and was located near (_+) place, near the Baker Branch. In the early 1900s the school had close to one hundred students and had two or three teachers at different times who taught from elementary through high school. During the 1930s the number of children had dwindled to between fifty and sixty. The school disbanded right after World War II and the building was sold in 1952. Students from Boz were shifted to Forreston. One-half of the school was moved behind the Bethel Church and is today used for a recreation center. A school, (apparently defunct by World War II) for blacks was located across the road from the old Cunningham place which also briefly served as a Black church. The Bethel Church is still located to the south of Boz and today consists of the church, a fellowship or recreation hall, a parsonage and a tabernacle. The present site of the church is the third in its history. The Bethel Cemetery is located just to the south of the church. The church, cemetery, and tabernacle were used in the filming of "Places in the Heart." The Bethel Church, while outside of the area to be affected by the collider has played an important part in the community. It was the first church in the area to start an annual Lord's Acre Sale (in 1952). The Lord's Acre Sale was a method for increasing church revenues. In the beginning, farmers and ranchers put a wooden cross in one of their fields thus denoting that an acre of the harvest would be sold at the church auction. Women offered quilts and canned goods. Near the tabernacle there used to be a corral in which cattle were auctioned during the sale. The tradition continues today. However, the farmers now bring a pledge rather than the actual crop. The sale is accompanied by a free barbecue lunch and entertainment. Economy: Past and Present The economic fortunes of the community and its people mirror nationwide and local trends both historically and in the present. Today, since Boz is little more than a settlement we can speak of its economy as composed of individuals that either work outside of the area (such as in the city of Waxahachie) and those households still involved in ranching. Some of those currently ranching in Boz are the following households: Coker, Muirhead, Bratcher, Murdoch, Allen, Sherman, and Williams. Among those ranching households, the Cokers, Bratcher, and Murdoch are descendents of early inhabitants. The great majority of the other households not involved in ranching are those that work in Waxahachie and the surrounding areas. ( _), for example, are paper deliverers. The people not involved in ranching are generally "newcomers," people that have moved to Boz and built homes. This group is composed of most of the people living in trailer homes. The history of Boz's economy follows that of Ellis County with great productivity of cotton from the late 1800s through its decline in the 1920s through. 1950. In comparison to Dallas, Tarrant, and Johnson Counties, Ellis County had a higher ratio of tenant to owner farms from 1890 to 1940. This was largely due to the preeminence of Ellis County in cotton production.

Some of the original inhabitants began as sharecroppers. For example, ( _) father began as a sharecropper for the Cunninghams and the Dunaways in the late 1800s. By early 1900, however, he was able to acquire some land from the Maxwell family. Similarly, J. M. Dunaway (Francis MacGregor Dunaways grandfather) was hired to be the overseer of E. M. Brack's slaves (c. 1853). J. M. later married Judge Brack's daughter and purchased his own farm. In the mid-1800s, then, slaves were the major form of labor on the cotton farms and a typical farmhouse had small wooden slave quarters near. When slavery ended some of the slaves did remain in the community and worked for their former masters. A number of black families continued to live and work in Boz up into the 1950s. For example, Aunt and Uncle Hayes continued to do the washing for many people in the community. Tootsie became a maid for the Bearden's (Merline Coker's parents). Today there are no black families in the community (see Green 1970 for insight into the black perspective). There are two reasons that most of the blc-k families left Boz. First, the mechanization of cotton production from the late 1930s reduced the physical labor required on the farm. This work, the cotton picking, pulling and chopping, had largely been done by blacks, poor whites, and Mexicans. The cotton economy largely lost its impetus following World War II because of a combination of factors: cheaper foreign cotton became more readily available on the market, yields declined due to overproduction of the cotton monocrop, and the invention of synthetics reduced demand for natural fibers. One black man, (_+), continues to work in Boz, although he lives in Waxahachie. (__) is today a preacher for the Church of Christ and has a Sunday moming radio show. The position of the people living in the uailer homes of Boz is perhaps the more dire. Many of these people are low income earners. They have managed to save and buy their trailers and plots of land. These families will experience the greatest economic hardship when the SSC relocation takes place. There have been public hearings in which the rezoning of Ellis County has been the issue; the county may try to minimize the number of trailer homes allowed in the county. This means that a significant number of Boz residents could have to move to another county, a move which would cause significant disruptions among already impoverished people. All of the people of Boz, not just those in the trailer homes, are waiting for the SSC project to make the final move. The people's situations, whether rancher or town laborer, rich or poor, are presently being controlled by outside forces whose effects are bound to not be benign. BOZ AND THE SUPERCOLLIDER The SSC project will eventually destroy the community of Boz (Figure C-1). For those households which are living on land hel for many years in their family, this is a serious loss. Besides the stress of new and strange people (Supercollider authorities, appraisers, relocation assistants, archaeologists, geologists, etc.) on their land every day, the people have to live with the fact that they will be forced to move. The most unsettling aspect of this, however, is the uncertainty involved. Thus, many of the people in Boz have known since at least 1988 that the SSC would come through their community and have been waiting “for the axe to fall." The tentativeness of their future is quite significant for most of the residents and fosters feelings of powerlessness and anxiety. (__) says: "I feel like I'm just waiting here for my funeral and they're (the SSC administration) going to decide what to do with my body. That's the way it feels. ## Page 436

Adaptation — The process of change to better conform with environmental conditions or other extemal stimuli. Anthropology — The scientific and humanistic study of man's present and past biological, linguistic, social, and cultural variations. Its major subfields are archaeology, physical anthropology, cultural anthropology, and anthropological linguistics. Archaeological Context — The physical setting, location, and cultural association of artifacts and features within an archaeological site. Archaeology (also spelled Archeology) — The scientific study of the physical evidence of past human - societies recovered through the excavation. Archaeologists not only attempt to discover and describe _ past cultures, but also to formulate explanations for the development of cultures. Archaeologist — Anyone with an interest in the aims and methods of archaeology A professional _ archaeologist usually holds a degree in anthropology with a specialization in archaeology and is trained * to collect archaeological information in a proper scientific way. Artifact —- Any object manufactured, used or modified by humans. Common examples include tools, ~ utensils, art, food remains, and other products of human activity. Assemblage — A group of artifacts related to each other based upon some recovery from a common archaeological context. Assemblage examples are artifacts from a site or feature. Atlat!t — A wood or bone shaft implement, held in one hand, and used to propel a spear. The tool functions as a lever, giving greater thrust and distance. Botanist — A person who pursues the scientific study of the structure, growth, and identification of plants, Caddoan Culture Area — The geographical region that encompasses eastern Oklahoma, southwestern Arkansas, western Louisiana, and eastern Texas which was the homeland of the Native American Caddo people. Central Hall — A frame house consisting of two rooms and an enclosed central hall. When this house type is two story it is called an "I" house. Chert — A very fine grained rock formed in ancient ocean sediments. It often has a semi-glassy finish and is usually white, pinkish, brown, gray, or bluegray in color. It can be shaped into arrowheads by chipping. It has often been called flint, but true flint is found in chalk deposits and is a distinctive ~ blackish color. Conservation Archaeology — A subfield of archaeology which focuses on the preservation of archaeological resources. This position encourages the stabilization and preservation of archaeological sites as opposed to their immediate excavation. Cultural Resource Management -— A branch of archaeology that is concerned with developing policies and action in regard to the preservation and use of cultural resources. Cultural Resources — Sites, structures, landscapes, and objects of some importance to a culture or community for scientific, traditional, religious, or other reasons. Daub — Clay used to fill in the holes and gaps between the wood or thatching of a wall. It was used by both Indians and European settlers in North America to construct houses.

x = mea ER He He He HE EE iE Dendrochronology — The scientific study of the annular growth of trees. Trees produce rings of various thickness annually in response to rainfall. Tree-rings therefore, can be used to reconstruct fluctuations in rainfall in the past, reflecting past climatic conditions. Demography — The study of the distribution, density, and vital statistics of populations. Double Crib — Two rooms or chambers connected by a single roof to form a barn used for storage of grains or stabling of animals. Eastern Cross Timbers — A relatively narrow, north-south strip of forested land that divides the Grand Prairie to the west from the Blackland Prairie to the east in North Central Texas. The Eastern Cross Timbers are associated with the sandier soils of the Woodbine geologic formation. Ecology — The study of interrelationships of organisms and their environment. End Scraper — A stone tool formed by chipping the end of a flake of stone which can then be used to scrape animal hides and wood. Fauna — A Latin term which refers to animals remains, as opposed to flora which refers to plant remains. Features — Evidence of human activities visible as disturbances in the soil. Such disturbances are produced by digging pits for storage, setting posts for houses, or by constructing a hearth for cooking. These disturbances are often distinguished by soil discolorations. Flotation — A method of obtaining seeds and other organic materials from soil by using liquids. Flute — A long, narrow flake removed from a spear point to aid in the binding of the point to the spear shaft. Geologist — A person who studies the history of the earth and its life, especialy as recorded in rocks. Gorget — An ornament usually worn over the chest which may be either suspended on a cord or attached directly to clothing. Grit and Grog Tempered Pottery — Sand (grit) and crushed pottery sherds (grog) mixed in the unfired clay to make ceramic vessels stronger. These inclusions prevented the rapid expansion of the paste as the clay's water content was boiled away when the pottery was fired. Hewn — Wood shaped by heavy cutting or chopping blows struck by hand tools such as axes or adzes. Historic Sites Act of 1935 — Public Law 74-292; 49 Statute 666 enabling the authorized expenditure of funds for archaeological studies on major land modification projects. Horticulture — The science and art of growing fruit, flowers, ornamental plants, and vegetables in smali gardens. Incised —- A decoration found on pottery consisting of lines drawn into wet clay. When fired, the arrangement of lines leaves a permanent design on the vessel surface. Interaction Sphere — This term refers to prehistoric groups who shared social interaction and exchanged material goods, through a network made up of long distance trade contacts. Midden — The layer of soil which contains the by-products of human activity as the result of the accumulation of these materials on their living surface. For prehistoric sites, a layer of soil that was stained to a dark color by the decomposition of organic refuse which also contained food bones, fragments of stone tools, charcoal, pieces of pottery, or other discarded materials. For historic sites, a similar layer of soil but with appropriate historic material remains often in a much thinner deposit.

## Page 438

Mortises and Tenons — A method of carpentry joinery where holes are chiseled as receptacles (mortises) for chiseled projections (tenons) on wooden beams. National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 — Public Law 89-665, as amended by Public law 96-515, National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980, 94 Stat. 2987. This act and its amendments clearly established the basic funding and implementation of archaeological work in federally funded projects. National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) — The administrative branch of the Department of Interior that officially reviews nominations of archaeological and historic sites and structures, and guides the federal implementation of cultural resources legislation. Obsidian — A volcanic glass which is one of the finest raw materials for the chipping of stone tools. Oral History — Verbally transmitted information about past events. Although often providing information about non-written events, such history is subject to the vagaries of human perceptions and mental recall. Outbuildings — A term used to refer to all non-residential structures on a site. These include animal pens, storage buildings, sheds, barns, etc. Outcrops — A term designating the surface exposure of rock layers, which have not been decomposed into soil. Palynologist — One who studies plant pollen and spores. Since pollen may be preserved thousands of years it can be used to reconstruct the plant ecology of the past. Parallel Flaking — A technique used in the production of stone tools that is often found on the earliest projectile points from North Central Texas. Long, consistent chipping scars run parallel on the flat sides of stone tools. Petroglyphs — Carvings in rock which express artistic or religious meaning. Pictographs — Paintings on rock which express artistic or religious meaning. Pleistocene —- A geologic period, usually thought of as the Ice Age, which began about 1.6 million years ago and ended with the melting of the large continental glaciers creating the modem climatic pattern about 11,500 years ago. Prehistoric Hunter-Gatherers — Humans who lived prior to written history and depended upon the hunting of wild animals and the gathering of natural plant foods for their livelihood Prehistoric Sites — Locations where people who were alive before modern written records existed once lived, hunted, camped, or were buried. Painted or carved rock outcrops are considered sites as well. Provenience — The three-dimensional location of an artifact or feature within an archaeological site, measured by two horizontal dimensions, and a vertical elevation. Psoralea ssp. — The prairie turnip, as it is commonly referred to, is actually several species of plants which grow underground tubers. Only one species was actually recorded as having been used by Plains Indians, and only recently has any archaeological evidence for the use of this plant been recovered. Public Archaeology — (see also Conservation Archaeology) A movement to increase public awareness and eduction about archaeology which advanced the legislative attempts to provide funding and protection for archaeological sites. ## Page 439

Punctates — Impressions in the surface of ceramic vessels made by implements or by fingernails as a form of decoration. Quartzite — A stone which was formed in water deposited sediments and consists of sand grains which have been cemented together. It can be chipped, but is difficult to work. Radiocarbon Dating — A process that provides absolute dates by counting the radioactive decay of carbon in the remains of once living plants and animals (j.e., charcoal, wood, bone, shell). Rescue Archaeology — A term applied to the emergency salvage of sites in immediate danger of destruction by major land modification projects such as reservoir construction. Sedentary — A term applied to human groups leading a settled, non-migratory lifestyle. Sherds — The individual pieces of broken pottery vessels. Site — A location where human activities once took place and left some form of material evidence. Soil Scientists — One who studies the distribution, fertility, and chemical and organic composition of the upper layer of the Earth. State Archaeologist — An appointed official who is responsible for overseeing all potential impacts to archaeological resources and for reviewing and administering all archaeological work in order to insure compliance with state and federal regulations. Stone Boiling — A type of cooking that is done by heating stones in an open fire and then placing them in the liquid or substance to be cooked. This is often done in baskets or containers that cannot be placed directly in or over a fire. Subsistence Economy — The means by which a group obtains the food and shelter necessary to support life. Territory — The familiar surroundings or home range which is claimed by a group of people. Test Excavations — Subsurface excavations in areas which are either defined as sites based on surface artifacts or thought to contain buried deposits based on the landform. Texas Archaeological Research Laboratory — An branch of the University of Texas at Austin that has been appointed as the official state registry for archaeological sites and the repository for archaeological collections. Timber Frame — an early English building technique using sawn or hewn lumber (cut using hand tools) and joined with mortises and tenons (holes and pegs) instead of nails. Tool Kit — The set of all weapons and tools that was created and used by a person or group of people. Working Period Farm — A term usually associated with a working museum exhibit in which a full scale farm has been restored or reconstructed to depict the former lifeways, tools, and technologies of Zoology — A branch of biology that is concemed with the scientific study of animals, including their biology, distribution, and identification.
